Mr. Speaker, we have had meetings with the mayors of Toronto and Montreal. The Minister of Justice met with the mayors of Toronto and Montreal, then held another meeting with the newly elected mayor of Toronto and then another meeting with Mayor Dore in Montreal. Then there was a meeting in April in Toronto with four big city mayors of Toronto, Vancouver, Montreal and Calgary. On April 25, 1992 the Minister of Justice and Attorney General held a meeting in Vancouver with 19 big city mayors to review precisely these problems.
I would like the Leader of the Opposition to know that we have been making ongoing progress in very substantial ways with big city mayors over the last year in dealing with some of the fundamental root causes to which he refers.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the Prime Minister.
Yesterday the Prime Minister clearly said he would be delighted to meet the mayors. Today, there is an official request from the chairman of the caucus of big city mayors of Canada to discuss the problems of urban crime and violence and other aspects as well, such as infrastructures, housing and unemployment. They are asking for a meeting with the Prime Minister of Canada. Will the Prime Minister say yes to this request?

Mr. Speaker, the Leader of the Opposition changed his mind in mid-sentence.
He asked me yesterday whether I would agree to meet the big city mayors to discuss urban crime, racial discrimination, and so forth. Today I explained what we would do, and he refers to a request he received from the mayor of London, Ontario, not to discuss those problems but to discuss infrastructures, sewers and similar issues.
Now the hon. member for Toronto says that sewers are the biggest social problem in Canada. Let us be reasonable. I already told the Leader of the Opposition that if it would be helpful and worth while. We would be delighted to meet the mayors.
I think it is rather odd that the Leader of the Opposition received a request for a meeting from the mayor of London, Ontario, while I did not.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yesterday the Prime Minister was complaining that perhaps something is not working. This letter is addressed to the Prime Minister of Canada. It was sent to him and he claims he has not receive it. He should speak with the people around him.

I have a copy of this letter asking to meet with the Minister of Justice. What confidence can the mayor and municipalities have to meet when the Minister of Justice dismissed such a possibility yesterday when she said: "I do not want to reinvent wheels that are already rolling happily along".
Shame, shame.

Was the Minister of Justice expressing the view of the Prime Minister when she said more or less that what is going on in Montreal and Toronto these days is already rolling happily along?
Does the government not realize that we have major problems in Canadian cities today and should not be flippant like the Minister of Justice was yesterday?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would have to go a long way to be as flippant as that question.
I did not suggest the cities of Montreal and Toronto and their problems are rolling happily along. What I talked about was the importance of developing a strategy with the big cities on how we can come together and really make progress in this area, not simply to have a meeting for the sake of having a meeting, but genuinely to exchange information.
The hon. Leader of the Opposition may not understand that, but I can tell him the mayors of Canada's big cities understand it very well indeed.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Justice.
The United Nations has found Canada guilty of having the highest rate of drug crimes per capita in the developed world. Canada's police forces could do more to combat our nation's drug epidemic if they were not financially handcuffed while millions of dollars raised from the seizure of assets disappears into federal revenues every year.
I ask the minister why she has yet to amend the proceeds of crime legislation so that local police forces can use the forfeited funds to finance new equipment, training and community education programs that are vital to their drug enforcement efforts.
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as my colleague, the Solicitor General, mentioned in the House this week we are certainly reviewing the process by which proceeds of crime can be distributed among various levels of government.
It is important to point out that while we have taken the leadership in bringing forward this legislation, there is not a great pot of money out there for proceeds of crime that have been brought in. In fact the law enforcement challenges in this area are very great.
What we have done is we have announced three specialist task forces in Vancouver, Toronto, and Montreal, the major drug trafficking centres of this country, to focus on using the proceeds of crime legislation.
Before we can redistribute the proceeds of crime we have to get our hands on them. That is our first priority.

Mr. Speaker, I am happy to hear that the minister knows her priorities. She must also know that every year there are around 60,000 drug offences in Canada.
The Addiction Research Foundation claims this drug abuse costs the Canadian economy $11.5 billion annually. In the face of this world scale problem the government allocates less than $60 million annually for its anti-drug strategy. Only a fraction of this is aimed at law enforcement.
I ask the minister to reinforce this government's feeble anti-drug strategy so that local police forces can have the funds they need to purge this blight on Canada's international reputation.

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am quite enchanted by the interest of that hon. member and her party in this question.
I seem to recall before I became a member of this House when the Prime Minister made a speech in Vancouver in 1987 about Canada's growing drug problem, members of her party, members on her side of the House, accused the Prime Minister of exaggerating the problems. I am delighted those hon. members have come to their senses.

Oral Questions
This government remains dedicated to tackling the problems of drug trafficking. We are doing so with sophisticated efforts at consultation and co-ordination with other law enforcement bodies. We believe that our efforts will have success.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to put my question to either the Prime Minister or the Minister of Justice.
We have a disturbing report from Montreal today from Special Coroner Harvey Yarosky on police practices in regard to minority communities. We have more optimistic news from Ontario with the appointment of Stephen Lewis and Zanana Akande to advise on race relations.
The minister and the Prime Minister will know that the federal government has had reports on the shelf for some time, including the Marshall inquiry about racism in Nova Scotia and the justice system, the Manitoba justice support system and aboriginal people, Law Reform Commission reports, and so on. We need national leadership on the question of racism and crime prevention in the justice system.
I want to ask the Prime Minister or the Minister of Justice: What is it that they propose? Do they have a strategy and could they tell the House succinctly what it is?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, yes we do have a strategy. It is hard to tell the House succinctly what it is because there is so much of it. I will try to be as brief as possible.
With respect to aboriginal justice, I co-hosted with the minister of Justice of the Yukon last September a national conference on aboriginal justice in Whitehorse. That was the first time that such a conference had been held. Fifty per cent of the participants were aboriginal people.
The Government of Canada has committed almost $25 million to the funding of pilot projects and prototypes of the delivery of justice services to aboriginal people to meet our commitment to ensure that the Canadian justice system is able to do justice for aboriginal people.
With respect to other areas, my colleague, the Minister of State for Multiculturalism and Citizenship, has indicated in this House that one of the major thrusts of his department has been in the area of multicultural policing in the area of law enforcement and our visible minority communities in Canada. This is a strong commitment by this government, a commitment that we have met not just with words but with money, programs and very great effort.

Mr. Speaker, we would like to have some results too. We have had cutbacks, especially with social programs in the inner city. The government and the country can see the results.
I want to ask the minister to get specific. Give Canadians specific programs. She mentioned yesterday in the House that she was prepared to change what is called the fleeing felon rule. Generally that is a rule in which police officers may fire a gun at anyone avoiding arrest even if no lives are in danger.
I want to ask the minister to get specific. Could she tell the House what her proposals are in this area, what they will be and will they be similar to the 1987 Law Reform Commission report, the commission she is axing? Will the minister please be specific and tell us her specific proposals on the fleeing felon rule?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am not going to make policy on the floor of the House and I am not going to indicate the details of the legislation until it has gone through cabinet, but I am prepared to take it there.
As I have indicated to the House, in fact, in response to a request by the Government of Ontario in 1989 and other of my provincial colleagues, we have been working on this issue and are now ready to go forward to cabinet.
We will clarify the law to make very clear the liabilities and obligations of law enforcement officers with the use of deadly force in a way that I hope will strike a balance to enable law enforcement officers to do their job safely and to protect people around them and at the same time to assure Canadians that excessive use of force will not be part of enforcing the law in this country.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to return to my role as critic for youth in posing a question to the Prime Minister.
When the United Nations proclaimed International Youth Year it talked of the potential for an explosion among alienated, unemployed and powerless youth.
During International Youth Year a number of reports were produced by the Senate and by our party. Young people presented a number of recommendations. I know the government believes that in a number of ways it has responded.
I ask the Prime Minister: Would his government be willing, perhaps in-co-operation with other levels of government, to revisit the recommendations of that time urgently? We all believe that present circumstances justify doing so, to react to a situation that for many young people in this country is still becoming worse. It requires some kind of a response on a coherent basis throughout the country.

speakeroldname: Hon. Pierre H. Cadieux (Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport) and Minister of State (Youth) and Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport); Minister of State (Youth); Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party Deputy House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as the hon. member knows, there have been some studies in the past and there are still studies going on.
The government has acted with respect to the youth strategy. Obviously we have dedicated a lot of time and money to the major problem of youth in Canada, which is the dropout problem. My predecessor put forward a strategy to make sure our youth complete their education and have the necessary tools to face all the challenges they are going to be facing as the years go by, with all the technological changes and all the demands they will have on their future.
By keeping our youth in school, giving them an education and making sure that the economic fundamentals of this country are in place, I believe they will have a future that they can look forward to and that we have the responsibility to give them.
Oral Questions TRADE

Mr. Speaker, yesterday the Minister for International Trade said that Canada will seek separate bilateral deals with Mexico in the areas of agriculture and textiles, separate from the proposed North American free trade agreement.
Could the government explain why it has singled out textiles and agriculture from the proposed agreement, excluding them from the agreement for special treatment?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think what has happened is that if we cannot get trilateral agreement on these issues then we will try for separate arrangements between Canada and Mexico.
It may be that you will have difficulty with respect to agriculture. Ultimately you may find the textile situation resolved in the trilateral talks.
What the minister was trying to indicate was that we are prepared to make separate agreements to get an agreement and to protect Canadian manufacturers.

Mr. Speaker, that is an interesting departure in policy on the part of the government. I am glad to have confirmation of this tendency which I have been attempting to obtain for some time.
I take this from the minister's answer and let me pose it as a question. If indeed the government chooses to seek bilateral deals in agriculture and textiles, is it also the government's intention to seek bilateral deals with Mexico in other areas of contention such as automobiles and to exclude those from a trilateral agreement?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me make it very clear that it is our intention and has always been our objective to have an all inclusive trilateral agreement. That is still the objective.
We will only consider bilateral agreements when all else fails.

Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, in the three years and three months since free trade Canada's auto workers have lost 22 per cent of their jobs and this figure keeps rising.
I would like to ask the minister responsible just what specific measures the government proposes dealing with content and other measures to promote Canadian auto jobs and undo the damage this government has already done.

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, let me take the preamble of that question first.
It is very clear that there has been a major restructuring right across the globe in terms of automobiles. The hon. member picks on the Canadian sector which in many ways has fared no worse than many other countries.
With respect to his particular question, we made considerable progress in terms of the free trade agreement. Our objective is clear. We want to enhance and protect the Canadian auto workers and the Canadian automobile industry in the NAFTA even more than we did in the FTA.

Mr. Speaker, the minister says that Canada's auto workers have suffered no worse a fate than our counterparts. We have lost 22 per cent of our auto jobs since free trade. The Americans have lost only 10 per cent.
When is this government going to get serious about its negotiating? Let me ask: the Mexicans are proposing a lengthy embargo against Canadian used cars going into Mexico. What precisely is this government doing to stand up to this embargo and ensure that it is not just one measure that costs us even more auto jobs in Canada?

speakeroldname: Hon. William C. Winegard (Minister for Science):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member knows very well that we are making some progress on the auto negotiations.
I do not understand why in all of this members on the other side of the House have not mentioned the $2 billion investment by Ford for the auto industry and other things to come.
It always has to be the negative, never the positive.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of National Health and Welfare.
This week he announced an action plan allocating $500 million to children at risk. This plan, as we all know, has been severely criticized by organizations working on behalf of children and Canada's poor.
Yesterday in Winnipeg the minister stated, and I quote: "Poverty is not a children's reality".

In French: Ce n'est pas la realite des enfants. [English\
Could the minister please explain what he means by this to the over one million Canadian children living in poverty?
Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health
and Welfare): Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to answer questions about the strategy for the first time.
First, the member is wrong. The action plan is not $500 million. There are four different approaches to the question of the convention signed by the Prime Minister, and the $500 million is one part of the $2 billion we have set aside.
I said yesterday in Winnipeg, as I said in Toronto and in Montreal, that poverty in this country is not the responsibility of children. It is the responsibility of all of society, as are the needs of children. We are trying to fix the problem. We are looking after the problems of one million children in Canada who need to be helped not only in terms of resources but in terms of the way we look after them. That is why I called for action by all Canadians, not just by the government, in a way to help those people.
I call on my friend not only to say that we need more money. I call on all members and all other Canadians to look after the children of this country in a way that will enable them to face the reality they will have to face in the future. I hope deeply that we will go beyond the question raised by the hon. member. If all Canadians want to put kids on the map then the kids will be looked after in this country.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the same minister. I think Canadians are looking for the government to accept its responsibility for the plight of Canada's one million poor children, for the failure of economic policies in this country which has generated that problem.
This week we have heard a number of ministers talking about the importance of government economic policy, how useful it has been, and how much money is going to children. If all these policies are so good and working so well, why after eight years of Conservative government has the number of food banks in this country risen from 75 to over 300?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the member knows very well we have not invented that. We are in a recession, in a period of economic difficulty. In those circumstances Canadians must consider any way they can help.
On Sunday afternoon I was at the Daily Bread Food Bank in Toronto and had a very good meeting with the people responsible. Everybody has to look at ways in which we can help people get out of poverty, particularly kids.
It is not enough to say only that we do not have enough resources. We must get involved ourselves in the way to help children out of poverty and to deal with the future.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
Over 10,000 aboriginal youth in Winnipeg are looking for training programs so that they can find jobs. Yet under the UI rules brought in by this government they cannot access this training.
Instead of announcing a so-called Better Futures program, why does this government not change its policies and provide a better future for these youth in Winnipeg?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member refers to the plight of unemployed youth in Canada. I am also very sensitive to it. That is why we have in
Oral Questions
place programs that attempt to help those people to find work through better skills and better training.
The hon. member refers to the lack of programs in Winnipeg. I beg to differ in opinion on this with him. I do not have the exact numbers here, but it is literally tens of millions of dollars that we spend in Manitoba to help unemployed people.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the same minister.
The minister knows that one must be a UI recipient to access easily the moneys for these programs. Yet these youth are not able to get jobs in Winnipeg and therefore cannot access these programs. The minister knows that is the real problem but refuses to deal with it.
The minister's own department in describing the unemployment scene in Manitoba said: "There is no escape" from this employment market. There is no escape for the 11.2 per cent who are unemployed. There is no escape for 41,000 Winnipegers looking for work.
Why does the minister not change some of these policies and provide work for these 41,000 people?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I know-and it was
clear yesterday at the call of his leader-that the hon. member and his party are still calling for yesterday's solution to today's problem: throw money at the problem.
Canadians want more than their tax money being thrown at the problem. Rather, they want us to activate the passive funds out there for income security and try to help people to train, to get better skills and eventually get into the job market.
There is a host of programs in place to do just that.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of health.
This morning the minister tabled the government's response to the health and welfare subcommittee's report on poverty. Among the many recommendations that were rejected was one asking the minister to table yearly in Parliament a full report on progress made to eliminate child poverty.

Oral Questions
Why does the minister refuse to make public his government's record on child poverty?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we consider the announcement we made this week in Brighter Futures a long-term framework to deal with one of the issues, with child poverty, and particularly what we do with the $2 billion for low income workers. Of course the strategy is a start and it will progress.
I will be pleased to report on the way we can help children, not necessarily overcome the problem of poverty, because as I said yesterday in his home city of Winnipeg poverty is not the exclusive reality of children. It is a problem of society. The answer to poverty in Canada is in good economic policies and good management. This is done by the Minister of Finance. It will help children and other citizens to get out of that.
We have to move on.

Mr. Speaker, the request was for the minister to table yearly in Parliament a full report.
My supplementary question is for the same minister. The minister also refused to develop an action plan to eradicate child poverty by the year 2000. Why did the minister refuse to develop this action plan? How does the minister expect to eradicate child poverty in Canada without a clear plan of action?

speakeroldname: Hon. Benoit Bouchard (Minister of National Health and Welfare):
speakerposition: Minister of National Health and Welfare
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, once again it is a mistake to say that we will develop a plan for child poverty and not relate to the problem of poverty as a society.
We do not have the resources that the Liberal Party has. We do not have what it asks for. We have said that we did what should be done. We have asked Canadians to help children in Canada. We believe that with the help of people it will be possible to do something within the capacity we have.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister and it concerns children who are dying.
Last week James Grant, the executive director of UNICEF reported that there are severe food shortages, widespread malnutrition and a spectacular return of many infectious diseases in Iraq.
In light of this, I would like to ask the Prime Minister when his government will respond positively to the proposal of Dr. Eric Hoskins to release some $2 million in frozen Iraqi assets in Canada directly to the highly respected Canadian charitable organization, Global Med-Ed Supplies to allow for the purchase of infant formula and medicine for children in order to meet the solemn commitment made by the Prime Minister at the World Summit for Children in 1990 to work carefully to protect children from the scourge of war.

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to advise the member that the Secretary of State for External Affairs has this issue under consideration. We are very concerned about the humanitarian situation in Iraq.
She has indicated that the government is prepared to examine the proposals by Dr. Hoskins, but an eventual decision will have to support Canadian policy toward Iraq and also be consistent with both Canadian and UN legal requirements.

Mr. Speaker, the minister will know that the United Nations has specifically permitted this and as each day goes by more children are dying.
The Harvard study team on the gulf which was chaired by Dr. Hoskins has estimated that more than 50,000 children have died since the end of the war in the gulf and 300 children are dying each and every day.
In light of these staggering figures, will the government consider to this charitable organization releasing the funds which have been seized? Will the government consider providing matching CIDA funds to supplement these funds to ensure that the commitments that have been made by the Prime Minister at the world summit for children are met and that no more innocent victims of this war, particularly children, are created.

speakeroldname: Hon. Mary Collins (Associate Minister of National Defence and Minister Responsible for Status of Women):
speakerposition: Minister responsible for the Status of Women; Associate Minister of National Defence
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to advise my colleague that the Canadian government has been very supportive, through a whole variety of programs, cash and donations to other humanitarian activities. We have in fact provided over $23 million of support for food and humanitarian assistance to Iraq.
We will continue to work very carefully on this. My colleagues, the minister responsible for CIDA and the Secretary of State for External Affairs, will address various options and work in support of the children of Iraq and children everywhere around the world.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Justice.
Pornography is a multi-million dollar industry in Canada and a multi-billion dollar industry in North America.
The Supreme Court recently, in the Butler case, linked obscenity to violence against women and children. Surely now the Minister of Justice no longer has any excuse for not bringing forward tough new laws to deal with pornography, particularly child pornography. When will she do this?

speakeroldname: Hon. Kim Campbell (Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am delighted that the provisions of the Criminal Code were held to be constitutional by the Supreme Court of Canada. This has reduced a lot of the uncertainty among law enforcement authorities around the country and I firmly expect that these provisions of the code will be more strictly enforced.
With respect to child pornography, we are now looking at the implications of the Butler decision. The Butler decision did make some interesting references on the relationship of the definition of obscenity to pornography involving children, which I think provides some current basis for charges to be laid.
Oral Questions
I have made a commitment and I will bring forward, although it may not be until early in the fall, legislation we are now aiming to fill in any gaps in the law that would exist, even in light of the Butler decision. I share the hon. member's concern and we are acting as quickly as we can and I hope by the fall to have new legislation.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the minister for that answer. We will be looking forward to that new law, because as was stated by the Badgley commission in 1984, violence and child pornography almost always relates to child abuse. Canadians are sick and tired of people making money out of this trash.
My supplementary question is for the Minister of National Revenue. Canadians are also concerned about the amount of pornography coming into the country. They are concerned that customs is losing the battle against keeping this obscene literature out of the country. We know that the customs officers are understaffed. What is the Minister of National Revenue doing to assure Canadians that this trash is not going to be coming into Canada and certainly not in increasing numbers as it is now?

speakeroldname: Hon. Otto Jelinek (Minister of National Revenue):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I take exception to the hon. member's suggestion that there is an increase of this trash, as he put it, coming into Canada.
Our customs officers have and continue to be vigilant. There are some 3,500 excellently trained customs officers to protect Canadian society exactly from such trash coming into this country.
We have brought greater efficiency to the borders. We have brought in new technology. We have brought in new systems.
Another correction I would want to make to the hon. member's question is that we have not reduced customs officers at the borders, in fact we have increased our vigilance. We are continuing to increase the personnel at the borders in order to protect Canadian society from the illegal importation of pornography, illegal firearms and drugs as well.

Oral Questions UNEMPLOYMENT

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of employment.
As a result of government cutbacks in Winnipeg, just one example of what is happening in Canada, tuition fees at one university are increasing by 16 per cent this year and student debt is growing at unmanageable rates. There are often two-year waiting lists for training programs. Thousands of students are without jobs today as we speak. Three hundred staff in one university in the city of Winnipeg will be without jobs very shortly.
These conditions destroy our cities. They demoralize our youth and other Canadians. Why has this government permitted this situation to develop?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, surely the hon. member knows better than trying to shift or pass the blame to the government for a situation that is not peculiar to the city of Winnipeg but is present in the whole of North America and indeed in the world.
When we look at the youth programs, if we are going to measure the caring of the government by the number of dollars we take out of taxpayers to throw back at them, I think that is the wrong recipe. I know that is the recipe of the Liberal Party.
We would rather have a program. The reasons he has mentioned and the thrust of the prosperity initiative, if you care to look at it, is exactly to attack the fundamentals which the hon. member has referred to.
Instead of trying to blame one another, why do we not join Canadians and try to improve the situation within our fiscal framework?

Mr. Speaker, possibly the people of Canada will accept that next time around.

My supplementary question is directed to the same minister. Youth unemployment has now reached 17 per cent and continues to rise. In one employment centre in Winnipeg there were 10 students every 15 minutes looking for jobs, something that is becoming increasingly hard to find.
How can the government expect these students to be able to pay a 16 per cent increase in tuition fees and manage their debts which are increasing at an alarming rate, when there are hardly any jobs and when this government keeps reducing financial support for their education?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, when the hon. member refers to students' debts, he seems to be suggesting that Canadians pass the debt on to someone else, to our children and grandchildren. We must live within our means and try to use taxpayers' money as intelligently as we can, by implementing measures that will guarantee a prosperous future for our country, for our young people, the not-so-young and everyone in this country. That is exactly what the government is trying to do with its prosperity initiative, which, instead of asking people to blame someone else, invites Canadians to work together to try and find long-term solutions, not with last year's or the last century's methods but with the methods of the future.
*
*

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed either to the Minister of Finance or the minister responsible for small business.
I think members on all sides of this House have been hearing from constituents involved in business that Canada's big banks are throttling back dramatically on the amount of lending they are providing those businesses.
In the face of credit reductions, called loans and diminished loan levels which are extending the recession and flying in the face of the federal budget, what action is the government prepared to take?

speakeroldname: Hon. Tom Hockin (Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Small Businesses and Tourism)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think the House will agree that if a government has the lowest interest rates in the industrialized world, has the most responsible policy in the industrialized world, we still are going to have a slower recovery if there is restriction of credit in the economy.



We have been very concerned about this during the last two or three months and we are monitoring it closely. This was one reason why the Minister of Finance, in his budget, brought in the expansion of the Small Businesses Loans Act. The Small Businesses Loans Act guarantees 85 per cent of the losses and is guaranteed by the federal government. Very little capital has to be put aside for participation in it by the banks.
I encourage the banks to use it. It is going to open up credit and help small and medium sized businesses. I plead with financial institutions, and I might add the trust companies and the insurance companies as well, to participate in expanding and commercial lending after June 1. All of this is what the small business community needs.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Environment.
There has been a tremendous effort by the community of Truro, Nova Scotia, to develop an environmental exposition. Even though there is basic agreement by the business, the government organizations and the organizers, unfortunately consensus has eluded them.
Will the Minister of the Environment participate and assist by appointing someone to co-ordinate the effort and try to bring all the parties together to develop a proper proposal?

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean J. Charest (Minister of the Environment):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have had the opportunity of visiting Truro with my friend from Cumberland-Colchester, I think it was in the month of June last year. At that time I also had the benefit of a presentation made by officials and those people very interested in this innovative project. We undertook to examine the proposals that would come forward.
I would be more than happy to be of any assistance to try to find some consensus, as the member indicates, in bringing this project forward. I can assure him that my department and the government will look very closely at this proposal that is very important to the member for Cumberland-Colchester.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Right Hon. Prime Minister.
Oral Questions
Yesterday the Prime Minister confirmed that he was ready to betray the Quebecers who voted for him in 1988 and gave him 63 seats. We all know that they got into bed all they could with the nationalists and sovereignists. Today the Prime Minister is prepared to turn around 180 degrees and deny all those who gave him power.
I ask the Prime Minister how, from his seat as Prime Minister of Canada, which he obtained with Quebec's support, he can now turn around and try to break
Quebec.

Mr. Speaker, I see a constant improvement in the hon. member's situation.
Today he talks about betraying Quebecers, which I suppose means betraying a democratic mandate. I think that a careful examination of the situation would show that the only one in this debate who betrayed a democratic mandate is the member for Shefford, who was elected as a federalist Liberal in the most recent election and once elected, betrayed the people of Shefford by changing his position without consulting them.

Mr. Speaker, unlike the Prime Minister, I am ready to test my mandate at any time. If the Prime Minister has the same courage, let him follow me and call an election!
I challenge the Prime Minister to test his own mandate with Quebecers. He is trying to do a strongarm job on them.
I ask the Prime Minister whether he will have the nerve to go back on all the commitments he made in 1984 and 1988 and try to catch Quebec unawares as he announced yesterday, without shame or embarrassment.

Mr. Speaker, that is a fine offer from the hon. member. He is prepared. Having crossed the floor of the House, renounced the heritage of the federalist Liberal Party which made it possible for him to be elected in Shefford and having agreed to be a minister in a federal Liberal Cabinet, he now says that others in the House have betrayed their mandate. No, it is the other way around. Now he says that he is prepared to test his mandate. It is not a big mandate, is it? It is not a big mandate, Jean, but we will test it for you. Resign and I will call a by-election as soon as possible.

Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of the Environment. It has to do with the growing concern in Manitoba about the Assiniboine River water diversion.
I wonder if the minister, having had time to make himself aware of the resolution passed by the city of Winnipeg council, which is concerned about the reduction in the quality of water flowing through Winnipeg and possible other negative environmental effects, can tell the House today if he is considering a federal environmental assessment review process for this diversion project, as has been requested by the city of Winnipeg and by numerous other groups in rural Manitoba as well.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean J. Charest (Minister of the Environment):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I to thank the hon. member who had the courtesy of informing me that he would ask this question at the beginning of Question Period. I am going to look into this matter.
Maybe it would be useful for me to remind members of the House that following the Supreme Court decision in the Oldman Dam case in January, the Supreme Court affirmed that the federal government is able to do an environmental assessment review when there is an affirmative regulatory power involved.
I will look at this matter at the request of the hon. member to determine whether or not this is the case.
The hon. member for Cape Breton- East Richmond, the Thursday afternoon question.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. Yesterday the Prime Minister said in the House: "Mr. Speaker, I- "
Just a moment. I intended that Question Period come to an end. I was recognizing the hon. member for Cape Breton-East Richmond on the Thursday question.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext: I am sure, Mr. Speaker, you would get unanimous consent from the Prime Minister to have at least one more question.
The hon. member.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. Yesterday he said in the House: "I will be happy to meet with anyone at any time if it might be helpful in dealing with the given problem". Today the mayor of London wrote to the Prime Minister and I quote: "In response to your comments in the House of Commons on May 6,1992, we are pleased to learn of your willingness to meet with the big city mayors".
I ask the Prime Minister: Will he now meet with the big city mayors?

Mr. Speaker, I indicated to the Leader of the Opposition that I had not received the request for the meeting from the mayor of London, Ontario. I have already indicated that there have been many meetings with big city mayors across the country but that at any point in time, if any group of Canadian citizens, including big city mayors, wanted to meet with me to discuss the problems that have been raised on the floor of the House this week, I would be happy to meet with them.
That has always been my position and I would be happy to maintain it.
And now the hon. member for Cape Breton-East Richmond on the Thursday afternoon question.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext: Madam Speaker, I have several questions to put to the government House leader. Perhaps he could explain to the House the nature of the business that will take place for the remaining part of today, tomorrow, Monday and Tuesday. Thereafter, I have a number of questions pertaining to the enabling legislation as it relates to a referendum.

speakeroldname: Hon. Harvie Andre (Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this afternoon we will be commencing a special debate to take note of Canada's position at the UNCED conference in Brazil. By consent of the House that debate will carry on into the evening.
Tomorrow, Friday, May 8, and Monday, May 11, I intend to call an allotted day and I would like to officially designate tomorrow an allotted day.
On Tuesday the government will call Bill C-36, an act respecting corrections and the conditional release for conclusion of report stage and third reading.
In terms of business for the remainder of the week, I will engage in the usual discussions with the opposition parties to confirm that business.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
The government House leader will know certain undertakings were given by the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs and by the Prime Minister with regard to meaningful consultations in terms of the enabling legislation on the referendum.
The only opportunity opposition members have had is to receive information from the government House leader, but there have been no meaningful consultations. I am wondering if the government House leader could indicate to the House and to members in this party as to whether he has an answer or if he can respond to my suggestion of yesterday as to whether a committee of members of Parliament of this House ought to be convened for the purposes of looking at the draft legislation prior to its tabling to ascertain whether there are errors and omissions or different points which may be included in this particular piece of legislation.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, what the hon. member seems to be suggesting is we have committee stage
Business of the House
before we have the bill introduced. I am not quite sure what advantage that provides to ensuring better legislation.
As I indicated in conversations with the hon. member, in the House leaders meeting and in the House yesterday, the intent is pretty simple. It is to basically use the Elections Act if a referendum or a plebiscite is required; to use the Elections Act in terms of enumeration, holding of polling, allocation of polling stations, et cetera.
The other questions as to rules on who may campaign and limits, et cetera, are being examined now in light of restraints under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms and legal opinions have been sought on that. The government is looking at those. I will certainly discuss with the hon. member, his colleague or anybody else the leader of the New Democratic Party would designate these kinds of questions.
We are talking here about technicalities, really minutia in a sense. There are no great issues of policy here. We are talking about if a plebiscite is held, the rules of the Election Act would prevail. It will be by secret ballot and every illegible Canadian will have an opportunity to vote. There will be no question of fairness. The fairness will be there as there is in our election system and always has been.
We need to have rules that can stand up to charter challenge and that is why we cannot take off the shelf previous referenda legislation that was proposed prior to the charter. Those details are being looked at. I would be willing to discuss this with the hon. member or anybody else. That is going to happen when the bill is presented for first and second reading, committee study and so on.
I appreciate the hon. member's willingness to help. I hope there is not any suggestion that somehow there is something mysterious and nefarious going on here. All that is being done is that officials in the Privy Council Office are trying to ensure we have a legislation which, in its details, stands up to examination in view of the Charter of Rights and Freedoms. That is all.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the undertakings which were given to the Official Opposition were that meaningful consultations would take place before the tabling of the bill. There is a marked distinction between meaningful consultations and directives which come from the government House leader.

Business of the House
I am happy to hear on the floor of the House of Commons that the government House leader has now said there are no substantive policy issues that one has to be concerned with with regard to this particular bill. It is merely a discussion of technicalities.
If that is the case, it is all the more reason for members of Parliament to be given the opportunity in a meaningful way to sit down with the government House leader and to look at the draft proposals from PCO, the Department of Justice, in order to ascertain if there are particular technicalities in the bill, which we may see as being very obvious, which can be corrected prior to the tabling of the bill.
I cannot understand why the minister now tends to purport on one hand that it is merely technical information contained in the bill. In his letter to me, he says: "These questions include provisions for spending, advertizing limits, the use of public funds, the length of a potential referendum campaign, and the manner in which to enumerate". All of these things are technical.
Some of those issues will be looked at by the Chief Electoral Officer. I cannot understand why the hon. government House leader is going back on the undertaking of his colleagues, the Minister responsible for Constitutional Affairs and the Prime Minister, to have meaningful consultations prior to the tabling of the bill.
Why can the hon. minister not see to a very reasonable request?

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have no problem receiving the request, if the member is going to be here on the weekend, to work with me on the details.
The problem the hon. member is dismissing is that when the bill is brought before this House and everybody sees it, we have a second reading debate on it. In the mother of Parliaments, that usually takes about two hours. In this Parliament, for some reason, it takes a couple of days.
Nevertheless, you then go to committee and all of the things that the hon. member talked about happen.
All of the things that the hon. member just described are what happens in a committee that works properly.
You look at each and every clause, you find out whether it is appropriate, whether there are some glitches. Virtually, without exception, every bill that comes from here ends up being corrected and improved as a result of inputs at committee. That is the way we study legislation.
Why the hon. member is suggesting that somehow there is something devious going on in this instance, I do not know. I am really beside myself.
Remember that the important question here is not the details as to how we would hold a referendum. It will be by secret ballot with every Canadian eligible to vote and under a set of rules that is charterable. It will be fair.
The question of what is to be posed if there is a referendum, the Minister Responsible for Constitutional Affairs and the Prime Minister made it very clear that this particular issue would be discussed with the leaders of the federal parties in the House.
To make sure that the hon. member's paranoia does not get carried away too far, as I indicated Tuesday at our House leader's meeting and as I repeated yesterday in the House and as I repeat now, in terms of the technicality of the bill, the bill is not ready today because we are ensuring that those details are taken care of.
If the hon. member wants to come into my office on Sunday and take a look at some of those details, I would be pleased to sit down with him and look at each and every clause. It will merely be to do what we will have to do anyway when the bill is brought to the House and is treated in its usual fashion.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
The usual Thursday afternoon question is turning into a debate.
All the questions have been answered for the time being. I see that the hon. member representing the New Democratic Party is rising and I am quite prepared to hear him. I hope we are not going to repeat what has been done so far if we want to get into the special debate.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, on a point of order.
I do not know if you were in the chair when I had risen to ask my question, but I did indicate quite clearly that I had a number of specific questions with regard to the enabling legislation as it pertains to the referendum.
I have one other question that I would like to pose to the government House leader.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext:
I am quite prepared to hear the hon. opposition House leader. He must understand that the Chair has a point in saying that the Thursday question should not turn into debating a bill which has not been tabled in the House.
I will listen to the hon. member and I will then go to the hon. member for Winnipeg Transcona.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, for the clarification of the Chair, it is precisely why I asked these questions; in order that the business of the House can be done expeditiously.
What I am attempting to do now since there was a clear undertaking of meaningful consultations given, and it is my understanding that all three national parties have agreed that they will try to pursue or facilitate this bill in an expeditious manner, is to try and ascertain from the government House leader the rationale for refusing to have members of this Parliament to meet with him early next week in order to go over some of the preliminary points which he believes to be important for the bill and in order that there be no errors of omissions. That is all I am asking the government House leader.
If the Chair has difficulties with that, I would respectfully suggest to the Chair that what we are attempting to do here is to expedite legislation which will be coming forward to this House.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, this question was answered to the hon. member in a House leader's meeting. It was answered in the House. It was answered again today. I have given all the assurances necessary. What he is attempting here is to discredit this process, to show that somehow something is going on. There is absolutely no basis for that; none whatsoever, absolutely none. I am not sure why this game is being played but I remind him that what is at stake here is the future of the country.
Let us not get off into these partisan games for the sake of short term political gains when what is at stake is the future of the country.

Madam Speaker, I suppose that is a moot point; whether there
Business of the House
are any partisan games going on. I do not think we should carry this debate any further. We ought to get on to debating UNCED and what is going to happen to the entire planet, not just Canada.
I do urge the government House leader to consider a larger problem. If the government is serious about wanting the co-operation of opposition federal parties in saving the country, in facilitating a resolution to our constitutional crisis, it has to consider how frustrating it can be for us who want to co-operate when at the same time the government wants to keep its cards close to its chest and play them on its own timetable in a way that it chooses.
There is a legitimate point underlying what the government House leader sees as paranoia and that is if we are going to co-operate in saving the country, that co-operation has to be as comprehensive and as extensive as possible. That might even include consulting people about legislation before it is tabled. I understand there is a committee process. That will happen. I do not think that you should rule out of hand the suggestion that there could have been this kind of consultation before hand. That is all I have to say.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
Last Tuesday, the hon. member was there. I took the opportunity at the House leaders meeting to talk about the specifics of this bill and what was happening. I told hon. members exactly the circumstances that legal opinions were being sought in terms of various options and until those legal opinions are in, there is nothing to discuss and no decisions can be made.
I undertook at that point to get back to hon. members. The very next day, the hon. member's leader stands up in the House and asks specifically the question that I had relayed to him and to the House leader of the New Democratic Party. For what purpose? The information was given to the NDP House leader and the hon. member at that meeting.
The very next day, the leader of the New Democratic Party stood up and asked a question on that. For what purpose? Was it for information? Hardly. It was for the purposes of being on the tube and making some points. It was the same thing for the hon. House leader of the Liberal Party. What is the purpose of these questions? Was it to get information that was not provided to him in person in that meeting or by way of a letter? That is not the purpose. It is for the purposes of being on television, to make the point.

Business of the House
Oh, oh.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
I did not heckle when the hon. members on the other side were speaking. I would appreciate if the member for Hamilton West would allow me to speak and the courtesy of finishing my remarks.
As I have said to the hon. member and the House leader of the Liberal Party, privately in a meeting, by way of letter and again in the House, once we have this information together, once we are able to make some decisions as to what is possible, I will again be discussing with him, his House leader or whomever they want to designate. If every time in House leaders' meetings I bring up talk about government plans and legislation it is the very next day to be the subject matter of partisan attacks in Question Period, that is not going to be much of an incentive for me to want to involve opposition House leaders in these discussions.
It is a two-sided coin. I am willing to involve them if we can assume that we will operate in a responsible fashion and will not use the information that we talk about in those things for the purposes of partisan advantage, which is what has been happening here, I am afraid.

Madam Speaker, I will get back to House business in a normal way and not comment on the referendum discussion, which is becoming a referendum debate. I am certainly not party to any House leaders. This is a legitimate House question. I had already telegraphed in advance that I was going to ask it this Thursday.
Has the House leader, with all the other meetings he has had, had a chance to discuss with the Minister of Veterans Affairs when the bill is going to come in to remedy the wrong to merchant marines in terms of legislation that we all generally agree with and is the basis of a committee report? It would be a great 125th birthday present to people who helped saved this country in a very difficult time.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
As a matter of fact I have had that conversation with the Minister of Veterans Affairs and I had the second part of that conversation a couple of hours ago.
The legislation is in the Department of Justice being drafted. He told me that just this morning he asked that it be accelerated and brought forward. I indicated to him that as soon as the justice department has finished its drafting I would welcome it and intend to bring it forward to House leaders to have it passed as quickly as possible.
That could be next May.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext: I think we are talking about days, not weeks.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Before the government House leader leaves I want to indicate that we reject outright the assertion by the government House leader that we were attempting to play partisan advantage here. We are asking simple questions with regard to procedure which may expedite the passage of legislation which the government and which we, and I believe my colleagues to the left, support in principle and wish to see passed in this House.
I reject outright the assertions of the government House leader. If he were an honourable colleague, he would do the appropriate thing and apologize to the House.

speakerposition: Minister of State (Without Portfolio); Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Progressive Conservative Party House Leader
speechtext:
I will hope and expect and operate on the basis that the hon. member does not seek or want partisan advantage and that from now on we can carry on these discussions as we usually do through private conversations in my office and he will not use the excuse of the Thursday question to take partisan shots at me.
I am willing to discuss legislation coming, its details and any aspect that I can within the constraints of a Privy Council oath, but I am not willing to stand up and be abused in the House of Commons by charges which are simply false.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: We have debated enough on the subject and we should proceed to Orders of the Day.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
speechtext: Madam Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I wish to indicate to the House that I do accept the apology of the government House leader.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean J. Charest (Minister of the Environment) moved:
subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
That this House take note of the Canadian position at the United
Nations Conference on the Environment and Development.
He said: Madam Speaker, I am very pleased to have the honour to begin this important debate on Canada's participation in the United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development. This special debate was made possible with the co-operation of members of this House and concerns a subject and an event that will no doubt be a landmark in the history of Canada and the world.

I am very pleased to rise today in support of this motion. I want to take this opportunity to talk of Canada's participation, not only of the conference itself but obviously of the work leading into this very important conference, especially given the fact that Canada has been fully committed to the United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development.
It is important to point out for the memory of this House and for all Canadians that we backed this initiative from the very beginning. It is this country that was one of the original co-sponsors of the resolution calling for what is better known as the earth summit. We have been one of its most vigorous supporters ever since, financially and in other ways also. We have also done so because we understand that environmental problems demand a co-operative approach, not only within the country itself, but within nations and between nations.
It has become quite evident over the last few years that countries cannot settle for protecting only those ecosystems that lie within their their borders. Air, water, fish and wildlife are not contained by national boundaries or internal lines of jurisdiction.
Pollution generated in one country or in one hemisphere impacts on another, as we and our neighbours
The Environment
have learned in one very important instance with the acid rain file. There are a great many lessons we have brought forward from that experience. One of the most important lessons in the case of acid rain is that Canada alone could not solve the problem. If we are going to find some answers to the very difficult questions and issues we were faced with, it became critical for us, as a country, to enlist the help and co-operation of our neighbours from the south at the time.
This is true also for other issues. Canadians recently have been very concerned with scientific information about the depletion of the ozone layer. NASA came out with some reports and Environment Canada also voiced some concerns about a potential situation that could have happened this spring. There was more depletion this spring than in the past, given particular circumstances.
We also realized through this debate that in the case of ozone depletion, Canada contributes to about 2 per cent of the problem. Recent scientific data seem to indicate that we are paying more than 2 per cent of the price for the problems we are dealing with and that if we are going to effectively deal with this issue of ozone depletion, we must absolutely enlist the help of all countries around the world.
This is true also in other areas. Fish stocks, for example, is an area in which we have recently had experiences that also lead us inevitably to this conclusion. We have learned recently that the 200-mile limit, the line drawn on the map, does not mean much at the end of the day when dealing with an ecosystem. In the case of fish stocks, for a long time we looked at the issue of fishing in our seas as a matter of a ledger; we count the number of tonnes caught on one side for one species and count the tonnes caught by other countries and talked of traditional fishing rights.
At the end of the day, as we realized today, what is important is the ecosystem itself. The ecosystem may have very little to do at the end of the day with this 200-mile limit. For this reason we are faced with a very difficult problem in the North Seas; an issue, by the way, that Canada will be pursuing vigorously at the conference in Rio de Janeiro.

The Environment
There is also growing pressure on the environment that has mobilized a steady widening circle of co-operation. It evoked national action. We have been witness to a lot of that. One of the interesting things, to put these issues in perspective, which I do not think we appreciate enough, is that there are few areas of public administration in this country or in the history of this country that have attracted more attention by municipal provincial and federal governments than the environment.
I have tried to find a parallel. I have presented this argument to some people before. Try to find one area, whether it is education or whatever, in which there are comparisons and in which governments paid so much attention. The environment is certainly unprecedented.
At the same time, and I do not want to dwell on this, we also recognize that this being the case Canadians are also asking us to do more because they feel and they know there is a great deal that must be done in this area.
It is with this recognition of global threats that the circle I was talking about a few seconds ago has widened. The life support systems that make this planet habitable or under increasingly dangerous pressure. The cause of that stress is development conducted with a blind eye to the environment. This kind of development is unsustainable because it cannot be kept up; eventually it cuts the ground from under us.
At the same time, we understand that economic and industrial growth cannot be put on hold. That is the other side of the coin. Four out of five people on this planet live in what are called developing countries. Their daily reality is about poverty, it may very much be about hunger and, in some cases, their plight is a plight for survival.
This is a challenging issue for us. We have to also recognize for their sake and for the sake of the world that we do need economic growth, but we must switch to a mode of development that is sustainable.
To use an economic metaphor, we have to start living on our environmental interest and stop eroding its capital.
The purpose of the earth summit is to attempt to change course in the direction of sustainable development. We must take that beginning now. The pressures are building very fast. This conference is about those pressures which we have to deal with.

Let me illustrate an aspect of the challenge facing us. According to the United Nations Fund for Population Activities, in June 1992, during the month of the earth summit, our planet will have around 5.48 billion inhabitants. That will be the approximate population of planet earth. The United Nations Fund for Population Activities estimates that our planet will have about 10 billion inhabitants in the year 2150, according to present projections and trends. Demographics is not an absolute science, but the projection is a reasonable figure.
Most of this growth, and the industrial and economic activity that goes with it, will be in the developing countries. Make no mistake: the less fortunate countries of our world will refuse to bear the burden of the environmental security that everyone needs now. We must be realistic about it. Those countries will not give up the development objectives that the industrialized nations themselves pursued and attained and which, by the way, made it possible for us to have the standard of living that we enjoy today. Quite frankly we will have to consider this aspect as well in today's debate.
These countries are aware of the importance of sustainable development. However, they also say they cannot afford to make the necessary changes unless they receive financial and technical assistance from those who can provide it. Unless the rich and not so rich countries find a way to work together to achieve sustainable development, our environment will suffer the consequences.
The primary objective of the earth summit and the preparatory talks is to kick off a global co-operation initiative on implementing the concept of sustainable development. At the present time, the nations of the world are drifting into hazardous waters. The UN conference, and I would like to make this clear, is about both environment and development. There is a common tendency to stress the environmentalal aspect, and in any case, people are talking a lot about the environment nowadays, but when we talk about environment and development we realize that basically we are often talking about the same thing.


[DOT] v?
w.


Canada has been very supportive of this conference, and in fact Canada's role is entirely in the Canadian tradition. Canada has been one of the great promoters of co-operation in international affairs.
I am thinking, for instance, of the United Nations and a tradition each one of us can be proud of. There is also the leadership role we play within the Commonwealth and the leadership role we have the privilege of playing-because it is a privilege-in the Franco-phonie. There is also the Organization of American States, where Canada recently became a member.
It is all part of a tradition in this country of which we may be extremely proud. It is a tradition of involvement. We do not intend to stay on the sidelines. We have international responsibilities, but our national interests also dictate taking an active part in this conference.
In fact our objectives in Rio cannot be separated from our national objectives. This applies not only to Canada but to all countries taking part in this great conference.

The government is committed to sustainable development and we are acting on that commitment. Canada is one of only three countries in the world to have adopted a comprehensive long-term approach to sustainable development, our green plan.
Over a period of six years the Canadian government, along with the Canadian people and all members of this House, will dedicate its energies to this effort of sustainable development. Canada's green plan is very much at the centre of implementing and articulating this concept of sustainable development in Canada.
The green plan itself is based on that principle and adopts that vision, and also commands and obliges the government to change its ways of making decisions. As well, through a commitment of $3 billion it enables us plan over this six-year period to put forward a very important number of initiatives.
We know that we cannot do this job alone. Some of the most critical challenges we face can only be dealt with in co-operation with others; that includes every Canadian.
The Environment
There are many links between the green plan and the global plan that will be considered in Rio. For example, agenda 21 is a detailed proposal for global action developed in pre-summit negotiations. In chapter after chapter one finds proposals for action that extend and complement action under the green plan.
For example, one chapter of agenda 21 deals with toxic chemicals. It calls for measures to expand our knowledge of the risks associated with the use of these substances and it proposes measures to strengthen information exchange networks on a global scale.
These proposals mirror closely what is happening here in Canada. Last February we announced a $14 million allocation under the green plan for the creation of a national toxicology network. It will link four universities in co-operative research on toxic chemical risks.
The government also making an $85 million investment under the green plan in scientific studies to reduce uncertainties about climate change. That will complement research in agenda 21 with exactly that end in mind, because there is still a lot of uncertainty.
The nations of the world hope to agree on a convention on biodiversity. That is a separate convention which is, from the reports I have received, progressing well. Biodiversity is about saving plant and animal species, which ties in with our green plan goal of completing a national parks system in this country by the year 2000 to protect examples of all of Canada's natural regions.
It also ties in with the excellent and fantastic work done by the Canadian Wildlife Service. We now have a bill that is being examined in legislative committee, the Wild Animal and Plant Protection Act, which is very ably chaired by a member of the New Democratic caucus. We also have a $35 million wildlife strategy resulting from the green plan. In that respect I am happy to report to this House that work is progressing well and Canada is making a contribution.
The earth summit will also consider measures to promote sustainable agriculture. Under the green plan we have budgeted $170 million to pursue that goal in Canada. There are other examples.

The Environment
They all make the same point, that the goals we pursue in Canada are linked to the goals we are pursuing in Rio. The headway we make in this country will contribute to the environmental well-being of other countries. Their efforts will contribute to our own. The green plan is also very much part of the global plan.
What do we hope to accomplish in Rio? We are now little more than a month away from the summit. This is a good time to look at how far we have come in the process and what happens next. Negotiations have been underway for over two years now. There have been four meetings, what we call prep-corns. Separate meetings were also held to attempt to negotiate conventions on climate change and biodiversity, which I just talked about a few minutes ago.
There are very tough issues relating to climate change between developed and developing countries. Negotiations are happening right now in New York City. I think it is the fourth round of negotiations. With a bit of luck an agreement might result from these negotiations.
There is also separate negotiation on a statement of principles on forests. It is of great importance to this country, especially because we have on our territory 10 per cent of the world's forests and thus have a responsibility to citizens of the world for the management of this forest.
We know from experience all that is being done is not going to be easy. This whole process has been very challenging for us.
The fourth and final prep-com faces the challenge of coming up with an agreed draft for agenda 21. This was an incredibly large and complex task, particularly since consensus agreement was required. There was not a lot of optimism in the prep-com in dealing with agenda 21 when they started. In fact, they did not agree on 100 per cent of the agenda. However, negotiators did reach a meeting of the minds on about 90 per cent of the issues that they were dealing with, which represents a substantial gain.
This leaves a considerable challenge at Rio. Obviously the 10 per cent of the issues on which there was no agreement are not the easy areas. It is that 10 per cent that in most cases represents the most important challenge.
What will we achieve at Rio? It is still too early to tell because negotiations are not finished and all the countries of the world are involved. It is safe to say that we are optimistic at this time. It is also safe to assume that the negotiations may continue up until the last moment.
However, we do know that we will be on a new course. It is true that the world will not change overnight and that there are no quick fixes, but a new course will be embarked upon as we leave Rio.

We hope the earth summit will stake out new territory. In fact it cannot do otherwise. We also hope to leave Rio with certain essential elements we do not have at this moment: a plan for co-operation and some of the institutional mechanisms required to implement that plan. In fact, there is a whole debate within the confines of this conference on the kind of institutions that will come out of this debate to follow up on the decisions that will be made in Rio. These discussions may not garner the same public interest, but they will nevertheless have a tremendous impact on the implementation of the commitments that are made in Rio.
We will try to conclude a comprehensive agreement, one that with a little luck will chart a new course for the people of this planet.
Canada has a duty to do everything it can possibly can. I can give members the assurance that the government will not shirk that duty. As in the past, Canada will act as a responsible member of the international community. We will put our shoulders to the wheel in the best Canadian tradition.

In closing I would like to thank the significant number of Canadians who participated in this process. One thing about Rio, the prep - corns and the preparation going into them is that Canada did exceptionally well in including as many people from our country in this process as possible.
There were environment groups, people from industry, academics, the provinces, the cities of Toronto and Montreal. They were part of the contribution of Canada. For example, Canada is the leader in the contributions of the young people of the world to this summit.

I would like to say today, not as a member of the government but first and foremost as a Canadian citizen, how proud we all should be of the great contribution made by these people. It happened because we had a process that included them. It is Canada's insistence that we include all of these players, whether they are aboriginal people or environment groups, that has made their participation possible on a global scale.
Some of our members of Parliament, the Minister of State for the Environment for example, have taken a special interest in this conference.
I would like to single out the hon. member for Waterloo on our side of the House who has taken a special interest in all of these issues. I would especially like to single out the hon. member for Rosedale who has participated directly in some of these conferences. He has led some of our Canadian delegations and has done just a fantastic job for each and every one of us. His contribution will be felt for a long time to come.
