I also would like to single out the hon. member for Brandon-Souris, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment, who has also contributed. As we approach this conference we do it in a very non-partisan spirit, in a spirit of generosity.
I have not mentioned members from other sides of the House, but I was just getting to them. Everybody, whether it is the hon. member for LaSalle-Emard or my friends on the other side, the members for Skeena or Saanich-Gulf Islands, has participated in a spirit of generosity. We look forward to putting together a good Canadian team to go.
Finally, the Prime Minister of Canada will also be present. He has made a commitment to be in Rio, and that is probably the most significant contribution that he can personally make to this process. As we all know, it is the heads of governments who at the end of the day can make the biggest difference in this regard.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is my pleasure to speak in debate today on the subject of the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development.
It is not my interest to launch into a debate with the minister about his green plan, I will leave that to my colleague from LaSalle-Emard.
I think it is very important to have this opportunity to inform the Canadian public at large as to exactly
The Environment
what will be taking place in June in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. Although, as the minister states, there may have been several Canadians involved in developing policy and posturing leading up to this very important and crucial meeting, for the most part the Canadian public is ignorant of the reality of this conference.
In order for it to be the success that we all hope it will be it is very important that the people of this country, the people of the globe, take hold of this agenda and lend their support in whatever way possible. We do want it to be a success.
UNCED, or the earth summit as it is more popularly called, is probably the most important international conference to take place this century. The topic is sustainable development in a world in which we see life threatening, environmental degradation increase every day.
There will be over 100 heads of state expected to be present at this conference. We are very pleased that a few weeks ago our own Prime Minister mentioned his intention to attend. Today we are even further encouraged by the announcement that President Bush of the United States who it was felt would boycott this important conference, will probably attend. There will be 6,000 delegates in attendance at this conference.
The event will include both an official forum of heads of state and delegates accompanying heads of state. As well a parallel non-government organization forum will have an important impact on the output from the UNCED conference.
As Canadians we should all be very proud that the leader of this conference, the secretary-general of this conference, is our very distinguished and respected Canadian Maurice Strong. Maurice Strong was also the head of the crucial Stockholm conference on the human environment which took place 20 years ago in 1972.
At that particular conference there were 113 countries represented but not by heads of state. The Stockholm conference marked the first time ever that nations met to discuss environmental degradation and at that particular conference secured the recognition of the environment as an internationally urgent issue and produced the first ever action plan on the environment.

The Environment
It produced the United Nations environmental program which looks after the agenda that came out the Stockholm conference. It produced the first ever international environmental laws. It produced public awareness of the issues and the coming into existence of many non-government organizations, development and citizens groups, and voluntary groups.
These groups have been very important in applying political pressure for the achievement of environmental goals. Since then, NGOs and businesses have put the environment on their agenda.
Just to underline the importance of the involvement of people and their understanding of the issues I refer to an article that appeared in The New York Times yesterday which was referring to the fact that it is probable that President Bush with attend this conference. I would like to quote from this article. It says:
Bush has repeatedly voiced great skepticism about the conference. For most of this year, while his aides haggled over the fine points of treaties and declarations, he has publicly fretted that the conference would become a soapbox for poor nations to demand billions in environmental technology and cash handouts that the White House neither has nor intends to pledge.
But Bush is apparently going anyway, because an alliance of political advisers and policy experts has persuaded him that he cannot afford to stay home.
That group is said to believe that Bush's absence would be an abdication of global leadership, because most major leaders will be at the conference and strongly support its goals.
The meeting also bears potentially huge political implications for Bush. Aides believe that his failure to attend would blot his environmental record at a time when the issue has become a major factor in the votes of young people and in some large states, such as California and Florida.
I would like to emphasize again the importance of the Canadian public being aware of what exactly is taking place in Rio de Janeiro in June of this year. By understanding what the issues are they themselves can be involved and participate in the process of the success of the Rio conference.
At the Stockholm conference in 1972, even then developing countries, the countries of the Third World, insisted that the primary source of environmental problems in the world were poverty and underdevelopment. Since that environmental conference, it is sad to say that little progress has been made.
In fact a UNDP report which was published just a few weeks ago indicates that the gap between the world's rich and poor has doubled in the last 30 years.
The north is statistically the world's greatest polluter, but the late Prime Minister of India, Indira Ghan-di, stated years ago that poverty is the greatest polluter. We do not need a debate to settle this ignominious honour, but we do need to recognize that present industrialization and economic policies in the north and poverty issues in the south must be addressed concurrently.
The visibility of the current crisis is evident in many ways. Environmental degradation is most readily seen in the pollution of lakes and rivers, deforestation, global warming, nuclear contamination, desertification, soil salination. The list goes on and on.
However, it is also obvious we have a crisis when one considers that we are now involved globally in natural resource conflicts of which we all remember so well, the first and most dramatic being the gulf war and more recently, the problems we have experienced on the east coast of our country through the depletion of cod stocks. Will water be the next resource conflict? Where will that conflict occur? Right here in North America?
The southern U.S. has an eye cast on our fresh water resources in this country and certainly, in the Middle East, water as a natural resource is a source of conflict.
However, as pitiful and as serious as these crises are, we can contrast them with environmental actions that have been undertaken which have had a positive impact.
First of all, we can begin to look at the strategies of Germany, Japan and Switzerland. Those countries are very powerful economically throughout the world, as we all know, but it is those same countries that have taken on the economy as it relates to environment as an important agenda item. The fact that they have imposed upon themselves strict environmental standards has not hampered but, in fact, improved their economic performance.
We are very concerned in Canada about signing a North American free trade agreement with Mexico because of the environmental degradation which exists there and whether or not coming into an economic alliance with Mexico will pull our environmental standards down to the lowest common denominator.

We have to consider, however, that there is another possibility and that Mexico, starting from the base may be able, much more easily than Canada, to impose environmental standards on its economic development. There are indications already that this is the case.
On the Ivory Coast, a Third World country in western Africa, attempts have been made to deal with environmental problems. China is committed to a growth of 12 per cent in its gross national product in the next years, but in order to do so they require development and that requires energy. Their basic source of energy is coal. If we are to prevent a tremendous increase in environmental degradation from this nation which represents one-quarter of the world's population, we must do more to help China technically to prevent this environmental degradation.
The Stockholm conference spawned what has become known as the World Commission on Environment and Development or the Brundtland commission after its first chairman. This commission produced a report called, Our Common Future in 1987. Although many reports become dated within a few years of their publication, I would say this is a report that still can be recommended as most important reading for all Canadians. It is as relevant today, if not more so, than when it was first published.
It presents a strong message on environment and development and the fact that environment and development must be fully integrated into every aspect of economic and social policy. There must be equal emphasis on the responsibilities of developing countries and industrial countries.
As a result of the publishing of this report, the United Nations General Assembly in 1989 mandated the earth summit or the UNCED conference which will take place in June in Brazil.
In the meetings that have been held which were referred to by the minister leading up to Brazil in June, Maurice Strong, is quoted as saying:
The Earth Summit must establish a whole new basis for relations between rich and poor, north and south, including a concerted attack on poverty as a central priority for the 21st century.
The Environment
This is now as imperative in terms of our environmental security as it is on moral and humanitarian grounds. We owe at least this much to future generations, from whom we have borrowed a fragile planet called Earth.
What is the earth summit about? It is about sustainable development. A definition of sustainable development from our common future is as follows: sustainable development is development that meets the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs.
The goals of the summit in Brazil are various. They will bring together, as I said before, heads of states and grass roots representation in the process. We hope that it will come with a new political commitment to a global war on poverty and development, that the north and south both, through economic change in their management of resources and their lifestyle, can bring about a world where we only know sustainable development.
We do need, as others have said, a new equal industrial revolution. Regulatory measures and laws alone will not solve the problems of sustainable development and environmental degradation. Regulatory measures must be balanced by incentives. The incentives of the marketplace can be important. In fact even in Canada we are beginning to see the incentives of the marketplace taking place in our pulp and paper industry in Canada.
Canada in the past has had a good reputation but that reputation is in jeopardy. Certainly our pulp and paper industry and their methods have been great contributors to pollution in this country. However, because now different countries of the world such as Germany are refusing to purchase pulp and paper produced in polluting Canadian industries, our pulp and paper industry is being forced to turn around and improve its methods and come up to higher environmental standards.
The south has needs. It needs to have an improved professional capacity in order to be able to assess its choices of development. It also needs the scientific and technical capacity to make this transition to sustainable development.

The Environment
The responsibility of the north is enormous. We have a large responsibility in making trade fairer. We talk now of the greening of the GATT, the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs. We must be open and find new ways of providing technical transfers in agriculture, energy, natural resource base sustainability, pollution control, et cetera. We must put an emphasis on the development of local solutions to environmental problems in the Third World through technology co-operation.
We need a new and improved UN system of global governance. This is essential. Institutions of the United Nations must be assessed and modified to improve their ability to cope with global governance needs.
To quote Mr. Strong again: "Global environmental and economic security require global co-operation". We have important United Nations' structures in place right now which, with modification, can meet the challenges of the future.
There are three specific outcomes of the Brazil conference.
First, it is hoped that we will have an earth charter which is legally binding. At the present we have a declaration of principles which was agreed to at the fourth prep -com meeting in New York. It was felt, because of the division between north and south in terms of the agenda for Brazil, that we would not even come as far as the declaration which we have today. It is hoped that this declaration will become, as I said, a legally binding charter at Brazil.
We have an agenda 21 which we hope to have approved by all nations coming out of Brazil. The conference in Brazil must also deal with the means of implementing that agenda, including the commitment of financial resources. It is estimated that it will require $125 billion per year in order to achieve the agenda 21 goals by the year 2000. Fifty billion dollars is now provided of that $125 billion through aid from developed countries to developing countries. We still require an additional commitment of $75 billion. It is certainly my wish that Canada will make a commitment of additional funding to achieve agenda 21 goals before the Brazil conference.
The money that has been provided to date through the green plan is insufficient. It is an insufficient response by Canada and must be improved upon. Certainly this government's commitment to poverty alleviation has not been expressed when it comes to budget time. In fact, this government has dramatically
cut our overseas development assistance in the last three years' budgets. We all urge this government to reinstate its commitment to achieving a .7 per cent ratio of official development assistance to Gross National Product as a target.
The convention in Brazil also expects to achieve legally binding conventions on global warming, the protection of the atmosphere, biological diversity, and perhaps forest, ocean and other natural resource
protections.
In prep-com meetings leading up to the earth summit, the first three concerned the environmental agenda of the north at the expense of the development of the agenda of the south. The fourth prep-com meeting did produce a proposed declaration which includes many of the principles reflecting the priorities of the countries of the south. I would like to mention just a few of those in passing.
Principle No. 3, for example, states that the countries meeting in Rio de Janeiro recognize the right to development must be fulfilled as to equitably meet development and environmental needs of present and future generations. All states and all people shall co-operate in the essential task of eradicating poverty as an indispensable requirement for sustainable development in order to decrease the disparities and standards of living and better meet the needs of the majority of the people of the world.
The indigenous people and their communities and other local communities have a vital role in environmental management and development because of their knowledge and traditional practices.
The creativity, ideals and courage of the youth of the world should be mobilized to forge a global partnership in order to achieve sustainable development and ensure a better future for all.
Women have a vital role in environmental management and development. Their full participation is therefore essential to achieve sustainable development.
Many new initiatives have been taken preparatory to UNCED or the earth summit in Canada. Women and native peoples have met internationally. Nongovernment organizations representing north and south, environmental and development groups have met. Today we had a declaration from the Canadian non-government organizations involved in preparing for UNCED. This afternoon as I speak, the International Development Research Council is discussing the south agenda for Brazil. Parliamentarians through

Parliamentarians for Global Action, an international organization representing parliamentarians around the world, have met to try and improve and direct the agenda of Rio.
Other colleagues of mine will speak to these various agendas and efforts to make sure that Brazil is a success. I would particularly like to mention that our own Liberal caucus held a round table in February on UNCED in which we heard from experts on a variety of sustainable development fields. The discussion at that time resulted in the development of our own recommendations which will be pursued later in this debate.
In conclusion, I think it is important today to build public awareness and the public base of support which is required in order that the political will of Canadians and all international leaders will be such that UNCED can be an opportunity to proclaim and be proclaimed a success.
I would just like to finish by quoting Maurice Strong once more. He said: "Rio in 1992 will build on the foundations established in Stockholm in 1972. The people of our planet, especially our youth and the generations which follow them, will hold us accountable for what we do or fail to do at the earth summit in Rio. Earth is the only home we have; its fate is literally in our hands".

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am honoured to begin this debate for the New Democratic Party this afternoon on the earth summit, the UN Conference on Environment and Development.
Following on from the comments of the Minister of the Environment and Canada's leadership role, we should be proud as Canadians that Maurice Strong is the secretary-general of the earth summit. He along with Arthur Campeau, who is Canada's ambassador to the earth summit, have something in common. Both of these men came from strong business careers. Both of these men at a point later in their lives said: "Is this all there is?" and decided to turn their energies to something really worth while aside from making money. That is, trying to save the planet. They provide an example which this government should follow; stop worrying about the bottom line, start worrying about the planet.
The Environment
This calls for a fundamental rethinking. This is a call that has come from all-party committees on numerous occasions in this House. We have to stop thinking about the financial criteria as being uppermost in any thinking and start realizing that basic human objectives are at stake here.
I must say in these days that are left before the convening of the earth summit that events have not made me optimistic. I know that Maurice Strong has been travelling the globe trying to patch together real change coming up to the earth summit. This afternoon and this evening, we are debating the Canadian position. Let us make it clear how this Canadian position has been obtained. This is a government position. There has been no consultation with the members of the Liberal Party or the New Democratic Party on any of the positions determined here.
This is a neo-Conservative corporate agenda that is framing the so-called Canadian position. No opposition members of Parliament were included in any of the preparatory conferences. Oh, no. What we had to do was depend on the non-governmental organizations and the aboriginal peoples, and they did a very good job in keeping us informed. Including those groups actually may have changed the minds of the government delegation.
I would like to turn to the Prime Minister's quotes in his comments before the non-governmental organizations this past week. I quote: " Canada's international reputation depends on what we do at home". I agree but I do not know whether that is a laudatory comment or a negative comment. His second quote is: "Canada is exemplary".
I went to the dictionary and looked up in the Concise Oxford dictionary what the word exemplary meant. There were four definitions. One, it is fit to be imitated; two, typical; three, illustrative; four-and this is my choice-serving as a warning.
Canada's role here is serving as a warning for what the rest of world should not do. There has been a pattern established about how this government performs. It is nice talk, little action. I will give examples. I can see the government members getting a little uncomfortable about this because we are supposed to be non-partisan. I am tired of being non-partisan when there is nice talk and little action.

The Environment
As an example, I served on an all-party committee, the subcommittee on international debt, a subcommittee of the external affairs committee. This committee would focus this debate on the UN Conference on Environment and Development, UNCED, and put the 'D' back in UNCED because that is what needs to be done.
I want to talk about population issues. Somehow it is almost too polite to talk about it at the earth summit. We do not want to talk about population issues. It will sort of get the imagination flowing as to how population increases. We would not want that. I also want to talk about militarism and, finally, climate change.
On the international debt issue, as I said the allparty committee came out with recommendations. What did this government do? Put the report on the shelf. It is collecting dust. It has not initiated one fundamental recommendation from an all-party committee. Nice talk, little action.
The statistics are numbing on international debt. The World Bank estimates that Third World debt now exceeds $1.3 trillion-that is trillion with a t. The human cost of servicing this massive debt is having a debilitating effect on developing countries. In fact protracted international debt prices, a grave unsustainable financial burden, have become the principal obstacle to development for much of the world's poor majority.
The committee believed then, two years ago, and believes now that Canada's interests in a healthy and secure global order are profoundly at stake in finding solutions to what is part of a larger north-south crisis.
The committee in its response to the government's non-response pointed out, and said it very concisely, and I quote from the report: "Let us be forthright in stating that the response from the government tabled last November to this report is far from meeting our expectations". The response tries to convey the impression of rhetorical agreement with the committee's report when in fact in substantive terms the committee's recommendations are mostly rejected without alternative initiatives.
This is the crime of it. This government thinks that nice talk, nice words, are good enough. They are not.
We are talking about the crisis of our planet. This is what the earth summit is supposed to be addressing. What this government is doing is nothing, or very little. The Prime Minister said "Canada's international reputation depends on what we do at home". This is a condemnation of what we do at home.
Further on in that report on international debt there is a quote from Paul Krugman from an issue of Foreign Policy. There is something we can do. We are not paralysed in this instance. We can do something. He argues persuasively in the article: "Debt relief is cheap". He points out that the market value of the $400 billion owed by the highly indebted countries is only about one-third that amount. Even that overstates the true cost of forgiving the portion of the debt.
Krugman calculates that cancelling half the total debt might impose a one time cost of $25 billion on creditors. It sounds like a lot of money. However, put it next to the $500 billion that has been put to the savings and loan bailout in the United States, or put it up next to the $50 billion United States cost of engaging in the gulf war. The total costs of the war and the reconstruction will run to hundreds of billions of dollars.
This is I think a useful comparison. He concludes: "The United States and other industrial countries must take advantage of the opportunity to do so much good for so little money". So there is something that this government could be doing.
I urge this government to start shaking up those that are really running the show, eliminate the complacency and grab them by the neck and pull their heads out of the sand. Our planet is at stake. I do not understand why people are being so complacent. Perhaps we are a little too comfortable here. I am not comfortable.
There is a large unacknowledged gulf between the approach emphasizing financial criteria and those that see human basic objectives as the overriding concern. The Canadians that I began the speech in complimenting, Maurice Strong and Arthur Cam-peau, have learned that. Why has the Prime Minister not learned that? There is something he can do.

I would like now to turn to the population issue. As I said, this is almost too polite to talk about. This is the fundamental issue. If we do not solve the population issue, we are all going to be history.
What is required is that we have to remove the barriers to women. We have to overthrow the patriarchal institutions. In our desire not to offend sensibilities, we have become paralysed. Women have to have control of their reproductive capacity; not churches, not governments, not men. Women. We are not vacuous creatures. We do control our own cycles. We know how to do it, if we are given the power to do it.
We are not doing it by imposing birth control measures, but by removing the barriers to power for women. Through education and literacy programs women are much more in tune with the cycle of this world just because of their own biology. That is why the patriarchal institutions have been afraid of allowing that power to be demonstrated.
However, there are those women right around the globe who are saying: "Enough already. You guys have run the show so far. Put it over to us and we'll run it from now on and we'll do a far better job".
I would like now to turn to militarism, the other item I wanted to talk about. These are all wonderfully connected. I point to an article in The Globe and Mail today talking about $7 billion for a fleet of submarines, naval patrol vessels. I go back to the different perspective that women might have. Why are these bigger, better toys needed? It is not the women of the world who are demanding them.
Militarism and the environment are not even on the agenda because who is controlling the agenda? It is not the women who met in Miami last November.
I point to an article in the Montreal Gazette of March 18: "World's armed forces are worst polluters-global military spending reaches trillion dollars, but little is used to fight environmental problems". It reads:
The world's armed forces are the single biggest polluter on the
planet-global military spending has reached a trillion dollars yet
there is little money available to fight global warming or other
serious environmental threats.
The Environment
In the United States, the Pentagon generates more than five times the toxic waste produced by the five major chemical companies.
With these statistics one wonders if the world has gone mad. What are the priorities of this planet? Is it to buy more submarines and naval patrol vessels?
That is why I ask for women to be in power because those priorities would change. There would be fundamental change, fundamental rethinking. That is what we in this party are trying to do.
I would like now to turn to climate change. In the United States a report has recently been published. It is entitled "America's Energy Choices". It is a real solid condemnation of the American priorities on atmospheric change. Four agencies put together a computerized modelling system. They tested four models: a reference case, which is the status quo, this is how things have been done; they put a market case as to how consumers would be affected; they put an environmental case; and finally they put a climate stabilization case. They considered that the most aggressive case.
I quote from page 2 of their executive summary on that climate stabilization case:
National energy requirements in 2030 would be cut nearly in half from the reference case with renewable energy sources providing more than half of our energy supply.
Our nation's petroleum consumption would steadily decrease to just one-third of current levels by 2030.
Carbon dioxide emissions would be cut by more than 25 per cent from 1988 levels by 2005, and by more than 70 per cent by 2030.
Consumers would save $5 trillion in fuel and electricity costs over the next 40 years; subtracting the $2.7 trillion additional investment needed to achieve this, we estimate a net saving of some $2.3 trillion.
Why are they not doing this? It is because the policies of the current Government of the United States and the marketplace are structured in such a way to encourage the wasteful use of fossil fuels. There is no fundamental rethinking here on climate change at all.
That is why we see in preliminary reports out of New York this morning that it appears the climate change convention to be signed tomorrow will have no binding commitments to targets or schedules. There will be no funding for developing countries. There is no mechanism for technology transfer.

The Environment
In short, the convention has been gutted for shortterm economic interests. This is why it is very difficult to be optimistic. The short-term economic interest, those financial considerations I referred to earlier, are the ones that seem to be primary in the governments. That is not just in the United States government but in our own government.
We have these wonderful words about climate stabilization, goals, targets and timetables within the green plan, but we do not seem to have an implementation plan on how to achieve it. I do give the government credit. It is saying the right things. It is just that it is not doing the right things. Picky though I am, I think one should follow the other.
In conclusion, this is a condemnation of the work that has gone on by this government. It is not good enough. The whole neo-Conservative attitude of "let the market look after it; do not interfere with the big multinationals" is imperilling our planet.
It is only through the forceful speaking of the non-governmental organizations, from the aboriginal people who, by the way, seemed to manage quite well before we ever came here in demonstrating sustainable development. This is the challenge.
We have to change the way we live. We have to reduce our consumption patterns. We have to start valuing what is important, rather than how much money we have in our pockets or in our bank accounts. If we do not do that, it is not just we who will suffer, it is our children and our grandchildren.
Having given that rather dreary picture, I want to conclude by a call to those people who believe that there is still something they can do and I believe that. The energy that has come forth from Canadians generally, not from the government but the non-governmental organization sector, from aboriginal people, from churches, they can do more. They will do more. They will not despair.
I would like to conclude with a quote that I see regularly in the office of my colleague, the member for Skeena. It is a quote from Walt Taylor: "Optimism is essential for life, even when it may not seem justified by the evidence available". The evidence available does not encourage optimism. However, we cannot give into despair.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to return to a non-partisan tone in the debate.
The member who just spoke said that she had determined that there had to be some partisanship and she demonstrated it.
I would just like to point out in passing that the most radical status governments in the world have also produced the most pollution and have become economic and environmental wastelands. Whenever you turn things over to state planning, people become less important.
The Secretary of State for External Affairs recently said that the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development is not an end in itself, it is the beginning. For the first time we, the citizens of planet earth, have a chance to work together for sustainable development, a goal in which we all have a stake. This is a true global partnership. It comes at a pivotal time when the world is less interested in dividing into camps and more interested in solving fundamental problems.
When the UN charter was crafted nearly a half century ago it envisioned a world in which nations would work together for peace. Making peace and keeping it meant not only avoiding conflicts but also getting to the very roots of these conflicts, the economic and social conditions of mankind.
Over the years, the United Nations has steadily worked to address these root issues despite tremendous political divisions and differing visions of a just world. Tangible efforts have been made to improve human rights and promote economic development. Twenty years ago, the Stockholm Conference on the Human Environment made the world aware of the environmental costs of economic growth, whether it was from population pressures, industry or agriculture.
Institutions were put in place to gather data and develop procedures for monitoring environmental degradation. The United Nations environment program was established. Countries began to co-operate and minimize environmental damage to the air, land and waters which sustain life on this planet.

The next decades brought international agreements to deal with such issues as waste management, the depletion of the ozone layer and protection of endangered species. The UN Convention on the Law of the Sea included rules for dealing with marine pollution and the conservation and management of living resources. Environmental issues were regularly considered by the UN General Assembly and became a part of UN policies and programs.
In 1987, the World Commission on Environment and Development lead by Prime Minister Gro Harlem Brundtland of Norway took a new look at economic development and its impact on the environment. Where Stockholm had raised the question, Brundtland pointed to an answer. Development must meet the needs of the present without compromising the ability of future generations to meet their own needs. In other words, it must be sustainable.
The United Nations decision in 1989 to convene in Rio de Janeiro the UN Conference on Environment and Development demonstrated a global commitment to tackling this new challenge on the international agenda. The subsequent decisions to negotiate conventions on climate change and biodiversity affirmed international political will to resolve special global issues in a framework which recognizes their environmental and developmental aspects.
The convention negotiations and the preparations for Rio have been daunting. Countries from all different types of political and economic persuasions have worked to forge a basic understanding of what we have to achieve. Environment and development are still seen by many as competing, not complementary objectives. It has been difficult for countries to adopt the new thinking called for in the Brundtland report.
We must persevere, as the Prime Minister said two days ago. We should see environment and development as two sides of the same coin. Despite all the differences, countries have accomplished a great deal in preparation for Rio.
Some outstanding issues remain. They must and they will be addressed. What has truly emerged from the discussion and debate is that the United Nations has been the dynamic forum it was designed to be. UNCED is the beginning of a process to secure our common future.
The Environment
As a founding member of the United Nations, Canada is firmly committed to the organization. We are great defenders of multilateral diplomacy. Working in the UN system and other international organizations has allowed us opportunities to build bridges to solutions whether through international agreements, co-operative arrangements or common action plans.
When the Stockholm conference was launched in the UN as an idea whose time had come, Canada was among its first champions. We supported the establishment of the UN environment program. Indeed, its first head was an illustrious Canadian, Maurice Strong, who has served as secretary-general for both the Stockholm and the Rio conferences.
Canada was the first to recognize the significance of sustainable development. The government promoted and funded the creation of the Brundtland commission and hosted one of its fact finding missions. We endorsed the commission's report.
Canada was among the first to propose the convening of UNCED and help draft the complex UN resolutions which launched it. Similarly, we played a lead role in setting up the negotiation processes for the climate change in bio-diversity conventions, recognizing that a true global partnership included not only nations but groups and individuals. We fought for and got governments to agree to the participation of non-governmental organizations. The input of such groups as business, environment, development, aboriginal people, women and youth has been crucial to achieving positive results in preparation for Rio.
Canadians have a profound connection to their environment. Our vast land of forests, mountains and lakes, the great Arctic expanses, their surrounding seas are all an intrinsic part of our national consciousness. Canadians depend on natural resources. We understand the political and economic imperative of managing those resources and protecting the environment which nurtures them.
Thus, our commitment to strengthening international efforts to protect environment and promote sustainable development stems from a deepening understanding of the need to protect our habitat and our heritage.

The Environment
We have assumed a high profile in international fora like the UN and have often held the pen in drafting agreements.
At the Stockholm conference, for example, Canada drafted and negotiated a seminal principle on the sovereign right of states to exploit their own resources while at the same time recognizing their responsibility not to cause environmental damage to other states or areas beyond their jurisdiction. This has now been evolved into a principle of international law. In recent years Canada has drafted key elements in such agreements as the Montreal protocol on substances that deplete the ozone layer.
Through our development in assistance programs, we have assisted development countries in strengthening their capacity to manage scarce resources and minimize the environmental damage. For example, Canadian expertise has helped build up data bases, enhance environmental and resource monitoring and develop environmental impact assessment procedures and techniques.
We have assisted in making energy efficient technologies available to developing countries to help them meet growing demands for fuel and electricity. We have worked with governments and other organizations to develop appropriate institutions for dealing with both environmental protection and economic development.
It has not been easy to agree on an action plan based on a long-term strategy described in the Brundtland commission report, but the last preparatory committee meeting of UNCED held in March did make considerable progress.
First, there was a consensus on about 90 per cent of agenda 21, an action plan for promoting sustainable development through to the 21st century of national, regional and international levels.
This covers several sectors such as forests, oceans, atmospheric questions, freshwater and land degradation. It also covered cross sectoral development issues such as poverty, health, and economic development. Some sectoral issues such as climate change await the outcome of the current negotiations for a convention taking place in New York.
Countries also generally agreed on ways in which the UN system and other international organizations should follow up the results of the earth summit. Important options on new or revitalized UN bodies
will be considered in Rio. There are to be concerted efforts to improve the UN's systems co-ordination planning and development of its programs.
As my other colleagues will elaborate, Canada had a particular interest in promoting sustainable conservation and management of living marine resources of the high seas. We also continued our efforts to ensure countries would co-operate to eliminate marine pollution from land-based sources.
We worked hard to develop the guiding principles for forest management. In all cases we and our partners from non-governmental organizations made some headway in convincing countries of the benefit to be derived from keeping renewable resources renewable.
In the case of high seas fisheries, we and some 40 like-minded countries hope to see incorporated in agenda 21 recognition of coastal state's rights and obligations with respect to straddling stocks on the high seas.
We see a diplomatic conference after Rio as a crucial first step toward implementing the relevant provisions of the Convention on the Law of the Sea. Similarly, the UN environment program has been invited to convene another conference on land based sources of marine pollution. This is part of an ongoing commitment first proposed by Canada at the 1990 Houston economic summit to develop international guidelines to deal with these serious environmental problems.
Canada is also striving to refine current principles with a view to eventual negotiation of its international convention on forests, one of which will deal with the development and management of these vital resources.
At the heart of UNCED is the need to resolve differences between the north and the south, to merge the two agendas of environment and development into one goal of sustainable development.
During the preparatory meeting, developing countries pointed out that they had to meet basic needs before dealing with their environmental consequences. They also concurred however that population pressures on fragile ecosystems and unregulated economic growth could deplete the very resources they required for their people's sustenance. Their potential to degrade the environment could be as damaging as any hazardous pollutant emitted in the industrialized countries.

Therefore, the challenge for Canada and our partners was to begin a process for dealing with environment and development from both sides of the coin. We had to come up with innovative ways to enable countries, but particularly the Third World, to reduce global risk. We had to consider ways to assist developing countries in meeting the incremental costs of adjusting their development to make it sustainable.
We had to think about traditional development assistance and how it could be improved to implement sustainable development objectives. We had to examine new ideas to mobilize new and additional financial resources, including through investment and debt arrangements.
We also had to consider the pivotal role of technology in meeting the challenge of sustainable development. Data management, energy efficiency, and waste minimization, especially in industry and agriculture, all require state of the art technology. Developing countries want preferential and concessional access to these technologies. The question of financing and technology transfer remain to be resolved in Rio, a reflection of their fundamental importance. Canada played a crucial role facilitating the complex discussions on financial resources. For our part, we are committed to providing funding for sustainable development in developing countries. This is already demonstrated, for example, by our contribution to the UN World Bank global environmental facility, to a multilateral fund to protect the ozone layer, and to international development assistance projects.
We are seeking ways to promote the transfer of environmentally sound technologies, taking into account legitimate trade and commercial rules and practices.
These are complex issues and UNCED cannot be a panacea for the problems and conflicts which have arisen on the road to Rio. As the Secretary of State for External Affairs has stated, UNCED is not the earth's last chance. It is, however, a chance for us all to work together, governments and non-governmental organizations. Indeed, NGOs have shown us that in addition to being creative thinkers and skilful lobbyists,
The Environment
they too are shrewd negotiators on the international stage. Their visible participation in UNCED and its related processes is a pointed reminder that Rio cannot be the end of the road.
UNCED poses an extraordinary challenge to all of us. It is important that we not have raised expectations about resolving the environmental development dilemma by June 14. That is not what the conference is all about. Nations and individuals are being asked the world over to take first steps toward an ambitious long-term goal. The ecosystem is a complex web of entwined linkages. It cannot be neatly compartmentalized into different segments. The same thing holds true for us, the stakeholders of the earth. We each have a responsibility to do our part in ensuring the outcomes of UNCED are not lost on future generations. Whether as nations or ordinary folk, we can think and act locally and globally. Let us work together to take those first steps toward sustainable development.
