speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext: The hon. member for LaSalle-Emard has 20 minutes.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I would like to thank the parliamentary secretary for his courtesy, and my colleagues on this side of the House. I promise that I will not abuse the privilege which you have given me.

The Environment

It is with pleasure and great interest that I rise today to express my expectations for the coming United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development, better known as the earth summit.

Rising today gives me a special pleasure. We are here to talk about the Rio conference, a conference headed by Canadian Maurice Strong, a person I have known for a long time, a Canadian indeed but one whose vision encompasses the whole world.

Let us hope that this conference will make irreversible the deep changes in attitudes and values now going on with respect to the environment and saving our planet. Basically, Canadians, like people in other countries, have started to see progress in a new light. An improved quality of life is now a more reliable indicator of progress than mere economic growth.
If people increasingly choose quality over quantity, the need to protect the world's environment will no longer be only essential, but the basic principle underlying the whole future of the human community.
The environment must be the basis of everything we do. A healthy environment is now an essential precondition for a sustainable dynamic economy. A healthy environment is a precondition for moral equity between the generations, between northern and southern countries, and even between species, it must be said.
For these reasons, we cannot be content with partial success at the Rio conference. It would be too easy to hide behind partial success and minimize the amount of work that will remain to be done.

I am now going to switch to English because I think my mother is watching and she will understand.
The challenge at Rio is very great. The world needs an action plan. It needs clear targets, as was articulated by my colleague from Northumberland in her opening speech from this side of the House. These are targets that must be implemented from the smallest
village to the UN Security Council, from the poorest hut in the south to the grandest mansion in the north.
What does this mean? It means that we must recognize that the true threat to the life support system of our ecosystem is over consumption in the north and unmet basic needs in the south. That is why the breakdown between the north and the south at the recent prep-com conference was so tragic.
Why is there environmental degradation? Why is there environmental degradation in 75 per cent of the world's population? It is because 75 per cent of the world's population is poor. Clearly this is the make or break issue for all progress at UNCED.
It appears that there will now be a global environmental facility established to fund the new costs that are associated with the measures that we hope, as my colleague from Northumberland outlined, will be brought out at the Rio convention.
The national round table in our country on environment and the economy has called on Canada to commit a minimum of $100 million a year in new and additional funding with a financial package for the developing countries to implement the earth summit's conclusions.
It is inconceivable that the Canadian government remains silent. Other countries, Japan for example, have said that their chequebooks were open.
Why do the poor cut forests that we need to breathe. They do so because when you need wood to burn in order to get heat, or when you need to build shelter, you take whatever is at your disposal. We have to begin to understand that you cannot divorce the issue of environmental degradation from the very deep issue of poverty.
UNCED is taking place at a time of great change and increasing interdependence. It is unfortunate for this reason that UNCED is taking place in isolation from the GATT. The environment is going to be the number one focus at the next trade round following the GATT. We must be prepared to introduce countervailing sanctions, not simply because countries seek to manage trade but because countries, industries, and municipalities seek to mismanage the sound administration of the ecological system of this world.
May 7, 1992

Within that context, it is unfortunate that the NAFTA does not include, within the body of its negotiation, the sound and increasingly improving environment principles and standards.
It is inconceivable that in this day and age a government would seek to negotiate a trade agreement on the continent in which we share air, water and soil and not understand that the environment must be protected within the body of that agreement and must not simply be an addendum to be dealt with later.
There is the need for new institutions, new institutional arrangements. The UN Security Council must be reconstituted, not simply on the basis of military power and the basis of economic strength, but on the basis of those nations capable of protecting the ecosystem of the world.
My colleague on this side of the House from Saanich-Gulf Islands gave a very important speech on the role of women within the context of the environment. I believe that the environment is going to be, on a world-wide basis, one of the principal means of bringing forth the role of women. They are the ones who draw the water in the Third World. They are the ones who see the food which is contaminated by pesticides. I believe that as a result of the environmental awakening in the world the role of women is going to be more clearly understood.
At Rio, the absence of women's issues is going to be felt. The same mistake will not be made again. It is the same thing in terms of indigenous people. It is very clear that there are new players entering the world scene. Those of us who would protect the environment must understand that they are crucial to that debate.
The minister spoke of the crucial need to sign major conventions such as forestry and bio-diversity. The one that I would focus on is the framework convention on climate. We have now been told, as my colleague from Saanich-Gulf Islands and my colleague from Northumberland said, that agreement has been reached in the New York negotiations on the framework convention on climate change. We have also been told that the agreement buckles under to American pressure. We have been told the agreement will be non-binding.
I spent my whole life in business. I do not understand a non-binding agreement. We are told it includes no targets and no timetables. We are told that it contains no mechanisms for technology transfer, no
The Environment
financial commitments for developing countries. If this is true, it is no more than a shell.
The national round table on environment and the economy recommended that Canada not sign such a convention unless it included binding targets and schedules. What is the government's position? I fear for the answer. Canada's position entering the negotiations has been to stabilize greenhouse gases at 1990 levels by the year 2000. Will this commitment be reconfirmed despite the apparent weakness of the international convention? I hope so, but there has been no reconfirmation by the government.
Finally, the measures set forth in the green plan will only bring us 60 per cent of the way toward stabilization. Will there be a strategy for achieving the remaining 40 per cent? Will the government take a world leadership role in a world problem?
The minister spoke of the green plan. Let us be very clear. I say this with a great deal of sadness. This is a plan of broken promises and of budget cutbacks. It is a plan that has failed to assess policy. It is a plan that has failed to provide a vision.
I hope that what comes out of Rio shows a greater world conscience than has been shown by this government in terms of the very basic human problem of how we preserve this very fragile planet.
Other members will speak to you on the fishery. I would raise one point. The vital importance of protecting the marine environment has been widely recognized in the preparations for UNCED. It has the need to assist developing countries in their ability to manage and develop their coastal and ocean resources.
Just when there is a need and a recognition for environmental capacity building in developing countries, that is to say, the development of locally based expertise and management skills, what does the government do? It dissolves the International Centre for Ocean Development.
This centre enabled the kind of north-south cooperation that is now being called for by UNCED. It helped small coastal states, primarily small island states, to develop expertise to sustainably manage their fishery resources. It worked on a budget of $23 million and it gave small but significant grants to coastal states for their work.

Private Members' Business
Ironically it is many of these same coastal states which have supported Canada in making the issue of conservation of fisheries prominent on the UNCED horizon. The government's approach is counterproductive. It is virtually suicidal for hundreds of Atlantic Canadian communities that are dependent upon the fishery.
Canada needs all the support it can get. This is not the time to cut the funding to those countries that will support us in what is the single most vivid example of a lack of sustainable development; the decimation of the cod stocks off the nose and tail of the Grand Banks of Newfoundland.
We are asked in this particular debate to take note of the government's position. That is a little difficult because I do not know what the government's position is. I do know, however, that at all the prep-com conferences, a wide range of Canadian public servants have worked very hard. I know that what could have been a leadership position by the government was undercut by the failure of the Canadian Prime Minister to commit to going to Brazil until the last possible moment.
As a result this country, which could have been the bridge between the north and the south and which has established such a strong position, lost the opportunity on what has become the single most important issue facing civilization.
The time has come to conclude. I would do so by simply giving one piece of advice to the government. The Rio conference, my colleague from Northumberland so articulately said in opening the debate, has to succeed. It cannot fail. The hopes and aspirations of countless generations not yet born depend upon what the world does this June.
There is one thing worse than failure at Rio. That is failure covered over by bland communiques of success. The world must not come out of Rio bound in some form of a chloroform handkerchief saying that it has succeeded. If we fail, then let the world know that we failed because at least we may have a catalyst to wake this world up to the tremendous danger that it is under.
It may well have been that if the world, as the Second World War approached in the 1930s, understood the dangers that lay before it, it might have taken the steps to counter Armageddon. What I would say in conclusion is let us hope that Rio succeeds. If it is going to fail, then let it fail openly so that the world understands that failure cannot be allowed to stand. Otherwise, this planet will not survive.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext: The House will now proceed to the consideration of Private Members' Business as listed in today's Order Paper.

that Bill C-227, an act to amend the Criminal Code (desecration of the flag), be read the second time and referred to a legislative committee in the Departmental envelope.
He said: Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have this opportunity to proceed with this debate on Bill C-227. This is a bill prohibiting desecration of the Canadian flag.
I am pleased to proceed because it has been nearly two years since I first submitted the bill. It was drawn and approved for debate and voted on in this House, but the proroguing of the House pre-empted all of that and it was lost. I was fortunate enough to have it drawn again and selected as a votable item. Finally today we are proceeding with the first hour of debate.
First, let me say that in Thomas More's fictional Utopia laws are not needed. Every citizen is guided by reason, devoid of greed and self-interest. However, we do not live in Utopia. We live in a democracy which must enact laws to curb individual activity and inactivity for the sake of society at large.
At times the tension between individual rights and the social good erupts in ways that make one want to take a definite stand. Desecration of the flag, in my opinion, is one of these occasions.

It has been said that Canadians are reluctant to proclaim their patriotism, that they cherish reticence as a national virtue. This has certainly not been the case when it comes to our national symbol.
Since first introducing this bill in the fall of 1990 I have found that the protection of our flag has proven to be a very emotional and difficult issue. Whatever our heritage, politics or religious beliefs, it has been determined to be an issue close to the hearts of millions of Canadians.
I believe that this is because no other object remotely resembles the flag as the symbol of our identity as a nation. For most of us it holds a very unique place in our national life. I will admit that both sides of the issue hold some very sound and reasonable views. Some will argue that to prohibit desecration of our flag is a restriction of their freedom. I understand and empathize with their concerns.
Others, like myself, believe that this great nation of ours should protect and respect our most powerful symbol, that its desecration tears at the very fabric of our nationhood. It is for this reason that I have introduced this legislation. I sincerely believe that this bill recognizes the deeply held feelings of a vast majority of citizens for the physical integrity of our flag.
I am sure no one will dispute that. For most countries the flag is the single most important symbol of one's nationalism, representing everything that a country stands for. It identifies, it communicates, and it inspires. It is flown by nations, provinces, states, towns, churches, private sector institutions and schools. It is used by armed services and civilian organizations. It expresses our joy when raised on holidays and it expresses our sorrow when it must be flown at half-mast. When draped over a coffin it honours those who have given their lives in service to our country. Whether it flies over an embassy, from the masthead of a ship or at an international sports meet, it is always an assertion of our sovereignty.
To me the Canadian flag represents everything my country stands for. As chairman of the Canadian-NATO Parliamentary Association I have had the opportunity to visit many countries and have seen the absolute reverence shown by those people for their flag. I understand and recognize that pride, for wher-
Private Members' Business
ever I may be in the world, the sight of the maple leaf reminds me of how honoured I am to be a Canadian.
It was almost 98 years after Confederation before Canada finally had a truly distinctive flag. It had been the subject of great debate intermittently since 1867, with a number of great debates in the House of Commons, most prominently in 1925 and again in 1945 and 1946.
Finally on December 15, 1964 the red and white maple leaf was approved as Canada's official flag and was first raised on February 15, 1965.
Since that time it has flown proudly representing not any single set of ideas and beliefs, but rather the unity that has emerged from our diversity as a nation. As Canadian society becomes increasing more pluralistic, it becomes more and more important to have this one symbol which has the ability to transcend literary and language barriers, besides unifying our nation as a whole.
It is my belief the one symbol that expresses our existence as a community, the one symbol that stands above all others as an expression of our nationhood, is the Canadian flag. Our flag should be preserved inviolate as the one symbol that stands above political and partisan ideological dispute.
I am privileged to represent the riding of Scarborough East, a riding where these very diverse cultures, nationalities and religious backgrounds have come together under this one flag. It fills me with pride to see the children of those families proudly waving this symbol of our national unity.
As an educator for over 30 years, I had the opportunity on many occasions to observe young people. I would like to take this occasion to read from a letter sent to me from a young boy scout, Mr. Nathan Bean, expressing his views about our flag. This is what he says:
I am strongly opposed to the deliberate destruction of the Canadian flag. Why do people destroy the flag? It is a sacred piece of material. Not many people would deface the coin of the realm so why destroy the Canadian flag? When people destroy the flag by burning it, tearing it, or walking on it, they are destroying a part of Canada. Piece by piece, flag by flag we'll fall apart. The two red bands on the side stand for truth and valour and when you destroy the bands you are not being true to your country and you are diminishing the courage of this great country Canada.

Private Members' Business
That is the end of that young boy scout's letter which I think says a lot to all of us. This is the voice of our youth and our future, the voice of a young boy who is obviously honoured to be a Canadian and proud of what that stands for. He understands, as I do, that what we are talking about here is the integrity and dignity of one of our most enduring and precious symbols, the Canadian flag.
Furthermore, in a questionnaire sent out to my constituents about this very issue approximately a year ago, 82 per cent of the respondents were strongly supportive of this particular bill.
This legislation would protect this symbol, making it an offence to wilfully burn, deface, defile, mutilate, trample upon or otherwise desecrate this flag, except of course when the flag has become worn, soiled or damaged.
The term desecration is defined as "to deprive of sacred character". It is my opinion that those who desecrate or deprive our flag of its sacred character deserve nothing but utter contempt. Desecrators of the Canadian flag threaten our freedom, challenge our strength and trample upon the sensitivities of patriotic Canadians. If we allow the flag to be desecrated, then we also allow a desecration of the sacrifices that our people have made on behalf of our country as symbolized by our flag. Should we collectively as a society permit our national honour to be trampled on as well?
Seventy-five years ago on April 19, 1917, 35,000 Canadians launched a full scale assault on the entrenched German position along Vimy Ridge. A sacrifice was made by thousands of young Canadians who came from all across our country to defend freedom. Our allies gallantly fought their way up and captured a ridge that many said was unassailable.
The Canadian army did not fight its way up Vimy Ridge at the expense of 3,500 of our countrymen who would never see their homeland again to raise the flag of Ontario, a copy of the British North America Act, or the Royal Seal of His Majesty the King. The heroes of 1917 did so in the name of the maple leaf which they proudly wore as a dominant symbol on their military uniform. The supreme sacrifice made by thousands of young Canadians at Vimy to maintain our collective resolve to defend justice and freedom will rest forever under the shade of that maple leaf.
Last year over 1,000 service personnel returned from active duty in the Persian Gulf. These brave men and women were prepared to give their lives to protect the right to democracy that we as Canadians often take so much for granted. For seven months our flag flew proudly from those military bases, a constant reminder of what our great country stands for.
Some of the strongest endorsements for this bill to become law are coming from the Royal Canadian Naval Association and the National Council of Veterans' Associations which represents 19 varied veterans associations. These organizations are not the only groups interested in this bill. I have had widespread support from Canadians right across the country for this particular initiative.
These flags will be kept and protected forever of a remembrance of such an important moment in history. Is it now just another symbol? I think these men and women would strongly disagree. I think that they would consider it a grave dishonour to treat our flag with anything less than the utmost in respect and reverence. I can only imagine how tough it would be for them to see this cherished symbol defiled.
However, you do not have to be a member of the armed forces or a veteran to understand what the Canadian flag means, nor do you have to be a super patriot to understand that the symbol of our freedom deserves to be protected.
Some of course will argue that to prohibit the desecration of the flag challenges the very rights that our flag stands for. This is a case of where do we draw the line. We all understand that freedom of speech and political expression are some of our most cherished rights as Canadians. I certainly do not support any infringement on an individual's free speech. I realize that we cannot prohibit someone from saying whatever comes to mind about this country or about the flag; that is clear. Anyone with an opinion can and should express his or her views. This is what the principle of democracy is all about in Canada.
Taking away the right to desecrate the flag does not limit an individual's ability to say he hates his country, his fellow countrymen, its institutions or its leaders. You can say or write anything you want about the flag, but it is when we step over that line, that line from speech to conduct, which is not necessary to the expression of one's views, that there should be a definite distinction.

It is no longer freedom of speech that we are talking about, but a freedom to do anything we want without consequence. Put another way, this form of free speech implies that an individual can express himself with any type of public behaviour at any time and the community is powerless to set limits on these particular acts.
It is not free speech to burn the flag even though they may quite genuinely have some very profound and legitimate grievance to be addressed. Their purpose is not served by desecrating our flag. It is an act that simply dishonours this symbol of freedom.
Some find these limits unacceptable. Unlimited freedom would make all law which by definition restricts freedom impossible. All laws ultimately limit freedom in our society as we know it. It is just a case of, and I repeat, where do we draw the line.
It may well be necessary for the Supreme Court of Canada to rule on whether such a law inhibits unnecessarily the freedom of expression.
In closing, as I have said at the beginning, this issue is an extremely emotional one, one in which I have learned very few do not have an opinion. In the United States Congress it was the subject of many hours and months of a very impassioned, emotional debate before the historic Supreme Court ruling of June 1989. The United States Supreme Court overturned a similar law passed by the U.S. Senate by a vote of five to four. As I said, it may be necessary for this particular law, when passed in this House, to proceed to the Supreme Court. It would be very interesting to listen to its deliberations and decision.
In response to the United States Supreme Court decision, Robert Bork, a former Federal Court Appeals Judge put it this way:
Ultimately, the question is whether the nation is entitled to one
symbol that must remain undefiled. I think so. To say that the
freedom of speech requires that no symbol remain sacrosanct is to
say something demeaning about the first amendment itself.
With that I could not agree more.
Our flag is not just another symbol, but is our nation's most powerful symbol and it must be treated with the respect and the reverence it is due. No other
Private Members' Business
object remotely comes close to resembling the flag as the symbol of our identity as a nation.
In conclusion I will quote briefly from the national flag ceremony. His Excellency, the Right Hon. Georges P. Vanier, Governor General of Canada, said:
I hope and pray-that our flag will symbolize to each of us and
to the world the unity of purpose and high resolve to which destiny
beckons us.
I look forward with great anticipation to the comments of my colleagues.

Madam Speaker, I am pleased to be able to speak on this private members' bill presented by the member for Scarborough East. I congratulate him on this bill, as well as the fact that he is obviously very concerned about this question and about where our country is going with respect to its unity and to our feelings as Canadians about our country.
It is quite evident that this hon. member has a very strong feeling for his country and for his flag, and those of us who know him know this to be very true. He is a man who has brought very special dignity to the House of Commons, and his motion here today just emphasizes that once again.
Any time we talk about our country and about our flag it is an important question. It is not something to be taken lightly, by any stretch of the imagination. Whether, as the hon. member for Scarborough East has said, it is an emotional issue I cannot really say. However, I can say that it is a very important issue because it goes to the fabric of what we are as a nation.
When we discuss Canada and the representations and the symbols of our country they are very important discussions indeed. They are all part of what our country is and what we as Canadians feel toward our country.
Canada is unquestionably a very special country. To those who live outside of our borders it is the greatest country in the world. Sometimes we take our country for granted. However we should listen to the reports of others outside our borders. People in other countries speak about Canada in such glowing terms and look upon it as the epitome of what a nation should be.

Private Members' Business
We have reached this distinction not by being the greatest military power in the world, not by being the greatest scientific power in the world, or even the most populous country in the world. We have reached this position by being distinctively Canadian. That is what it has come to be.
What does that mean? It means that we are a country of rational people who have brought this country together through peaceful means, through negotiation, through the wish of two cultures to live together as one, together with the aboriginal peoples who were the first residents of this country and recognizing the rights that they have. These three peoples have founded this country in which we take so much pride.
We take pride because our history has not been the gun blazing west or an example of might or of imposing imperialism on other countries. We take pride in the example that we have set to one another as Canadians, and in the example we have provided to those in other countries.
When war came Canadians were always there to help the oppressed peoples of the world. When aid was sought by other countries throughout the last 200 years Canada was always there ready to lend a helping hand. When people from other countries were persecuted within their own boundaries and left their country and came to Canada we took them in.
This is what Canada symbolizes. It symbolizes an understanding, it symbolizes a pride.
It symbolizes a feeling of pride and understanding that we carry in our hearts. It is not a manifestation of something we can show, although we have our passports, medical cards, and social security numbers. Certainly those are manifestations. However, the true manifestation of a Canadian is what he or she carries in his or her heart, which is the pride of having created and worked toward a country which is the envy of all people throughout the world.
That is not to say the manifestations themselves are not important. Manifestations are important because when we talk about our country we must have certain manifestations. Our flag is the first and foremost of these manifestations.
I understand the bill and the wish of the member for Scarborough East. I feel very strongly that we cannot
desecrate the flag. It is a travesty to desecrate the Canadian flag.
In keeping with our history and our understanding as Canadians I want Canadians to not desecrate the flag. I want Canadians to appreciate the flag without having the law say that they cannot desecrate it. I want Canadians to feel in their hearts more than anything else pride for what we have and what we have developed as a country. When they see the flag I want them to understand that this is the manifestation of the pride that they carry in their hearts and therefore they will not want to desecrate the flag.
The United States has a law, as the hon. member has said, which makes it a crime to desecrate the flag. It went much farther in its law because it not only talks about the flag itself but about any picture or representation of the flag.
It has caused some problems in knowing where to draw the line. Perhaps we remember a controversy last year when the wife of the President of the United States wore a scarf which had a picture of the flag of the United States. She was severely criticized by many as desecrating the flag.
A young person was arrested for wearing a patch of the United States' flag on their jeans. That is carrying it too far and I do not want to see that. I want our young people to wear patch of Canada on their sleeve when they are visiting other nations as a symbol of pride in their country. I do not want young people who have T-shirts with the Canadian flag on them to feel anything but pride in what they are wearing. I do not want them to have the moment darkened by the fact that someone may accuse them of desecrating the flag.
Canadians have pride in their country and pride in their flag and they will always have that. If we do not have that, if the day comes when Canadians do not have pride in their flag then all else will be lost in Canada. We will cease to be the nation we are and we will most certainly have deteriorated into at the very best a hollow shell of our former selves.
I would say to the hon. member, to other members and to all Canadians that if you cannot carry around in your heart the pride of Canada, of what this country stands for, it is not nationalism. We do not go out and constantly beat our breasts and say how great we are. We leave that for others to do. They are quite ready to tell one another how great Canada is.

As we are seeing today, nationalism can be a disease. We do not want that. We want the understanding and the realization that Canadians have. That is what we want and that is what we want to keep. I am very much afraid that if we amend the Criminal Code to make it unlawful to desecrate the flag then we are in some way desecrating the Criminal Code by having to do that.
It is not what we want in our law. We do not want to make it illegal for Canadians to wear the Canadian flag but we do want Canadians to appreciate the Canadian flag, and I am hoping that they do and will. Maybe I will be proven to be wrong, but if we cannot truly appreciate our country then we cannot appreciate our flag.
If we cannot appreciate our flag we cannot appreciate our country, and if we cannot appreciate our country then we as a nation are in very serious difficulty-
Mr. Bob Corbett (Fundy

Royal): Madam Speaker, it gives me great pleasure to speak in the House of Commons on such a very important subject as has been introduced into the House in the form of Bill C-227 by my friend and colleague from Scarborough East.
My colleague's motion would make it a criminal offence for any Canadian citizen-and I trust that my hon. friend from Cape Breton would appreciate that it is the intention of my hon. friend from Scarborough East to indicate that it would be a criminal offence- to wilfully burn, deface, defile, mutilate, trample, or otherwise desecrate the Canadian flag. I know very well that it is not the intention of my hon. friend in the bill he has presented before the House to suggest that a young Canadian proudly wearing the symbol of Canada, the Canadian flag, on his or her arm as an arm patch or on his or her jacket as they travel throughout the world is defiling or mutilating the symbol of Canada.
I am sure that is something that my hon. friend would abhor and would just as strongly defend the right of that individual to display the Canadian flag in that context as he would abhor the mutilation and
Private Members' Business
defacing of the Canadian flag by other various obvious means.
The Canadian flag is presently protected against criminal usage and false representation of citizenship under section 9 of the Trade Marks Act of Canada. The bill we have before us today would increase that level of protection.
On February 15, 1965 at 12 noon the symbol which came to represent Canada after much debate in the House and throughout the land was raised on flagpoles from sea to sea to sea to unite Canadians and bring them under a common and unified banner. Since that day the Canadian flag has become the most visible symbol of Canada and has come to represent Canadian values at home and throughout the world.
The flag is identified with flight, with peacekeeping forces, with our international development aid programs, and with the emergency humanitarian aid Canada has so often sent abroad to others in countries that were in need.
The Canadian flag is a tool for which barriers can be taken down. As we have already discussed, the flag is a symbol for all Canadians-youth, seniors, new Canadians, francophones and anglophones alike. We must not let our differences come between us. The glue that holds us together is the fact that we are Canadians, that we are proud to live as Canadians and to live free as we please. The Canadian flag is the symbol that represents this notion.
How can we as parliamentarians and as Canadians let anyone desecrate such an important component of our Canadian way of life? The Canadian flag is a guarantee that as long as it represents Canada and Canadians we will enjoy certain freedoms, such as the freedom to express beliefs and opinions without fear of social censure, the freedom to participate in the political process and thereby to take part in the building and strengthening of Canadian society.
These freedoms are guaranteed by the laws of Canada. They are symbolized by our national flag. These rights and freedoms are not to be taken for granted or abused. They are ours to do so as we please and does not necessarily give us the right to abuse or manipulate them.

Private Members' Business
While many other nations search for a sense of identity, we in Canada are extremely fortunate to have one that is representative of the values of freedom and equality. Our symbol, the Canadian flag, stands for something. It more than any other device acts as our manifestation of our collective ideals.
Dr. George Stanley, a fellow New Brunswicker, the former Lieutenant-Government of my province, whose red and white maple leaf design had considerable influence on the development of the Canadian flag, once said: "A flag is more than a means of identification. It is the embodiment of what a country stands for. It is the symbol of the ethos and the spirit of a people".
Although the flag was not officially adopted until 1965, in 1914 Canadians soldiers, as my colleague pointed out, displayed the maple leaf on their military badges. It was the designation of choice used by almost all Canadian regiments serving in the war. During World War II Canadian soldiers incorporated the maple leaf design on regimental badges and naval equipment.
The bill that we are debating today is not an attempt to stifle the rights of Canadians to express themselves but rather an attempt to protect this valued history and to ensure that the Canadian flag remains the symbol that we as Canadians can be proud to call our own, one that allows us to boast to the world that we are indeed Canadians and we are strong and we are free.
One further point concerning the importance of the adoption of this private member's bill is that if this bill is adopted then it will provide a precedent for us as parliamentarians to introduced further acts so that we can protect our national symbols such as the coat of arms and the provincial flags, as they too represent our differences while still representing the fact that we are Canadians.
I just want to close simply by saying that as a Canadian I am extremely proud we do have something that stands for us as Canadians, that stands for our Canadianism.
Just this past Tuesday I had the great fortune to be delivered by my daughter Susan of a baby boy in the province of Quebec. He is born a Quebecer and he is a Canadian. I just hope that in coming days and years he has the opportunity to grow up under the great symbol of Canada I have come to accept as being everything I cherish and feel so close to my heart, that is the flag of Canada. I hope he will continue, as I am continuing to
be, a proud Canadian and will live on to cherish that as I have.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Congratulations to the grandfather.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter Milliken (Kingston and the Islands):
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I congratulate the hon. member for Fundy-Royal on his very capable speech on this important bill moved by his colleague. I am pleased to rise to support the bill in its present form.
This bill had been drawn for debate as I recall before. The debate did not get held because the session came to an end and the bill died on the Order Paper. Although I have never won a draw for one of my dozen or so private members' bills, which is a shame, I congratulate the hon. member on winning the draw a second time and bringing forward this bill for discussion.
I think it is a worth-while bill, particularly so after the events that caused so much difficulty in our country with the trampling of a flag in Brockville. There was also the burning of a flag in my community of Kingston which attracted considerable press attention and was widely regarded as a most unpopular gesture by the citizens of my community who reacted quite strongly to this particular incident.
The bill that has been put forward seeks to make it an offence to desecrate the flag of Canada. I support the concept because the flag of our country does not represent a government. It represents the people of our country who have lived, worked and died to make this country a better place and in fact to make the world a better place.
Our flag is not the embodiment of the Government of Canada, although the government does use it for its own purposes to some extent and quite properly so. It is a symbol of everything about our country like the coat of arms of Canada and certain other national symbols. It embodies the people of this country as well as the government. It embodies the Parliament of Canada, the people of Canada and the Government of Canada. It is a symbol of everything about our country in all its aspects and in all its parts.
Because it is not a symbol of government, its desecration becomes more than a desecration, a criticism, an objection or a rejection of the government. It becomes damaging to the fabric of everybody because we all regard it as a symbol of everything our country stands for.

No single person or government owns the flag of Canada. Once the resolution approving the flag design was approved in this House in 1965 and the proclamation was issued declaring the flag to be the flag of Canada, it became everyone's flag. It became a symbol of our entire country.
The importance of it as a national symbol is very great. It is one to which we have perhaps attached too little importance in the past as witnessed by the absence of a law such as that proposed by the hon. member in the House today.
By stopping the desecration of the flag, we are not in any way prohibiting people from showing dissent from government policy or objection to the proposals, policies or initiatives of the Government of Canada. People are still free to speak out against their government or their political leaders of any political stripe.
They may show their opposition to government policy in various other ways. They can write letters, make speeches and have peaceful demonstrations. All these are quite lawful expressions of dissent, but the desecration of the flag goes beyond that kind of dissent and in my submission is damaging to the symbol of our country which we all regard as very important.
I think back and recall the times when the flag debate raged in this House and the difficulties we had in discussing that issue. As perhaps Your Honour can recall, the debate went on for months. It was extremely bitter and very protracted, but it ended up with a flag that I think all Canadians today hold in reverence and with great pride.
The people who struggled in this House through those years can remember that debate. The hon. member for Saint-Denis, the hon. member for Windsor West and the hon. member for Vancouver Quadra were in the House in those days. They would remember that debate, how bitter it was and how difficult it was.
Frankly it is reassuring today to find that there is such unanimity in the House on the question of our flag. Perhaps there will not be on this particular bill, but certainly there is in terms of the value of the flag as a national symbol, one that we all have great pride in and hold very dear.
Private Members' Business
There are two quotations on which I would like to close. One is from the Right Hon. Lester Pearson, who as Prime Minister on the first flag ceremony on February 15,1965 said these words outside this building:
Under this Flag may our youth find new inspiration for loyalty to Canada; for a patriotism based not on any mean or narrow nationalism, but on deep and equal pride that all Canadians will feel for every part of this good land.
Finally I have a quotation from the Hon. Maurice Bourget, Speaker of the Senate:
The Flag stands for the unity of the nation and unequivocally speaks for all the citizens of Canada, regardless of their race, language, creed or opinion.
In seeking to protect this national symbol, I know all hon. members will look to the bill we have before us and carefully consider its wording before casting votes for or against this excellent proposition put forward by the hon. member.

Madam Speaker, I too am very pleased today to rise and say a few words in support of Bill C-227.
As our country's symbol, the value of the Canadian flag cannot be measured. Our flag is based on the traditions and values upon which this country was founded. It represents more than nationhood and patriotism. It also represents the very character of Canada which makes this country the most unique and greatest country in the world.
It has been said that a flag speaks for the people of a nation. The flag is used in celebration when it is raised at holidays and at other festivities. It also expresses our sorrow when flown at half-mast. The flag also expresses our reverence for those who have given their lives in its name in wartime or while in keeping the peace.
The purpose of this bill is to instil the necessity of respecting the importance of the flag's past role and its continuing symbol of what Canada is today by providing that anyone who wilfully burns, defaces, defiles, mutilates, tramples upon or otherwise desecrates the Canadian flag will be guilty of a criminal offence. This bill will ensure the protection of and respect for the ideals upon which this great country has been founded.

Private Members' Business
The idea of the Canadian flag was born back in March 1964, during a chance meeting between a former eastern Ontario member of Parliament and United Empire Loyalist, Mr. John Matheson and George Stanley, a one-time Dean of Arts at the Royal Military College in Kingston, Ontario.
At the time the government was considering the possibility of providing Canada with a distinctive Canadian flag. When informed of this intention by Mr. Matheson, Mr. Stanley drew a design of a maple leaf on a red and white background. He later submitted a memorandum to the government listing the traditional symbols of Canada. The beaver and the maple leaf were on the top of that list.
In early 1964 the Prime Minister of the day had informed the House that the government had a desire to adopt a truly distinctive national flag. The ensuing debate about the design of the flag has been described many times as no less fierce. It demonstrates the intense devotion Canadians from across the country feel about Canada.
The official ceremony inaugurating the new Canadian flag which was held on February 15, 1965 was a very emotional time. On that day the Speaker of the Senate at the time said that the flag was a symbol of the nation's unity for it, beyond any doubt, represents all the citizens of Canada without distinction of race, language, belief or opinion. These words add further symbolic meaning to our flag and illustrate that our flag is more than just mere identification. It is representative of the very character, substance and spirit of this great nation.
In realizing the importance of the Canadian flag, what it really represents or stands for and the emotion it evokes among Canadians, it should be our duty to make sure that it is properly protected.
There are those who have said, especially our neighbours to the south where similar legislation has twice been ruled unconstitutional by the United States Supreme Court, that laws such as the one proposed in this particular bill infringe upon society's right to freedom of speech. I certainly disagree with these arguments. Protection of the flag, a unique symbol of nationality, will in no way limit the opportunity or the breadth of protest available in the exercise of freedom of speech. Freedom of speech must not extend to
those who would damage another national symbol, the Parliament Buildings for example.
I seek only to protect the national symbol which is just as, and maybe more significant, our Canadian flag. Protecting our flag will not inhibit other forms of protest such as speech, the use of placards or literature or any other number of peaceful, non-violent actions. It simply will ensure the protection of the unique symbol which Canadians, time and time again, have shown to be the one thing which most represents Canada and what it is about: the best place in the world to live.
This year, 1992, as we know marks Canada's 125th anniversary. Our history stretches back to the First Nations of this land. It embraces such beliefs as those of the United Empire Loyalists many of whom settled in eastern Ontario, who over two centuries ago sought a better life. And it spreads out to include people from all nations of the world who arrived here looking for freedom and prosperity.
Our flag has come to embody this heritage, our pride in our country today and our hopes for the future. I think it is more than fitting that we preserve and ensure respect for our national symbol.
For that reason, I certainly want to add my congratulations to the member for Scarborough East for his introduction of this bill. I am very pleased to offer support on behalf of the proud Canadians I represent in Hastings-Frontenac-Lennox and Addington, a historic part Canada, settled by United Empire Loyalists over 200 years ago and the home of Canada's first Prime Minister, Sir John A. Macdonald, an architect of Confederation.
Our flag is the greatest symbol of national unity.

Madam Speaker, I just want to put a few remarks on record with respect to this important debate which comes at an important time in the debate over Canadian unity.
Everybody in Canada wears Canadian pins with pride, waves the flag on July 1 and at other functions with pride. You can certainly see it in the faces and actions of our children. We look to our flag when we are in other countries with pride. Although our flag itself is rather new to our history, it is already steeped in a lot of tradition over a short period of time.

As has been said already, whether it be in peacekeeping or whether it be in celebrations in various parts of the world, whether it be at the United Nations or in Commonwealth conferences, we look upon our flag with a great deal of pride.
We are looked on by every country in the world with some envy because for the most part, Canadians are seen as peace-loving, peacemaking and peacekeeping people. That is what our flag has shown over the past 25 to 30 years that we have had the maple leaf.
The symbol of the flag is something that certainly my children are proud to have in pointing to their heritage and their country. They were born in Canada as I was, and I am always very pleased to be able to give out flags, flag pins and table flags to young people who represent Canadians on rotary exchange trips or school trips while they go overseas. That is the symbol that says: "We are from a country, from a place that we are proud of."
This bill, however, goes a little far. As a lawyer, I have seen municipal, provincial, federal and criminal legislation that goes essentially unused or ignored. People are reluctant to prosecute because of problems or difficulties inherent in it.
I do not believe for a moment that people should desecrate or in anyway deface the flag. It is something that we are all proud of but I question whether the route to go in this case is through legislating it as a criminal offence within the Criminal Code of Canada.
Now, I say that partially from my background and partially from my own feeling that, no, I do not want to see things happen to the flag. I also do not want to see us bring in legislation for things that may be very difficult to prosecute and may lead to having one more law on the books that is essentially unenforceable because of the problems that it brings.
Personally, I turn inside out when I see any demonstration in my country by fellow Canadians that defiles or defaces what I have come to know and love as part of Canada. It is a part of my heritage, a part of what I like to wear and take with me when I leave our country, to be identified as Canadian.
I do not know whether we solve the problem by putting it into the Criminal Code. It has been pointed out to me during the course of this debate that perhaps the route to go is through an educational
Private Members' Business
process. There will always be the odd one who is outside of the law. What we have to do as parliamentarians, as adults, as teachers, is to try to instil in our children and in our children's children, in our friends and our neighbours, the same love for our country, the same love for the symbol of our country as we have. I do not think we have to take that added step of saying: "If you do something then you could go to prison".
I firmly believe this can be done in a way that may take some evolving, it may require an evolution. I appreciate what the member is trying to do in hurrying that step along. I do not see this as the solution to the problem of defacing of our flag.
I want to see people voluntarily feeling that national spirit. We can do that. We do not have to throw a lot of money at it. It is a matter of our expressing our feelings to others and having them express their feelings to their friends and neighbours. We do not have to follow the American way. We have been and are a gentler people, and this is one area where we do not necessarily have to follow them down the path. It is not the best way, I would suggest, to get where we want to go.
I hope that this bill will be reconsidered and I hope that an alternative might be found for it, because I do not believe that it is the route we should be taking at this stage.
I appreciate the member's love for country, love for flag, love for the symbol of nationalism but I must repeat once again, I do not think the criminal route is the route to go on this.
I cannot support the bill personally at this stage. I speak for myself. I cannot support the bill in criminalizing the defacing of the flag.
Madam Speaker, I know the hour is late. Perhaps you would be kind enough to advise me how much time I have.

speakerposition: Deputy Speaker and Chair of Committees of the Whole of the House of Commons
speechtext: Five minutes.

I am pleased today and thankful that I at least have five minutes to lend my support to my colleague for Scarborough East, my neighbour in the Confederation building. I appreciate the opportunity I have today to express my thoughts about the symbol that we have, the flag of Canada.

The Environment
I am sorry that I cannot agree with the previous speaker inasmuch as he is in the same profession as I, the legal profession. I find no difficulty at all in supporting a bill that would save and respect such an important symbol for our country.
It is perhaps apropos that this debate is on today inasmuch as Canada is in the process of commencing celebrations for its 125th anniversary since the founding of Canada. We were under the symbol of other flags for a period of time and it is only in the last 25 years that we were able to establish our own symbol.
We stand today at the threshold of a new Canada, of an extremely invigorated Canada. It is a Canada that will thrive under the new constitutional arrangements. I am satisfied clearly, unequivocally and beyond any doubt that when the unity debate is ended, we will be united under ten provinces and two territories, perhaps three as a result of the vote that was held the other night, and we will all be gathered together as one country, under one flag, our symbol.
It is apropos that we are at that threshold this evening. Again, I compliment my colleague for Scarborough East for bringing this important legislation before the House today.
Let me just come out with one thought. I come from an area that I am sure you will visit, Madam Speaker, in the very near future under the Voyageur Program. We look forward to welcoming you to the area of northwestern Ontario and Thunder Bay. As I thought about the remarks I was making tonight, I can only think that you will meet these folks, Madam Speaker.
I think about the community I represent. We have people from Scotland and Finland, people from Ukraine, from England, Ireland and Poland. We have people from Greece, Portugal, Italy, Germany, Holland, Croatia, Slovenia, China, Japan, Jamaica and other Caribbean nations. I am sure I have forgotten some.
Many of them left their homeland and chose Canada for their home. When they chose Canada as their home, they chose the flag as a symbol of our country. Many of these people from the countries that I have mentioned chose Canada because they wanted to be in a country where we live in peace, harmony and understanding of one another.
Surely the people I represent from the riding of Thunder Bay-Nipigon would become very distressed if we were to allow anyone to desecrate not just that symbol of national unity, but what the symbol truly represents, which is the unity of Canada and all people in Canada. I compliment and thank my friend for bringing this important debate before this House of Commons at such an appropriate time. I certainly support this legislation to the fullest extent. Thank you, Madam Speaker, for allowing me the time to make those points.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to say a few words on Bill C-227 this afternoon. There is no doubt whatsoever that desecrating our national flag is an act which is offensive. Like others here today, though, I have some reservations concerning the use of the criminal law to deal with such an affront.
Various sectors of our society have been urging the government to exercise restraint in the application of our criminal law. The government has been urged to use the criminal law only to reaffirm fundamental values.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT

speechtext: The House resumed consideration of the motion of Mr. Charest (p. 10331).

speakeroldname: Mr. Ross Belsher (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Fisheries and Oceans and Minister for the Atlantic Canada Opportunities Agency):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I rise with pleasure this afternoon to speak to the motion that is before us because it is certainly dealing with a subject about which many Canadians are deeply concerned. It is dealing with the environmental effects of what we hope will be accomplished in the environmental conference that will be held later this year in Brazil.
The United Nations Conference on Environment and Development is a forum for finding solutions to the world's pressing environmental problems. Therefore this conference presents a significant opportunity for Canada to work with other coastal states toward international solutions to high seas overfishing of straddling stocks.
One of the realities Canadians face is that unlike other coastal states some of our fish stocks straddle our 200-mile fishing zone. They are therefore for parts of the year beyond our management jurisdiction. Hence they are vulnerable to overexploitation on the high seas by distant water fleets.
In preparation for the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Rio de Janeiro in June we have been working with other coastal states to develop more effective measures on conservation and management of the marine resources in the high seas and, in particular, the straddling stocks.
Through the two years of preparatory meetings for this conference, Canada has found an increasing number of allies who wish to see an end to high seas overfishing. The resolution that Canada is co-sponsoring sets our principles and measures that would help give full effect to the Law of the Sea provisions on the rights and responsibilities of coastal states and others to co-operate in high seas conservation.
More than 40 countries have co-sponsored this resolution and wish to see full international agreement to its principles by world leaders at UNCED.
In addition, in New York at the final preparatory meetings non-government organizations also joined governments in calls for an end to high seas overfishing. They issued the New York declaration of high seas overfishing which reads in part: "All states should work to reinforce the provisions of the United Nations Convention of the Law of the Sea, recognizing the special rights of coastal states to straddling stocks and
The Environment
the concomitant obligations of distant water fishing nations to respect conservation measures on the high seas".
Canada is building support in the international community of this issue.
Let me put high seas overfishing in an international context by describing the global situation that Canada and its allies are seeking to improve.
The English scientist and statesman, Sir Francis Bacon, said:
Nature, to be commanded, must be obeyed"
Man cannot command of the oceans what he will. Disobedience of the laws of nature bring retribution. If we obey ecological limits we can command of nature a bountiful and a sustained harvest. If we exceed those limits, we will destroy the ecological integrity of living marine resources.
As the UN food and agricultural organization has pointed out, the world fishery situation is generally not one of bounty arising from obeying ecological limits. Rather it is one of decline caused by exceeding those limits. No area is more vulnerable to this than the high seas.
It is almost axiomatic: where fish can be harvested on high seas they are overly exploited leading to stock declines. There is an ecological crisis in high seas fisheries, one carrying grave social and economic consequences for fisheries-dependent populations.
No coastal fishery is more vulnerable to such stock declines than one where the fish migrate between coastal states jurisdiction and the high seas, and that is especially true for straddling stocks. I certainly do not have to tell our friends on the east coast of Canada about the stock that straddles the outer limits of our 200-mile limit, namely, the nose and the tail of the Grand Banks.
It is true for groundfish stocks like hake in the southwest Atlantic on Argentina's Patagonian Shelf. It is true for the orange roughy on the Challenger Plateau off New Zealand. It is true for blue whiting and jack mackerel in the east central and southeast Pacific off Chile and Peru. It is true for the pollack in the Doughnut Hole in the central Bering Sea between Russia and the United States. It is true again for pollack in the Peanut Hole in the centre of the Sea of Okhotsk off Russia's Pacific coast.

The Environment
It is true in the Sea of Japan, where the exclusive economic zones or better known as the EEZs have not been established and so the high seas begin at the limit of the territorial sea. It is true for cod, flounder and redfish on the Grand Banks of Newfoundland off Canada's Atlantic coast.
Some of these international fisheries are relatively new, like for orange roughy off New Zealand. The fishery on the Grand Banks of Newfoundland has been conducted internationally since the 16th century and from coastal populations in Newfoundland from the 17th century, but what was sustainable for so long no longer is so, given modern harvesting technologies, unless effective international controls are applied.
Let me give an example. There is an important flounder stock, American plaice, that straddles the 200-mile zone on the Grand Banks of Newfoundland. Because of harvesting by distant water fleets at levels far beyond what the resource can sustain, much of it immature fish taken in nursery areas, the total allowable catch and Canada's quotas have plunged by more than 50 per cent in five years. Similar dramatic declines have occurred in the cod and other flounder stocks. This has contributed to a 30 per cent reduction in Canada's offshore fleet and has severely reduced catches by small boat fishermen.
What happens when there is a conflict regarding harvesting of straddling stocks? Here is how a report of last July by the UN office for ocean affairs and Law of the Sea described the situation:
The dilemma posed for the coastal state is that unrestrained fishing of a straddling stock in an area beyond 200 miles can render useless any measures taken within 200 miles to manage that stock. Moreover, if the stock is predominantly within 200 miles during the greater part of the year, its depletion through overfishing beyond 200 miles may be disproportionate to the actual interest distant-water fishing states should have in the stock given its distribution between the areas within and outside 200 miles.
This is exactly the situation that Canada faces in the northwest Atlantic. There is perhaps no other coastal fishing area whose population is so vulnerable to overharvesting of straddling stocks on the high seas. What Canada and other fishing coastal states have sought to do in accordance with the Law of the Sea convention is to achieve conservation and proper resource management of straddling stocks through
regional fisheries organizations. The Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization or NAFO manages straddling stocks off of Canada's Atlantic coast.
From 1979 through to 1985, NAFO was effective in rebuilding stocks depleted before establishment of a 200-mile zone. Since 1986 however NAFO has been increasingly afflicted by the type of problems that have crippled other regional fisheries organizations, particularly disagreement by one major member over allocation decisions and inadequate measures for surveillance and control.
Inadequate surveillance and control is the Achilles heel of international fisheries management, rendering all else meaningless. There are some helpful signs though. However, there is a growing realization among certain distant water states of the need to reflect ecological limits. These responsible distant water states participate in regional fisheries organizations. They support stable resource sharing arrangements and accept needed international control measures. By contrast, several distant waters states do not act responsibly. For them, the right to fish on the high seas is a licence to fish at will, whatever the consequences.
There is a critical difference of views between coastal states and at least some distant water states regarding the nature of the right to fish on the high seas. In the UN report of last July to which I referred to earlier it stated:
The high seas right to fish is subject to the rights, duties, and
interests of the coastal state in respect of straddling stocks.
This is opposed by a view that there is a balance of interest struck in the Law of the Sea convention whereby distant-water states have virtually unlimited rights to fish on high seas in order to balance the rights of coastal states to resources within their EEZs.
This is not a proper reading of the Law of the Sea convention however. Rather, as the chairman of the fourth UNCED preparatory meeting, Tommy Koh of Singapore, recently pointed out, the freedom to fish on the high seas must be balanced with the obligation to co-operate with other states to ensure conservation of living resources. In effect, the freedom to fish on the high seas is subject to the principle of sustainable development and the action of distant water states should be measured against that standard.

As the 1987 World Commission on Environment and Development, more commonly known as the Brundtland commission, stated:
Without agreed, equitable and enforceable rules governing the rights and duties of states in respect of the global commons, the pressure of demands on finite resources will destroy their ecological integrity over time-Only the high seas outside of national jurisdiction are truly 'commons'; but fish species, pollution and other effects of economic development do not respect these legal boundaries.
Surely freedom of the high seas must mean more in practice than the right to overfish.
As I indicated when I began, to give practical effect to the principle of sustainable development in high seas fisheries, Canada is one of 40 countries that is sponsoring a resolution on high seas fisheries at UNCED. This resolution outlines the principles and measures that will give proper effect to the provisions of the Law of the Sea convention regarding stocks that migrate between coastal state jurisdiction and the high seas.
It also calls for an intergovernmental conference on high seas fisheries. We are seeking the support of those wishing to avert ecological disaster, whether coastal states or distant-water states. By this means we are endeavouring to heed Sir Francis Bacon's dictum by obeying nature in order to command of her a bountiful and sustainable harvest.
Protection of the ocean resources is but one of several areas of Canadian concern for the environment. Canada has put a high priority on the environment through its green plan. Major programs both domestically and internationally are moving many parts of the environmental agenda forward. Green plan support for Canada's participation in the implementation of the Montreal protocol for control of the chlorofluorocarbons is just one example.
The green plan support of the Canadian participatory committee for UNCED brought Canadians into the international UNCED forum to ensure that the objectives sought there reflect the wishes of individuals and communities.
I can assure the members of this House that those individuals and communities affected by high seas
The Environment
overfishing support Canada's efforts at UNCED to put an end to the destructive fishing of straddling stocks on the high seas.
All of the fish in the sea has a hollow ring in the many fishing communities of Canada's Atlantic coast. There is seen firsthand what happens when an ecosystem is under attack. Those communities as well as the other coastal states around the world are looking to UNCED for help.
The Canadian delegation at UNCED will be led by the Prime Minister. The issue of overfishing is a major reason he has decided to attend, and I know that all members from both sides of this House join in giving the delegation that goes from Canada to the conference in Rio their strong backing. It needs the enlisting of all the help of the countries that are interested in fishing, whether they be from the distant fishing fleets or from the ones that have their own coastal waters.
We need that kind of backing and that kind of support so that proper control can be taken of the straddling stocks, particularly over the nose and the tail of the Grand Banks. We will be looking forward with anticipation to the reports of the Rio conference that takes place this coming month.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in this debate, my colleague for Northumberland has effectively dealt with the impact of Third World poverty on the environment while my colleague for LaSalle-Emard made a substantial contribution with his speech on sustainable development, the depletion of natural resources and the importance of technological transfer to developing nations. Later on, my colleague from Bonavista-Trinity-Conception will make an important contribution on fisheries.
The issues before us today, all so very vaguely worded in the government's motion, are of enormous importance. In the limited time at my disposal, I will deal with the position of the Government of Canada and the one that the Government of Canada, in my view, should take at the earth summit if Canada is to live up to repeated declarations made by the Prime Minister at home and abroad over the past five years.

The Environment
First, let me say that Canada's record on sustainable development-this is what the earth summit will be all about-is not something to write home about because while we have talked a lot about sustainable development, we have hardly and are hardly practising it.
From fisheries to forests, from agriculture to energy consumption, from megaprojects to land use, from topsoil erosion to chemical fertilizers, our record leaves much to be desired. How then can we preach sustainable development at the earth summit if we do not practise at home what we preach abroad? How can we urge other nations to reduce their per capita emissions of carbon dioxide if we are at the top of the list? How can we preach sustainable forestry when we apply barbaric, clear cutting techniques in the forests of British Columbia?
Our inefficient methods in energy consumption, our lavish approach to land use, our ever weakening public transit policies, our rampant consumerism, our insensitivity to aboriginal peoples' requests to leave the land to them as in the case of the Great Whale or Oldman dam, our pathetic efforts in developing renewable energy technologies, the political propensity to yield to pressures from the fossil fuel lobby, the political impotence with respect to the ratification of the Law of the Sea, the dreadful decision to cancel the Science Council and the Ocean Institute, the insidious and systematic weakening of the National Research Council, all these facts put together point to the fact that this government five years after the publication of the Brundtland report and its endorsement by Canada at the United Nations General Assembly, that this government with one national and 10 provincial round tables across the nation, that this government with major declarations of complete commitments made at the United Nations, at The Hague, in Bergen, in Geneva, you name it, has not yet started to apply sustainable development in a substantive manner. So far the green plan has produced very few results. It attacks problems at the end of the process and not in the planning stage.
The Minister of the Environment earlier this afternoon made a reference to acid rain and the necessity of tackling global issues with other nations. Had we waited in 1983 for the U.S. government to move on reducing SO*in2*xx emissions, we would not be able
to claim, as we can today, having cut acid rain pollution in Canada by half in 1992.
We went ahead alone. We did it and finally, with President Reagan out of the way, the U.S. administration came on board. We proceeded alone because we had to give leadership on a matter of urgent necessity as we should also now with carbon dioxide and the convention on the atmosphere.
The weakness of this government is that when it comes to the crunch it is incapable of moving unless Washington gives the green light. That is the sad conclusion.
Since the earth summit will deal with the protection of the atmosphere on behalf of the entire global community, I must now turn my attention to this matter and inform the House that Environment Canada issued on April 28 of this year an important press release entitled, "Winter 1992 warmer than normal". This may come as a surprise to people, particularly in eastern Canada, but Environment Canada reports that in this past winter the trend toward warmer winters continued as temperatures in most regions were generally above normal, according to our meteorologists.
Temperatures were six to eight degrees above normal in central British Columbia and on the prairies but were near or below normal in the north and the east. A breakdown of average winter temperatures dating back to 1895 shows a trend toward warmer winters in most regions of Canada. Nationally, winter 1992 was the warmest winter in southern British Columbia, the third warmest on the prairies, the fifth warmest along the Pacific coast.
In the past 10 years we have had some of the warmest summers ever recorded in Canada. The prediction of meteorologists the world over is slowly emerging, namely, that climate change is taking place. The consequences could be devastating to the millions who live in coastal lands. Approximately one-third of the world's population from Bangladesh to the islands in the Pacific Ocean would be threatened should the Arctic cap start melting and sea levels rise as predicted by scientists.
In today's Globe and Mail members will find an article in which it is reported that global warming will cost the United States economy alone $60 billion a year by the year 2050.

The root cause of this climate change is attributed to the greenhouse effect, which in turn is attributed to our consumption of fossil fuels, namely oil and
coal.
Members will see why some of us on this side of the House, in particular, were so disappointed at the speech given at the opening of this debate today by the Minister of the Environment who ignored the urgency of changing our energy policies, the urgency of integrating the environment in our economic policies, the urgency of arriving at the earth summit with clear ideas as to what we want to achieve through an international agreement on the protection of the atmosphere. Clearly we want an agreement of substance, with teeth, with targets and timetables, none of that wishy-washy pap advanced by the parliamentary secretary for external affairs earlier this afternoon. A sheer disgrace.
Nations like Holland, Germany, Denmark, Australia and New Zealand have understood the importance of dealing with the greenhouse effect and climate change. Unlike Canada, they have already announced commitments to reduce the greenhouse emissions by the year 2005 by some 20 per cent. By contrast, in Canada we are timidly hearing the government talk about stabilizing its C02 emissions by the year 2000, but the fact that this afternoon the Minister of the Environment did not even reiterate this commitment tells us that even that weak commitment is uncertain.
Some of our major competitors, including Japan and Germany, have adopted energy efficiency policies which lead to the reduction of carbon dioxide and to better economic performance at the same time. It is good business, in other words, to be energy efficient, but this government has not got the courage, the vision or the intelligence to put it together.
It is inevitable at this point that one should ask why the government does not follow its words, its declaratory ability, particularly abroad, with actions at home. Why does it refuse to sign the draft on the atmospheric convention not unless, and by making it quite clear to the global community, it includes specific targets and timetables for the reduction of carbon dioxide emissions.
This is not a wide-eyed idea from the Official Opposition. This is a recommendation of the national round table on the environment and the economy, a body created by this government.
The Environment
We also call on the government, as the national round table has done, to contribute a minimum of $100 million to the financial package proposed by Maurice Strong on behalf of the earth summit and the global community.
Furthermore, the national round table proposes the establishment of an independent commission to identify federal government subsidy programs, especially in the area of agriculture, forestry and energy according to their sustainable development effects and then to begin a phase-out of the least desirable subsidies. With those freed moneys the government should consider improving the environmental efficiency of industry in those same sectors and enhance our commitment to support sustainable development in the developing world.
The national round table also urges the government to encourage reduction initiatives which would allow the poor nations in the Third World to practise and implement sustainable development, something that they cannot do now because they are under pressure to pay their debts and the interest on those debts.
A debate on the earth summit, without a reference to population increase, would be incomplete. The forecast is that the global community will double in the next 40 years from five billion to 10 billion inhabitants. Proposals have been made to the effect that women and couples must be given the tools and the right to choose the size of their own families.
In addition, population growth must be understood in terms of increased consumption and the impact on their resource base; namely land, water and air resources. Unfortunately the convention on population at the earth summit has been watered down so badly that it actually represents a retreat from earlier conventions in Mexico City and Bucharest.
