What this debate and all the discussions which have taken place so far on the earth summit point to is the growing degree of interdependence around the globe between continents, between regional communities, between peoples of different backgrounds and cultures. This means, for instance, that the traditional knowledge of aboriginal peoples should be used as a basis for sustainable development, be they inhabitants of the Arctic or the tropics. This means that national delegations should include representatives from the aboriginal peoples. It means we should support their efforts to be recognized as peoples with legitimate nationhood status.

The Environment
On the broader front of north-south relations, it means that Canada and other developed countries should ensure that developing countries have equitable access to the technologies needed to support
sustainable development.
Again, on the north-south front it means that governments of developed countries should promote at the earth summit urgently needed measures that would reverse the tragic flow of capital from poorer to richer nations. Governments should press for a substantive convention aimed at stabilizing greenhouse gases. Governments should agree to the promotion of measures aimed at stabilizing world population. Governments should practise at home sustainability in forests, in fisheries, in agriculture, in energy and in the totality of their economic and social programs. Governments should forge a new concept of security based on the elimination of threats from pollution, threats from possible collapse of life in food support systems, threats from desertification, threats from overfishing and overcutting.
It means that governments should finally ratify the Law of the Sea to make it operative. Canada, unfortunately, has not done so yet. Governments, as originally intended, should look at the earth summit as a place where a new political agenda ought to be pursued and, with the agenda and the provision of funds, to implement it. This is where the summit will make it or break it. If the funds are requested by Maurice Strong to implement it every year in the range of $125 billion, it will not come through.
The earth summit is to be a place where the policies would be pursued of growth sufficient to meet human needs and aspirations. It would be the place where you would agree on policies that would increase equity within nations, where you would agree on policies that would increase equity between developed and developing countries. You would agree on policies that would reduce rates of population growth, policies that would conserve and enhance the natural resource base of the globe, policies that would ensure a reduction in the energy and resource content in economic growth, policies that would lead to institutional change, to integrate at last the economy and the environment in one flow of decision making right from the beginning,
rather than picking up the cost of environmental damage because of bad economic decisions.
In conclusion, what is badly needed at the earth summit, and there is still enough time to generate it, is good political will and nothing else; political will to implement the new agenda, which I roughly sketched out here for you this evening. It is the new agenda which has been proposed by Maurice Strong, which has been proposed by Jim MacNeill, which has been proposed by David Munroe and many other distinguished Canadians.
What will be decided at the earth summit will have a profound impact on the global community over the next century. This summit is a crucial appointment with destiny and with history. The well-being of the global community will depend on the enlightenment and courage of the world leaders.
The question that has yet to be answered is: Will these leaders live up to the occasion?

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, we are hearing a lot of debate in the world today about who will go to Rio, who will not go to Rio, what they will say in Rio, or more important I suppose, what they will not say.
As we look at the emergence of the conference, when all the posturing is done, when all the rhetoric is finished, when all the trees are chopped down and the papers are piled on desks and faxed around the world, what will be left?
How will we measure the results of Rio? We hope that it will be more than a debate, an argument, between developed and developing countries. We hope that it will not break down over the differences of developed and developing countries, but rather results can be found by bringing developed and developing countries together through issues of common concern.
Those are the scientific issues of global warming, the ozone layer. These important big science and technological kinds of issues are facing the very survival of our globe. These are the major elements of discussion at Rio.

The real measure of the success or lack of success of Rio will be the quality of the air we are able to breath a few months or a few years later. Will it be better or worse? If the quality of air continues to deteriorate and we can no longer breathe, we have failed.
If the water that we drink continues to deteriorate in quality, we will have failed.
If we cannot find a solution to waste management programs, if we cannot find any place to put our garbage or to reduce the amount of garbage that we are piling up until we sit on piles of garbage that leach out into our rivers, we will have failed.
If we cannot find answers to waste management control and if whatever over and wonderful structure that we place does not provide green open spaces left in the world so that not just human beings can breathe, but those in the bio-diversity chains of life can continue to exist, one related to the other, we will have failed.
Those are the true measures. Can we save and sustain a minimal quality of life? Can we move beyond the doomsday, the sky is falling in, and say we can accommodate a world that not only can survive but maybe can survive and make our quality of life even better, be it that quality of life is in the least developed country and simply means the quality of moving from no food to basic food? Can we develop in the world a sense of upward mobility and production and at the same time containing our consumption?
There are only two things we can count on in the world today and be sure of. We can lament them and say we wish they were not going to happen, but as the previous member just said, the population will double from 5 billion to 10 billion. We might want it otherwise but it seems inevitable.
With that doubling of population and the acceptance of market systems, pluralistic democracies and these other trends of today, can we sustain the growth, can we sustain even a minimal quality of life, can we make life better?
I would like to accept that the task is difficult, maybe improbable, but that if mankind chooses to come together in Rio and come together in that way in the world with commitment at least, there is hope and we can live in the new world.
The Environment
Let us recognize what the new world is. The new world is a world of cities. It is a world of urbanization. For years we have focused in the United Nations on the important issues of basic potable water, or rural development, of response to emergency relief and these kinds of things in an effective way.
That is not where the next century is. The next century is going to place the people of the world from those rural areas into cities. That is where the consumption will be, that is where the degradation will be and that is where your lifestyle and my lifestyle will be, even though we might desire that it should be otherwise.
In 1980 there were 1.8 billion people living in cities. By 2010 that will increase to about 3.4 billion and by 2025 it is suggested it will be around 5.5 billion. What kind of cities? Will they be the massive megacities with the rotten homeless in the central core, with the shantytown surroundings, with people drinking undrinkable water, breathing unbreathable air and sitting bumper to bumper in rotting cars on freeways for three and four hours to and from work? Need it be that way in this kind of mega-city that is evolving? Not necessarily if we can recognize this trend toward urbanization and we can begin to manage urbanization in a realistic way to improve and sustain the quality of life and to sustain cities.
One factor that really illustrates this for me is I saw a picture from space. This picture was taken of the lights of North America. My first reaction was that it was a terrible waste of energy, the lights of North America at night. Then I started to realize what it really was. It was showing us this trend, the reality that the most developed nation in the world is really a nation of growing cities that are linked by jet streams of C02, that are linked by ribbons of asphalt, ribbons of wires carrying light and electricity, ships across our oceans, submarines underneath our oceans, ocean dumping. I thought this is real. We better look to that future.
While the scientific issues of global warming are extremely critical, the one element that developed and developing countries have in common is that they are all facing the issues of urbanization. Where will people work? How will they work? What jobs will they do? How will they travel to and from those jobs?

The Environment
That is what the people in my riding care about. I live 40 minutes from downtown Vancouver. Five years ago it was 35 minutes. Now it is 40 minutes or 45 minutes or one hour. The road did not stretch any longer. We put twice as many cars on it. I wonder how we are going to feel on those same roads when the city of Vancouver grows from 1.7 million to 3 million by 2010 and there is twice as many cars.
I wonder how we are going to breathe in my valley any more than we breathe in Los Angeles in the San Bernadino. Now when we drive into work in our cars in Vancouver in the morning by eleven o'clock in the afternoon it is all blown back up the valley. We cannot see our mountains anymore. That is what it is really about.
Can we sustain the quality of air that I, you and our children are trying to breathe? Our children and your children will move to the cities and they will be in those cars. Can we create liveable regional urban areas?
I looked at this map and I used to think I came from greater Vancouver. All of a sudden I look at the map and I find out that it is not greater Vancouver I come from but a new megacity, a new urbanization area running all the way from Seattle to Vancouver.
Unfortunately, in the United States the polls show that most Americans no longer think that the most desirable place in the United States to live is Los Angeles. That is an easy one, is it not? It is another failure of urbanization. We did not build our cities so that they were liveable, so that people could find identity and place in those communities, in those megalopolises.
We must learn from that if we are to sustain the quality of life that makes everyone in the United States want to migrate to the Seattle area and everybody in Canada want to migrate to Vancouver and Victoria, that is what the polls show. However, they are going to destroy everything that we all want to move and live there for unless we have the vision to see the whole city that goes from Portland, Seattle, and Tacoma all the way up to Vancouver as the one city that it is and to treat it as such.
We have some promising signs. One of those promising signs came from the premier of the new government. He suggested a few years ago a great idea called the Georgia Basin. He said: "We should not think that
the city of Vancouver is just Vancouver. It really is the water in between all the way over to Victoria, and it is that whole strait, and even moving down toward the United States".
I am pleased to say that I spoke with him this week. I know that he is meeting with Booth Gardner, the governor of the state of Washington. They are signing accords and starting to move toward the recognition of this greater unit in probably the most wonderful place to live in the world. Can we preserve it? Can we sustain it?
If in North America, in two of the wealthiest countries of the world with the highest quality of life, we cannot demonstrate that we can preserve that quality of life there is no point in going to Rio. If we cannot do it how can a developed country that cannot even provide basic food, shelter and health care to its people provide, sustain and hope for any future or quality of life?
It is because of these concerns that all levels of government must work together-the municipal governments that plan, the regional governments that plan, the provincial governments and the state governments that provide planning and energy and the national governments with their green plans. How can we tie those green plans into the sustainable cities programs of human settlements at the United Nations of the UNDP programs, with the World Bank Development Program?
I think we can if we can work together, if we can see the objective of desirable quality lifestyles within rural urbanized areas. With that in mind I am pleased to say that we have developed what we call the Vancouver charter.
Fifty-four nations of the world gathered in March in Vancouver and said: "Yes, we see the problem of urbanization. We want the United Nations to turn its focus that way and address the problem of sustainable cities". That was the first good recommendation that came out of the Vancouver declaration.
The second good recommendation that came out of it was one that said: "Let us show the way. Let us do three major world demonstration projects. One demonstration project would be our own right at home. Let us show that we can do a world demonstration project pulling all of the jurisdictions together in the Peugot and Georgia Basins and show not only that we can sustain the quality of life but improve that quality of life".

If we can do that then let us find another city in the rapid industrialization area that has to turn the factories off at two o'clock in the afternoon and send the kids home from school to let people breathe. Let us find another one of those rapid industrializations and see if we can take contemporary technology and turn it into a renewed industrialized city that provides both quality of jobs and work and quality of life.
Let us look over at eastern Europe at the terrible gloom and doom that still remains after the Second World War, at those poor once glorious cities. Can we rehabilitate them? Can we restore them? Let us do another world demonstration project.
In Rio let us take our focus, choose a few demonstration projects and show what all this science, technology, political will and human concern can do. Global parliamentarians on habitat, human settlements, development and the environment struck that tone in the Vancouver conference.
They addressed many other urbanization issues that they have mentioned in that charter: human settlements, management, effective land use, land resource management, adequate shelter for all, integrated provision of environmental infrastructure, sustainable transport and energy systems, human resource development and capacity building, promoting human settlements, planning and management in disaster prone areas, promoting sustainable construction, and industry activities, as well as another one that was added by a far-thinking Canadian.
That far-thinking Canadian is sitting in the House tonight, the member for Ottawa West. She came to our conference of 54 parliaments, one of the largest parliamentary conferences in Canada's history, and asked: "What about the role of women in urbanization?" She wrote a special paragraph on that into the charter, into the declaration.
I commend her tonight. I thank her for her role there, and for her continuing role in that international organization that was created there.
There are many other issues that we wish to speak about with respect to human settlements. As we pushed the science in Brazil we have forgotten what we have in common, which is urbanization.
The Environment
I hope that urbanization can grow in its strength and its central theme. It was recognized in New York at the prep-com that we have not done enough to deal with how people live together, one with the other. How do we survive within that quality of environment? As I speak tonight on sustainable cities and urbanization I know I am speaking about a subject of yesterday and a subject of today, but I am talking about the subject of the future.
Canada has shown world leadership through Monique Landry, Jean Charest and others who helped us form one of the largest parliamentary non-governmental organizations of the United Nations. We are going to bring the issue of urbanization to the forefront of the United Nations.
I am very pleased as chairman of the organization to join Senator Nakanichi of Japan, the international chairman, to take these ideas to Brazil. We have a ten-minute slide show that is now being shown all over the world that illustrates these ideas. We have received support from all of the congressmen in the state of Washington for the idea of a demonstration project.
We have received support from the Government of British Columbia, from many people within the Government of Canada, from Mayor Gordon Campbell and the regional district, Mayor Bose and all of the planners on both sides of the border. Congressman John Miller has struck a parallel committee in the United States.
We are working together to show the world that we can do it, that we can double our population, that we can double our consumption within a rationalized, urbanized setting. Cities can be wonderful places to live if we have the foresight to look to their future.
I am enthusiastic about Rio. I am hopeful for Rio. I am hopeful because of the very fact that we are having this debate tonight. I hope that many members of Parliament will join our Prime Minister in a Canadian delegation, on their own or in their international NGOs. Another great Canadian parliamentary NGO, Parliamentarians for Global Action, will be there. Our environment committee chairman, the member for Rosedale, is doing such great things. There is good work from Canada.

The Environment
We have a leadership role to play there and we have a responsibility to carry out there. I look forward to being part of that team to carry these messages to the world for a better place for you, myself and our children.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have this opportunity to join in this debate on the earth summit, the UN Conference on Environment and Development, to take place next month.
I want to pay tribute to my colleague, the member for Saanich-Gulf Islands, who made a very impassioned speech earlier today on issues of environmental concern. She spoke about militarization, or demilitarization. She spoke about over-population and the crisis it is causing for our environment. She spoke about the debt crisis that the developed world finds itself in and our obligation in the developed world to deal with that in a humanitarian and environmentally sensitive manner. I know that she has a very heartfelt commitment to the issue of environmental sustainability. I want to pay tribute to the remarks she made and perhaps expand on some of the issues she raised in terms of women's agenda for the environment.
The World Women's Congress action agenda is a compilation of the work, ideas and values of over 1,500 women from all around the world, from the north, south, east and west who gathered for a conference on women and the environment last year.
These 1,500 women represent millions of women from all over the world. They are presenting recommendations to the UN as a basic guide to promote environmental and economic security.
It is important to let members of Parliament and the Canadian public know of this women's action agenda, agenda 21. Unfortunately I cannot put our entire agenda onto the record as I only have 20 minutes to speak tonight. However in that time I want to give voice to the work of these women. I will read right from their document. I quote:
We, women of many nations, cultures and creeds, of different colours and classes, have come together to voice our concern for the health of our living planet and all its interdependent life forms. . .
As caring women, we speak on behalf of those who could not be with us, the millions of women who experience daily the violence of environmental degradation, poverty, and exploitation of their work and their bodies. As long as Nature and women are abused by a so-called "free market" ideology and wrong concepts of "economic growth", there can be no environmental security. Rainforest dwellers, island peoples, and inhabitants of fragile arid zones are threatened with displacement and dispossession due to human disruption and pollution of vulnerable ecosystems. In a world that condones such practices, there lies little hope for long-term survival or peace among peoples.
We are deeply troubled by the increasing quality of life disparities between inhabitants of industrialized nations and those in so-called "developing" nations and by the growing numbers of poor within the rich countries. In all instances, women, children, minorities, and indigenous people are the chief victims.
We are outraged by the inequities among children the world over, with millions denied food, shelter, health care, education and opportunities for a full and productive life. We condemn the racism and disrespect of diversity on which this inequity feeds. . .
We will no longer tolerate the enormous role played by military establishments and industries in making the 20th century the bloodiest and most violent in all of human history. Militarism is impoverishing and maiming both the Earth and humanity. It is urgent that resources currently consumed by the military be redirected to meet the needs of people and our planet.
We believe that a healthy and sustainable environment is contingent upon world peace, respect for human rights, participatory democracy, the self-determination of peoples, respect for indigenous peoples and their lands, cultures, and traditions, and the protection of all species.
We believe that basic human rights include access to clean air and water, food, shelter, health, education, personal liberty, and freedom of information.
We come together to pledge our commitment to the empowerment of women, the central and powerful force in the search for equity between and among the peoples of the Earth and for a balance between them and the life-support systems that sustain us all.
Women are a powerful force for change. In the past two decades thousands of new women's groups have been organized in every region of the world, ranging from community based groups to international networks. Everywhere, women are catalysts and initiators of environmental activism. Yet policy-makers continue to ignore the centrality of women's roles and needs as they make Fate of the Earth decisions.

We demand our right, as half the world's population, to bring our perspectives, values, skills, and experiences into policy - making, on an equal basis with men, not only at the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development.. .but on into the 21st century.. .We appeal to all women and men to join in this call for profound and immediate transformation in human values and activities.. .Knowing that it is the number of people plus their consumption of resources plus their wastes that determine their environmental impact, we note that a person in the industrialized world has a far greater negative impact on the environment than a person living in a poor country.
Aware that the right to reproductive health and choice is a basic human right of all individuals, we point out that the World Fertility Survey estimates that there are 500 million couples who wish to plan their family size but have no access to the means to do so.
Fearful of the threat to women's lives by the HIV pandemic and recognizing that women's ability to protect themselves from AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases and to determine when and if to have children is a prerequisite for women's health, selfdetermination, and empowerment.
We condemn any attempt to deprive women of reproductive freedom or the knowledge to exercise that freedom.
We demand	women-centred,	women-managed,
comprehensive reproductive health care and family planning, including the right to prenatal care, safe and legal voluntary contraceptives and abortion, sex education, and information.
We urge governments, multilateral and donor agencies to increase investments in comprehensive reproductive health services and to include men as beneficiaries of family planning education and services. Family support services should include child care and parental leave.
We call on policy-makers to recognize that raising the economic, health, education, and social status of women are essential to ending environmental degradation.
We call for recognition of the existence of a global, environmentally induced cancer epidemic and demand removal from the environment of carcinogenic substances, which have particularly adverse effects on women and children. Particular attention in medical research and treatment should be paid to women's cancers: breast, ovarian, cervical, uterine and vaginal. Research and remedial action should also focus on the effects on health of toxic chemicals, nuclear wastes, radiation, pesticides and fertilizers.
We demand that all governments systematically alert their citizens to the danger of AIDS and provide them with the information on how to avoid contamination.
We ask the World Health Organization, the International Labour Organizations, the Food and Agriculture Organization, national governments, public health groups, corporations and unions to increase efforts to eliminate environmental occupational hazards in factories, offices and on the land.
That is a part of women's action agenda 21. There are many issues the women's action agenda touches on in great detail. It discusses specific steps for con-
The Environment
version of military resources and personnel to socially and environmentally productive rather than destructive purposes.
It recommends gender balance on all UN bodies, as well as including an equal number of women in the decision-making capacities in all governmental and non-governmental organizations at international, national and community levels. Without this there is no true democracy. There can be no democracy, no real democracy, when the majority of the world's population, women, has almost no say in world decisions.
The women's agenda points out the need for an international code of environmental ethics and accountability. It deplores the disempowerment of women in the face of technology and encourages the education and training of women in math and sciences. It recommends specific action on the issues of foreign debt and trade. It discusses women, poverty, land rights, food security, credit, bio-diversity, biotechnology, nuclear power, alternative energy and women's consumer power.
I would like to expand on the issues of poverty, over-population and reproductive choice. First I would like to state that over-consumption by the industrialized world is responsible for the vast majority of the environmental problems that we face. Poverty also leads to environmental destruction because the poor are forced to use whatever they can to stay alive.
If they have to plant crops on depleted land, cut down more trees for firewood than they can replace, or clear forests for cultivation, they will do so in order to survive. The result is shrinking forests, spreading deserts, rampant soil erosion, and even more poverty and even more hunger.
The world has experienced an unprecedented increase in population. Other speakers tonight have made mention of this. There were one billion people on the planet in the year 1830. Now there are more than four billion people. According to the Brundtland report, within the next 35 to 40 years there are likely to be twice as many people on earth consuming three times as much food and seeking four times as much energy.

The Environment
Women have an important role to play in sustainable development. Women in developing nations tend to do most of the productive work. In Africa women do 80 per cent of the agricultural work. When women have few rights and no options, they also cannot exercise environmental standards in the subsistence work that they do. Development and environmental programs are often not aimed at them, nor are they developed by the women themselves. Their literacy rate is far below that of men's. They are kept often in ignorance and have little control over their own bodies.
Women are the teachers of our children. Poverty, over-population and environmental degradation will continue indefinitely unless the status of women improves. It is unfortunate but often women are treated as simple receptacles for child bearing. Women are urged to have more children as their duty to their husbands and their duty to their country. No one takes the woman's own needs into account. Unwanted pregnancy does not lead to stronger, more stable countries. In fact the opposite is true.
When children are wanted, they are loved and they are cherished. When children have a good chance of survival, women do not feel the need to have as many as possible. When economic options exist for women, they do not need to rely on large numbers of children to support them in their old age.
Over-population and poverty are interrelated. Poverty, the lack of access to family planning and the low status of women cause over-population, and over-population reinforces poverty. Family planning alone is not enough. Where men decide how many children wives should have, where women are forced by the community to bear children, where poverty and lack of health care mean that only a few children will survive, women do have many children.
Family planning resources must be accompanied by the right of women to decide the number and the spacing of their children without coercion. Better health care for mothers, infants and children so that the children who are born do survive is essential in keeping population manageable. Over-population is a tax on our resources and can only be slowed with the distribution of resources.
There is more than an environmental consideration here. There is a very sad human one. In Latin America there are an estimated 40 million children who live on the streets. That is more than the entire population of Canada. The World Watch Institute reports that reproductive problems are the leading killer of women of child bearing age throughout the developing world. At least one million women die each year and more than a hundred million suffer disabling illnesses from childbirth, illegal abortion and pregnancy complications. "A deadly combination of high birth rate and little or no access to contraception, safe abortion, and maternal care lies behind these numbers", the report said.
The report's author stated that the annual number of deaths due to reproductive causes would double by the end of the decade without a reordering of priorities toward health care and family planning.
Family planning must give people information and choice and must be accompanied by environmentally friendly economic development and resources to improve the health, the literacy and the status of women.
Sterilization and birth control should never be forced, but everyone should have access to family planning so they can determine for themselves the number and the spacing of their children.
Throughout history the biological imperative for human survival has been to reproduce as much as possible. Now that situation has reversed itself. Over-population is a threat to our common survival and is particularly detrimental to developing nations.
Our world's resources are being squandered. We overconsume in the industrialized world and we do not share our resources. World governments are not yet serious about the environment and equality. First, we must care for our resources and ensure that we do not harm the environment or each other. Second, we must distribute those resources.
As long as the developing world is poor leading to over-population and economic development contrary to environmental goals, the world's environment will suffer. We will all suffer. As long as the industrialized world over-consumes the world environment will suffer. We are all in this together. Everyone is affected.

Poverty is not just something that happens in developing nations. Aboriginal people in Canada suffer over-proportionately from poverty. Some 60 per cent of Canada's poor are women. We have countless homeless people, and one in ten Canadians is now unemployed. Lack of respect for the environment exists right here in Canada. Not all Canadians have access yet today to safe and effective contraception and family planning information, not even here in Canada.
The women's action agenda pledges to act in solidarity with women around the world to change policies responsible for economic, social and political inequities and to restore health to our planet.
Poor women means poor children. It means a cycle of poverty. Environmental degradation, disease and instability will continue throughout every generation until we address the status of women issues.
Sadly Canada is not in a leadership position on the status of women according to the UN human development report. We are one of the best countries in the world in which to live, the report says, except for women. Canada must take action within its own borders and internationally on the issues I have mentioned if we are to survive, if our planet is to survive.
Finally I want to bring to the attention of the House that the Population Institute has produced a priority declaration. In the preamble it states: "World population currently at 5.4 billion burgeons by more than 95 million each year. It is expected that the annual net increase will reach 100 million by the middle of this decade. Three billion people, an amount equal to the entire population in the world in 1960, will reach their reproductive years within the next generation". In this declaration they call on all nations to redouble their support to the UN population fund.
I would like to call on my colleagues and other members of Parliament who are here tonight to join with me in signing this declaration on world population.

speakeroldname: Mr. Lee Clark (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of the Environment):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of the Environment
subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, congratulations to you on the responsibilities you have accepted, even if it be only for a moment.
In the absence of the Minister of Forestry, I would like to spend a few moments this evening talking
The Environment
about the importance of forests in the global community, here in Canada, and certainly to the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development which will be occurring in Rio in just a few weeks time.
I would like to do that because forests are certainly our most bountiful and versatile renewable resource. They are a major source of economic activity and employment in many countries around the world. Their products are environmentally friendly, biodegradable and often recyclable.
The environmental role of forests is well recognized. Forests are a provider of wildlife habitat and they are indispensable to soil and water conservation and in local and regional climatic stability. More recently their significant global carbon, hydrological and climatic cycles is receiving increased world-wide attention.
The importance of forests in maintaining biodiversity for the production of food, fibre and pharmaceuticals is gaining in prominence and recognition.
From a societal perspective, forests are important for the maintenance of social and cultural diversity, particularly for people living in and around them. In some cases entire communities depend upon forests for their survival.
Recent studies show that world-wide the area of degraded land is equal to the total land base of China and India combined. The rehabilitation of such land would constitute an important contribution to sustainable development of the world's forests.
The use of forests in developed countries has shifted with changing social and economic needs and evolving technological capacities. In pre-agricultural society, forests served as a major source of food, fibre, fuel and shelter. Subsequently large tracts of forest land were harvested and cleared to meet the perceived need for economic development and capital generation and to create arable agricultural land in order to produce the necessary food for an expanding population.
However, this same sequence of events which has been experienced by developing countries is being repeated in many developing countries and at a considerably faster rate and with increasingly complex technologies.

The Environment
At the same time the effects of tropical boreal and temperate forests on the environment are receiving world-wide attention, particularly in developed countries.
There is now greater recognition of the need to shift our approach to forestry from sustained yield, which is aimed at maintaining an annual flow of wood to sustainable development, which takes into account both wood production and environmental outputs and values such wildlife habitat and soil and water conservation. Attaining this shift in the outputs and values would involve an associated shift from forest management to forest ecosystem management.
During the past two decades the scale, scope and complexity of environmental issues has been widening from local and national to regional and global levels. Within this broadened context, forest related economic environmental issues have emerged as a priority on the agenda of world leaders and this has happened for several reasons.
It has happened because of the need to satisfy the growing demand for forest products as the result of a rapidly growing world population. It has happened as a result of the need to facilitate international trade in forest products.
To address the issue of constantly shrinking forest cover and the consequence of soil erosion and environmental and watershed degradation, including loss, of course, of wildlife habitat.
It has happened because of the need to protect forests world-wide because of the increasing concentration of greenhouse gases and the impact of forests on the environment regarding global carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, hydrological and climatic cycles. It has happened because of the need to protect and conserve forests for the biodiversity and heritage values and to counteract forest soil acidification and forest decline associated with acid rain.
It has also happened because of the need to protect forests from negative impacts of anticipated global warming. As a result, forest harvesting and deforestation are exceedingly important in the minds of many people. It is important to understand that neither of these two in themselves are the main cause of global warming nor, on the other hand, would reforestation and afforestation be the principal solutions.
However, the role of forests in the global carbon cycle is now receiving special and well deserved world-wide attention. Regarding this particular issue, it is important in my mind to note that the right of sovereign nations to conserve, manage and utilize forest reserves within their jurisdiction is unquestioned and must continue to be recognized universally. However, with the recognition of sovereignty follows the responsibility to consult and to co-operate with other nations on global and transboundary levels.
This also involves a responsibility to maintain and to develop the productive capacity and ecological diversity of our land, which is to be inherited by future generations.
In an increasingly interconnected and interdependent world, global problems require collective action and co-operation. Consequently, through mutual agreement, financial and technical assistance, and investment and trade arrangements, nations both individually and collectively are searching for an appropriate framework to co-operate in the conservation, management and utilization of forests at both the regional and global levels.
As a result, sustainable development of forests is the most pressing challenge facing forest managers and forest policy makers today.
Before specifically discussing the UNCED forestry agenda, I think it is worth while to stop for a moment and to outline, albeit briefly, the importance of forests to Canada and to Canadians. I think that is important because, as you know Mr. Speaker, Canada's forests cover over half of our territory and represent some 10 per cent of the world's forest cover.
Forests simultaneously provide a wide range of economic and environmental benefits. The forest and our relationship with it is an integral part of Canadian history and our social-cultural identity.
Canada, in fact, has been and is a forest nation and the future of our forests, therefore, should be of concern to all Canadians. Economically the forest products sector is Canada's largest industry. It employs over 800,000 Canadians, both directly and indirectly.
In 1990 alone it generated over $50 billion in economic activity. As you know, Mr. Speaker, there are over 350 single industry towns in Canada which are dependent on forestry. In fact Canada is the world's largest exporter of forest products. Annually forestry contributes more to the country's net balance of trade than the net export earnings of fishing, agriculture, energy and mining combined.

In addition, our forests are an essential component of our multi-billion dollar tourism and recreational industry. In fact, this undoubtedly will be a growing industry because of the interest throughout the world in what is generally ecotourism.
Environmentally, Canada's forests form a critical component of our life support system. Our forests preserve and purify our fresh water supplies, conserve the soil, reduce flooding and landslides, and provide wildlife habitat, as I said earlier. Our forests provide life-giving oxygen, moderate the climate and help clean the air.
As forests grow they absorb carbon dioxide, the greenhouse gas that contributes to global warming. They provide natural and wilderness areas for the cultural, spiritual and recreational benefit of Canadians.
Since time immemorial forests have sustained the cultural, spiritual and economic needs of many of Canada's aboriginal peoples.
A number of existing and planned international agreements, include a forest related component such as the conventions on climate change and biodiversity. However, from a forestry perspective, this approach is still fragmented. Consequently, Canada has assumed a leadership role in calling for a comprehensive and cohesive approach on a global basis to address forest-related issues and opportunities.
In July 1990 the G-7 leaders at the Houston economic summit called for a global agreement on forests. Since then, many countries have actively supported the concept, with Canada continuing to demonstrate leadership on the issue.
At the first UNCED prep-com which occurred in Nairobi, Canada drew attention to the G-7 declaration and proposed that UNCED study the conservation and sustainable development of forests rather than the much narrower topic of deforestation, which had been originally considered.
This idea was accepted and led to a decision at the second prep-com to develop a non-legally binding "authoritative statement of principles" for the management, conservation and sustainable development of all the world's forests.
The concept of an agreement on principles for forests, leading to a global forest convention, was confirmed by the G-7 summit meeting in London just
The Environment
a year ago, last July. Consequently Canada attaches great importance to the progress being made on forest issues during the UNCED preparatory process.
Moreover, we look forward to the guiding principles being endorsed by world leaders at Brazil in just a few weeks time. Hopefully, a signed authoritative statement will become the basis for the eventual negotiation of a legally binding and comprehensive convention on forests, one that would balance and accommodate both the economic and environmental dimension of forests, while making appropriate linkages with the climate change and biodiversity conventions.
Forestry Canada's role in the interdepartmental mechanisms dealing with UNCED is being complemented by an extensive consultative process designed to ensure that all major Canadian forestry stakeholders have the opportunity to present their views prior to seeking cabinet approval of the Canadian negotiating position.
The round of formal consultations which were held involved a full range of representatives from provincial and territorial governments, industry, labour, environmental non-governmental organizations, professional associations, small woodlot owners, aboriginal groups and as well, the academic community.
As we approach Rio, there is a high degree of consensus and supporting Canada for the development endorsement of meaningful guidance and principles. There is as well a commitment to negotiate a forest convention, including internationally agreed criteria for sustainable forest management. This strong Canadian consensus has been carefully built over the last 18 months.
Furthermore, our international activities have been undertaken in concert with a number of major domestic initiatives. These include the establishment of the Department of Forestry itself in 1989 which has a legislative mandate to promote sustainable development. It includes a national forest strategy announced in March 1992 entitled "Sustainable Forests: A Canadian Commitment" which expresses the views of all of the Canadian stakeholders and it includes as well forest related initiatives in the green plan and federal-provincial forest resource development agreements.

The Environment
It is the government's intention at the upcoming meetings in Rio to actively seek a commitment to negotiate an international convention on forests. We will also actively seek agreement on a set of guiding principles for forests, with the goal of balancing economic opportunities and environmental responsibilities at both the national and global levels.
Forests are a precious national and global resource which must be developed in a sustainable manner for the benefit of present and future generations. In Canada, we are addressing our domestic forestry opportunities with major initiatives in support of sustainable development. Internationally, global challenges will require global solutions.
We believe that the Rio earth summit is indeed an important step in establishing a fragile balance between the human need for economic development and the necessity to meet this need in harmony with our natural environment.
We look forward to Rio with the understanding that it is an important step forward and indeed it will be but a step in an ongoing process. I do believe that those who have special responsibility for the management of forestry and forests in Canada whether it be at the ministerial or other level have indeed been acting in a co-operative and constructive manner toward achieving that objective.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is a privilege to rise and talk about the earth summit. We tend to think of summits as being called to discuss how to end a war or how to expand trade or international economies. But this is the earth summit and it is without doubt the most important, the most urgent summit ever held in history.
It is a question of more than our health although certainly the health of individuals world-wide is at stake. What is at stake in this earth summit is nothing less than the survival of life on this planet. It is the survival of the atmosphere of the globe which sustains life. It is the survival of the soil and everything that comes from it. It is the survival of the water systems of the globe. It is the survival of everything that makes life, not good, but possible.
We have been doing such irreparable damage to our environment and to our globe that we risk being
unable to even survive. That risk is not a century from now or a millennium from now, it is a matter of years from now. Therefore the time for action is now.
When the Brundtland commission came out with the report called Our Common Future, it certainly revolutionized talks from politicians at least. For some it revolutionized thinking about the environment and the economy. To date, it has failed to revolutionize action in the way that is necessary if we are to stem the terrible damage that has been done largely in the northern half of this world and largely by those of us who enjoy the greatest of the benefits of the resources of this earth.
We have talked about the sustainable development as meaning linking care for the environment and economic development. What we usually end up talking about are trade-offs. Can we afford to protect the environment? Translate that question and it is can we afford to live? Can we afford to survive? What is life worth? What is the survival of all life worth? We have failed miserably to recognize that what we have to do is integrate what we do economically with what we do to the environment and for the environment. Without trees there is no forest industry. Without fish there is no fishing industry. Without oil there is no energy. In every domain of our economy, without natural resources there is no prosperity and there is no quality of life.
We have tended to ignore the fact that sustainable development is a three-legged stool, not a twolegged stool. In addition to economy and environment, there is a link called equity. Because we have ignored that third aspect of sustainable development, we have created a situation in which the very security of our world is threatened, in which one billion people live in poverty, under nourished and in danger of starvation. We have created a dichotomy between the industrialized so-called developed countries of the world and those that are euphemistically called developing.
What we can see in the next 40 years is a doubling of the population of the world and an increase by six times in energy consumption if the developing countries follow the same pattern of lifestyle as we have followed. We know that will lead to a global climate change of catastrophic proportions.

We have the issue of equity between the north and the south, but we also have the very important issue of equity between people. As the speaker before me has said, equity for women is a fundamental building block if we are to save our environment and save our world. Of the one billion who live in poverty, most are women. Forty thousand children a day still die for lack of clean water. How can we say that in a world that is so rich? We allow it to go on day after day while we spend money on the instruments of death instead of providing for life.
Barely a month ago I was at a conference in Vancouver as part of the Globe 92 conference on the environment. It was focused on habitat and on our cities and on our communities, rural and urban. When we got to that conference we had a declaration there, but very quickly the women got together and said this declaration about communities is all about business and buildings. It is not about people. We sat down, as the member for Fraser Valley West has said, and worked hard to change that declaration, not to take out what was there, but to add the voices of women which complete the humanity of our statements and our actions.
What the women wanted to add to that declaration had to do with how are the elderly cared for, how are the disabled cared for, how do cities provide green spaces and play spaces for children, how do we integrate our home and our work. What the women wanted to deal with was clean water, access to fuel, access to food; all the fundamentals of life.
Women talked about cities and children. We think we had a problem in Los Angeles in the last week. We think we have had a problem in Toronto in the last few days. What kind of problem do we think we are building up in this world when 40 million children around the world are homeless, literally living on the streets of cities with no other value except survival, often from the age of two?
What kind of a population do we think we are raising in this world in which nobody is caring for children, in which they are not caring for each other? How do we expect them to care for us and our cities or for our values?
We have seen a very small symptom in our own continent in the last few days of what we can expect
The Environment
mega-times greater in the cities of the world if we do not act quickly to look after our children. We pay no attention to the economic value of the work of women.
When men lay a pipe in a village to bring water, that has economic value. When women, as many around the world do, work four and five hours a day to carry water to their homes, their families and their children, that has no economic value. Women can spend as many hours every day seeking fuel to cook for their families and we know that when we free the time of women from those essential tasks of getting fuel, food and water, immediately we improve the condition of their children. We improve the nutrition of their children. We improve the education of their children.
Two thirds of those who are illiterate in this world are women, women raising the next generation. We are concerned about over-population and we want to impose on the developing countries some kinds of limits on their population growth. It is really easy.
The single most effective way to reduce population growth is to improve the education of women. It operates internationally. The greater the education of women, the lower the birth rate. Women are the key decision makers and innovators in the communities. They are the ones who relate most closely to the natural environment. It is a source of food. It is a source of medicine. It is a source of fuel to provide for their families. Around the world women and their children are the victims of abuse of economic activity.
I listened in Vancouver to women from Peru talk about the economic terrorism by the drug trade against women in the small villages where they and their children are coerced into being part of the drug trade and growing the coca. When the forces of the world converge on them to destroy the coca plants, what they also do is destroy the fields that are growing the food.
I heard from them about the abuse of children internationally because we have the economic power to travel anywhere in the world we want to and do whatever we want to do to children.
I heard about the international trade in children. Women have to be given access to resources, access to the decision making process, access to the implementation policies and full and equal participation or our full humanity is not involved in solving the tremendous problems we have created.

The Environment
The third preparatory conference for the earth summit made it very clear that the concerns of women have to be integrated in every single aspect of all the programs, all the policies and all the international conventions being discussed at the earth summit. This has not yet happened.
Canada is first in the world as the best place in the world to live, but not for women. We are number one, but not for women. We drop to number eight and I have to repeat that. When we include the status of women, Canada is the eighth country in the world.
I see the danger of the increasing inequity as I see the globalization of trade and a new economic colonialism that can go anywhere, wherever the environmental standards are lowest, wherever people are poorest and most desperate, and exploit both the human and natural resources of the world.
Canadians are concerned about their environment. They say, on the other hand, that they want to see cuts in foreign aid. I want to tell Canadians that the only way we can improve the environment is to improve the economic situation of the poorest countries and the poorest peoples in the world. We are now taking $50 billion more as the wealthiest countries in the world out of the poorest countries of the world. We are not putting into the poor countries. We are taking from them.
These are some of the things that the women I have spoken to are concerned about. If protecting bio-diversity means protecting the plants that they have relied on for generations to heal their children so that international companies can come in and take those plants and turn them into expensive patent medicines and sell them back into the country from which they took those plant products at a price that the women can no longer afford to heal their children, what have those women gained, what have those children gained, what have those communities gained?
What does a community in a poor country gain when we import cotton and return it in the form of shirts and clothing that the people in that country cannot afford to buy? A few people in the wealthy countries may have become wealthier but a lot of people have become poorer.
We have to say that it is not good enough to wait for somebody else. Leadership is not huddling in the middle of a pack and shuffling forward as the pack shuffles forward. That is the sign of somebody just coming into adolescence and saying, "I cannot do anything different than anybody else. I might stand out and I may not be able to cope with it". Leadership means knowing what needs to be done and doing it and setting the kind of example that other people will want to follow.
We cannot say to the developing country: "Cut your demand for energy. Do not hope to have refrigerators and do not hope to have your homes comfortable and do not hope to have what we in the north have because you will damage the environment". How can we tell somebody in Africa not to have eight children when every one of our children takes 80 times the energy and does 80 times the damage to the environment of any one of their children?
This is true in a number of areas. We talk about being concerned. We know that if all the ozone destroying substances in the world were released overnight, the ozone would be gone and life on this earth would end. We continue to produce and we continue to use and we continue to expand our use of ozone. We know that the climate of our world is threatened and yet we fail to set clear targets and timetables for cutting or for even stabilizing the climate change gases that we are putting into the atmosphere. We know that the world's water supply is under threat and yet we pass regulations in Canada that still allow 400,000 tonnes a year of organic chlorines and poisonous substances to flow freely into our rivers and lakes. What kind of responsibility is that? How can we possibly then stand up on the world stage and claim to be leaders?
Canada must make it clear that we will not accept wishy-washy statements. It is too late for that. We need clear targets and timetables. We need concrete objectives. We need internationally binding conventions, not statements. We have to make it clear, if we want to persuade the rest of the world, that this is what is needed, that is what we are prepared to do because that is what we believe is not only right, but is necessary for survival.

The key issue for Canada has to become, not what the world will do, but what we will do. We simply cannot sit back and wait for somebody else to go first. Somebody has to go first. The world expects it to be Canada and I hope it will be.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am very pleased, as have members on all sides of the House, to participate in this debate and also to follow one of my colleagues who has been an active member of the environment committee on which we both work.
As she and virtually all those who have spoken in this debate have said the issues at stake one can only describe them as having global proportions.
The preparations for this conference have gone on now for the better part of two years. I know that several people have said something about my involvement or participation in this process which has been very modest in comparison to those who have played a major role, particularly at the official level, and those who have followed the process leading up to the earth summit who have represented many of the independent sectors.
It is not often that one has an opportunity in advance of a conference to take note of some of the important work that has been done and that we hope will result in a significant measure of success in a little over a month's time.
I want to take the opportunity this evening because it might not come easily again to mention two things. First of all, extraordinary collaboration has existed among a variety of professional people from a number of federal government departments and from a large range of the public sector.
I want to even go beyond that, and this is about the most risky thing anyone can do, to mention a few names of people who have made a significant contribution already. They have worked in the shadows for the last two years to prepare this event.
My colleague from Ottawa said a moment ago: "It will be important for Canada and Canadians to take a leading role". Well I think I can confirm to this stage that Canadians have done just that.
The most symbolic aspect of that of course is Maurice Strong who is doing something that in its own way
The Environment
is truly historic. Having been the secretary general of the first conference on the environment 20 years ago at Stockholm, he is repeating that effort with an even larger conference this time, representing not only issues of environment 20 years later but the whole of the development agenda as well. That is truly something of Herculean proportions.
Very briefly though I want to recognize the fact that there have been a number of Canadian officials in the first instance beginning with the head of the Canadian delegation, Ambassador John Bell, supported by people like Vic Buxton. Ambassador Arthur Campeau has worked actively to provide leadership to this process and has recently been designated as the Prime Minister's personal representative for the earth summit. As well, there are people like the Assistant Deputy Minister of Forests, Dr. Maini, Serge April, Bob Apple-baum, George Greene, Michael Small, Janice Kostash, Barbara Brown, Louise Cote, and Tim Leah, and permanent Canadian diplomats such as John Sloan, David Malone, and Alexandra Bezerechi.
These are just some of the key people on the government side. I could have also mentioned the outstanding collaboration of representatives of the NGO sector, Johannah Bernstein, Peter Padbury, Geoffrey Grenville-Wood, and people from specially designated areas like Dan Smith from the Indigenous People and Miriam Wyman and a host of others.
I will not mention any more names but it was simply to give the idea that there are a lot of people who have been involved over the last two years to make this earth summit a successful venture, not just for Canadians I might add but for the whole of the human community. That is no small undertaking.
One of the things I wanted to say at the outset at this stage in the proceedings for those who have been following this somewhat closely there is a tendency even before the meetings in Rio to say that we have reached the point of exhaustion. Can we do anything more?
There have been four long preparatory committee meetings. The first one was in Nairobi almost two years ago. The second and third meetings took place in Geneva over the course of the last year. The final meeting concluded just a few weeks ago in New York.

The Environment
Each one of those meetings went on for a month and involved non-stop negotiating sessions, thousands of pages of documents that were constantly being amended and revised, late night sessions, early morning sessions, sometimes all night sessions, in order to try and bring together two agendas that are absolutely unique to our period of human history.
Before the 1950s it would have been virtually impossible to have a discussion anywhere on this planet about international development. By and large, it just did not exist. Until the meetings in Colombo and the beginnings of the Colombo plan and the work of the Commonwealth and the establishment of government departments on international development in the 1950s and 1960s, there was no such thing as an international development approach.
There might have been organizations of goodwill and good works. One can think of the international committee of the Red Cross, the YMCA, church and religious organizations which have existed in some cases for many centuries but to have governments dedicated to carrying out consistent, coherent, longterm programs of international development was really a phenomenon occurring after World War II.
Of course, in some ways it may have peaked in the 1970s. Certainly, in some ways we have been struggling over the last 20 years to try and recapture some of the momentum that was very clearly there at the time of and after the Pearson commission which made its first major program of development recommendations for the international community.
Somewhat more recently beginning in the 1960s certainly with the landmark publication of Rachel Carson's book Silent Spring, we have had the establishment first of domestic departments of environment in the late 1960s and early 1970s. Of course in 1972 in Stockholm the first world conference on the environment was held. From that the first major United Nations agency for environmental protection was established in Nairobi.
It is fair to say that we have seen both of these phenomena on parallel tracks. Some of us have even been travelling in those parallel tracks and sometimes, to state the obvious, parallel tracks never meet.
We have had those who have been concerned with development activities chugging along in their direction and having some success some days, little success on others.
Then in the course of the last two decades we have had those who have been concerned about matters having to do with environmental protection, with some of the megaproblems of pollution, whether it was the pollution of the earth's oceans, which cover two-thirds of the globe's surface, whether it was concern for what was happening to our atmosphere or our loss of arable land, or whether it was simply a general mix of all these things, especially for the world that is rapidly moving into urban and sometimes somewhat inhospitable surroundings.
About five years ago we had a commission that was established by the United Nations which decided to take a look at these two phenomena and see if they could somehow be brought together.
We had the publication of the Brundtland report and in my view the unique proposal that no longer should we try to deal with environment matters and development matters as separate agenda items. We should bring them together as a single issue because as I am sure has been said today and I have said many times now, these are opposite sides of the same reality.
That is not easy. You can say it. You can think about it. But to try and change in some cases half a century of activity in a very short space of time-and I regard a year or two as a short space of time-that is not easy.
Having observed at fairly close range during the last two years the preparations that have gone into the earth summit, the dedication and the insight, it is sufficiently important to say that even at this stage without knowing if anything more will be decided at Rio, that Rio will be an important watershed in human history.
It will no longer be possible in my view to be able to say we are going to deal with this as primarily a matter of development, or we are going to deal with that as primarily a matter of environment, and later on we will think about the other thing when it is appropriate.
I just do not think it will be possible to do that and I know, even as recently as this week, we had officials from the World Bank meeting with members of Parliament in Ottawa telling us that within 10 days they will publish their human development report for 1992 on the subject of environment and economics. The two are inextricably linked.

It is for that reason that we can regard this even as we anticipate it as an historic event.
Now what are some of the matters that will need to be looked at more closely? In anticipation of the earth summit three conventions have been actively negotiated.
The first convention had to do with the matter of biological diversity. It is well known that in the kind of rapid changes that are taking place on our planet we are losing the species of biological diversity at an incredibly advancing rate, disturbingly so. It is important sooner rather than later that we begin to provide a way in which the process of deterioration which has gone on throughout the whole of our ecosystem can be arrested.
We cannot say at this stage how much success we are going to make with that particular convention. But if I were a betting person, I would say that that convention has somewhat more hope of success at this point in time for this earth summit than any of the others that are currently being negotiated.
The second one is one that will not be a convention at all because there have been enormous difficulties between rich and poor countries in trying to come to an agreement. That is the hope for a forest convention.
We in this country, where we have 10 per cent of the earth's forests, are particularly concerned about having a convention that has some real meaning to it in terms of respecting and recognizing the importance both of diversity and the replenishment aspects of our forest situation.
It is fair to say that there are many anxieties and fears in Third World countries, particularly in southeast Asia, that a forest convention at this stage would benefit the rich countries and greatly weaken and endanger poor countries. We may have a set of forest principles but beyond that it is not very likely.
The third matter and the one that has concerned a number of members of this House, in particular the environment committee for well over a year, has been the matter of a convention on climate change, on global warming.
The Environment
This has been extremely difficult because nothing so much goes to the heart of industrialized countries than their heavy dependence on fossil fuels as well as the threats that may exist for developing countries that hope to go through some similar processes of development as changes that might take place with respect to activities emitting carbon dioxide, the 50 per cent critical aspect of greenhouse gas emissions.
There are negotiations which I understand may have concluded even on the last day in New York that may have arrived at some kind of convention, though there are suggestions that perhaps the convention that will be agreed to at this stage will not have much by way of specifics in terms of achieving any real reduction in greenhouse gas emissions in the near future.
Beyond those three conventions, there is a real attempt in the context of this UN process to try to put down an action plan. I am sure it has already been referred to today in this debate but perhaps the most interesting and imaginative aspect of this UN conference is that it would produce an action plan called agenda 21, an agenda for the 21st century, which would contain a whole series of activities, a whole series of commitments, a whole series of strategies that would make the fine rhetoric and the discussions and the intentions of this particular earth summit have some real meaning.
I just received in the last day or two in my office on a computer disk the document agenda 21 and I have not yet printed it out because I am told it is 800 pages long. That will give all members a realization of how complex this whole program is.
I want to add one further thought because I believe there are a number of items that have not been touched upon clearly in the process so far. One of them is the need for more democratic participation in the decision-making around these crucial issues.
I was pleased to chair in New York about a month ago a meeting of parliamentarians that was brought together by Parliamentarians for Global Action. This was a group of parliamentarians who were there at the same time as the fourth prep-com representing more than 20 countries, north and south, east and west, Asia, Africa, Europe and Latin America.

The Environment
What perhaps was most interesting about it was that it was almost the exact mirror of our globe. A quarter of the delegates came from developed countries. Three-quarters came from developing or underdeveloped countries. Elere is the most interesting part. More than half the parliamentarians there were women.
We discussed two items over two days. One of them had to do with financial resources. In my view, the single most critical issue that will need to be resolved at the earth summit is: Can there be a new global bargain? Will there be a commitment to make the kind of expenditures necessary in order to make significant changes? If there was one singular failure out of the meetings in Stockholm 20 years ago, it was that in spite of the Stockholm declaration, in spite of all the fine language and the establishment of UNEP, no significant expenditures were put on the table then or in the 20 years since to make environmental protection truly a priority.
This time around Maurice Strong and his colleagues have learned something. They have already started talking about sums of money that for some of us may seem rather astronomical. The price tag for the package in Agenda 21 can be anywhere, depending on how it is calculated, from $125 billion up to $600 billion. People may shake their heads. I noticed you shaking your head, Mr. Speaker. People are saying: "How can we possibly meet that, given all the national deficits and national debts we are struggling with?" I ask members to think for a moment.
During the course of the last half century virtually, as we have concerned ourselves with issues of national security, and you know this well from your own career, Mr. Speaker, we have been prepared to spend, not $10 billion, not $100 billion, not a trillion dollars, but trillions and trillions of dollars over the course of many decades to effect some kind of national protection and national security.
What I am suggesting and what colleagues with UNCED are suggesting is that only a small part of that would be necessary to make a dramatic difference in the outcome of the UNCED agenda. Whether it is $125 billion or $500 billion, it will be a small price to pay in terms of the human agony that currently exists for the millions of the world's poor who are currently experiencing drastic and dire poverty or for all of us, and our children particularly, who will face the environmental consequences of our failing to act in this UNCED process.
We said at this conference that I participated in that there were a number of actions we could take with respect to adequate financial resources to make UNCED a success. I will not read the details but I would invite members, if they wish, to get a copy of this document from my office.
The other matter we addressed which, in my view, is equally important and particularly by this group of parliamentarians, more than 50 per cent of whom are women, was that unless women were front and centre in the whole process-I have heard several members in this debate today talking about this-then we can forget the significant human community based, local, world-wide impact of the UNCED decision. All the money in the world will be meaningless unless women are involved at every level of the UNCED process. We have said this in our document, in the consultation, in the planning, in the participation, in the benefits.
It is well know that in most rural societies, particularly through Africa, Asia and Latin America, that women are the chief bread winners. We may regard the economic importance of males in Europe and North America, but in my experience in Africa in the basic industries, it is women who are going to provide and make the difference. If they are not being recognized in a way that makes their contribution significant as we attempt to create a new set of norms, a new set of standards, then we will miss the boat almost entirely.
I know my time is just about exhausted. I have a couple of minutes left. I do not want to trespass on your good nature, Sir, or on the House but I do want to repeat in conclusion that I think this debate we are having today is one of the most important we could have in this Chamber. I do want to say as well that both at Stockholm and certainly at Rio, Canada has already played a major leadership role. That puts us, perhaps, in a bit of a spotlight.
While Canadians like to think of themselves as playing a leadership role, they sometimes become a little bit uncomfortable if they are little too far out in front. I want to assure and encourage all my colleagues not to flinch, not to back off at this time because within a month we will have the opportunity to make some of the most important achievements for humanity than we have been able to make for a very long time.

I trust that all of us together will support the actions of the government representatives and of the NGOs and the independent sector which will be there to provide leadership on Canada's behalf.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is indeed a pleasure to take part in this special debate on the United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development. I am pleased that you are in the Chair, Mr. Speaker, listening to this important debate.
A lot has been said today about the UNCED conference. A lot has been said prior to today's debates, and a lot will be said after the conference. I asked myself how much of what we said here in the House today will actually be implemented, how much we say here today is actually being listened to.
I would like to take a little different approach on this topic and share with the viewers and the people in the Chamber one concept that if implemented will change the direction of this planet toward a sustainable development environment. If it is not implemented, 10 years from now we will be having similar debates and the planet will be going further and further downhill instead of being cleaned up.
But to do that I think the people attending the Rio conference will have to change their thinking from two-dimensional thinking to multi-dimensional thinking or at least three-dimensional thinking. If the people continue in their two-dimensional thinking the planet will not change. It will continue to be polluted. The approaches are going to have to be holistic approaches to any recommendations made at this conference.
