The one concept that I would like to share with the House is the idea of elevated bicycle expressway systems for large cities. The concept of a bicycle expressway system was developed by Joseph Adler, an engineer from Toronto who is an enthusiastic cyclist, a professional engineer and a resident of Toronto. These three assets brought him to the idea of improving, in a radical, engineered way, cycling as a means of mass transportation and recreation in large cities.
The bicycle expressway system represents an additional transportation facility provided exclusively for
The Environment
bicycles and the servicing of large city areas. Its purpose would be to create the conditions and to give all residents the choice of replacing the use of a car by the use of a bike in most of their daily trips within the city limits and to create a convenience for everybody who would be willing to use a bike. As we know, the car is one of the greatest polluters on this planet.
We talked about different modes of transportation. We were talking about a high speed railway system corridor from Windsor to Quebec City. That is an excellent idea, but if we just take the people who are using buses and move them on to trains that is not going to solve the problem. But if we can take the people out of the cars between Windsor, Toronto, Ottawa, Montreal and Quebec and put them on a high speed electric train, then yes we are working toward sustainable development.
My concept is to take the people out of their cars in the big cities and put them on bicycles. That can only be done if we have a bicycle expressway system that includes a network of elevated, covered, level or downhill bicycle expressways accessible from the street level by escalators or ramps, provided in numerous locations in all of the large city areas.
The basic philosophy of this concept is that all expressways on all their length are elevated at a minimum of five metres above street level, covered with transparent, sun-reflecting material and at level or with downhill slopes. Conceived in this way, the bicycle expressway system provides complete separation from car and pedestrian traffic and therefore complete safety, full protection against bad weather year round and eliminates the need of climbing the differences in elevation between any two points in the city.
There is no intersection at the same level between bike expressways running north-south with those running east-west. They will be interconnected by ramps and escalators. In these conditions, no stop signs or stop lights are necessary, and the non-stop bicycle ride with maximum speed will be possible.
According to engineer Joseph Adler, using the expressway system, the bicycle will become the safest, the cheapest, the healthiest and the fastest means of urban transportation, very easy, pleasant and convenient for most of the city residents.

The Environment
Imagine the amount of money that we would save in health bills alone if we could shift even 10 per cent of the population from cars on to bicycles. Imagine how fit these people will be going to work by bike, returning home by bike. We will write off many of the health bills.
Imagine how many whiplash cases we have in this country from car accidents and how much money is spent on the treatment of simple whiplashes. A lot of these accidents and injuries to people would be eliminated. The proposed system will create the opportunity for a tremendous increase in general fitness, great energy and money saving, and a dramatic reduction in the rate of traffic accidents, noise and air pollution. The cost of the system can be recuperated in a few years according to- engineer Joseph Adler.
Summarizing the features of such an expressway, first of all, it has to be elevated at close to five metres above street level. Any interference with streets, motorized or pedestrian traffic is eliminated leading to a completely safe system. The system would have to be covered with transparent, sun-reflecting material and full protection against bad weather year round, be it cold, rain, snow, sleet, wind, sun or heat.
The system would have to be at a level or downhill approach. There would be no more streets with long slopes to peddle up. There would be no more sweating. It would be a faster ride. Many people will not take a bike to work today because they work up a sweat, there is no shower at work so they hop in the car instead.
With this system of not having to peddle uphill, we would not even work up a sweat. Many people are shocked with that concept. How can you have a system where you never peddle uphill? Very simple. We all know of escalators. Where there is a slope, you provide an escalator, you get to the level of the city and then you just peddle on level or downhill.
In such a system the expressways do not interfere one with another at the same level. At intersections, they are interconnected by ramps and escalators. There are no stop lights or stop signs. It is direct, non-stop bike riding between any two points in the system. We have a very easy, safe, pleasant and fast riding system.
If it is such a great system, why has it not been implemented until now? The reason it has not is
because of economic barriers. I presented this concept to Transport Canada back in 1981, and I pressed them to do a feasibility study. I told them to choose any city they wanted; Vancouver, Montreal, Toronto. Do a feasibility study on an elevated bicycle expressway system. We were in government then, and the reason Transport Canada would not touch it was because of the 1981-82 recession.
Mr. Adler and I resurfaced this concept 10 years later. We are getting the same barrier, economic recession. In the years 2001 or 2002, someone will resurface this concept again and we will probably have the same barrier, economic recession. I hope not. I hope that we will get into multi-dimensional thinking instead of two-dimensional thinking. Hopefully, in a decade from now we will have not only a feasibility study, but a system well in place.
Imagine if a city like Toronto, where my riding is, developed such a system. It would be the first city in the world to have an elevated bicycle expressway system. Because it is elevated it does not interfere with the local pedestrian traffic, with the auto traffic, et cetera. It is a complete system unto itself.
Imagine the tourist attraction that this would be. Tourists would come from all over the world to look at this expressway system. Imagine what it would do to the bicycle economy. We could rent bikes at various locations along this system and drop them off at another location. People could tour cities on bikes, which is getting more and more popular.
Imagine what it will do to the environment. Toronto, a Canadian city, would be the first to make that important turn to a truly sustainable environment on this planet.
What I am appealing, through this debate, is for at least three levels of government-in metro Toronto it would be four levels of government-to get their heads together. We are talking about infrastructure, sharing infrastructure at one-third, one-third and one-third the cost among three levels of government.
Here is excellent sustainable infrastructure, sustainable transportation, sustainable development. That may look costly, but when we look at what we save in preventing accidents, improved health in the people and fewer medical costs, the system would probably pay for itself within five or ten years.

Here is an opportunity for Canada to take a leadership role at this conference and present at least one new creative idea, which this is. Most of the bicycle expressway systems present now consist of adding on a lane next to the cars. That is not the solution. We cannot put too many bikes and too many cars on the same level. Here the bicycles would be above the cars.
In Toronto, well right across Canada, there is a bid for Expo 98.1 have already written to the committee. I said that if it would implement a bicycle expressway system in the city of Toronto, I am sure Canada would win Expo 98 because we would be the only city in the world that would have such a show-piece as this to show.
After my referring Mr. Adler to representatives of the provincial government, they were very polite. They thought it was a great idea, but they had the same excuse, a dozen economic reasons. They did not see themselves taking part now.
We talked with the chairman of metropolitan Toronto who said that because the federal government was giving less money to them through the provinces they could not afford to pay their welfare recipients, never mind building a bicycle expressway system.
We went to the former mayor of Toronto and received a similar answer. I referred Mr. Adler to the new mayor of Toronto, and I am sure it will be the same answer: this economic barrier.
We have to break that barrier, as I said, with three-dimensional thinking. We have to get away from two-dimensional thinking. Let us get into multi-dimensional thinking. If we implement such a system, the economy of that city would just boom because of the world attention, because of the world attraction.
Imagine the conventions that would be held in that city just to see a unique bicycle expressway system.
I do not know who is going to Rio de Janeiro, but I hope they will drop in to see Dr. Adler's presentation. He has been accepted to make the presentation at the sustainable transportation conference which is going on at the same time.
The government parliamentary secretary is listening very attentively. I hope he will pass this message
The Environment
on to the government or to all of the delegates who go to Brazil to sit in on this presentation.
It is something unique. It is something creative. It is something that no other country has thought of. A Canadian engineer has thought of it. Why do we not give this Canadian some help? I am not saying to go an build it off the bat. Let us do a feasibility study. Surely, putting our heads together we can come up with enough money to do a feasibility study, and if the feasibility study shows, yes, we can do it, let us go ahead and do it. Let us not wait and waste another decade. Let us really put into practice what we are going with to the UNCED conference.
I do not know if I require unanimous consent of the House to table this document, The Bicycle Expressway System by engineer Joseph Adler. The presentation here has coloured photos, engineer's drawings. I feel it should be tabled, with your permission, so that anyone who reads this debate could come and could have access to this unique system which would save our environment.

speakeroldname: Mr. Jim Edwards (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State and Leader of the Government in the House of Commons):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Government in the House of Commons
subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, the hon. member for Parkdale-High Park was right. I listened with great interest to his speech, as I have to the bulk of the speeches here tonight. I think we ought to do more of this. This gives the public of Canada an opportunity to see this place at its best, in the sense that various different points of view and some remarkably profound analyses can be displayed as a result of work and interest areas of members of Parliament.

The Environment
Frankly we tend to stereotype members of Parliament according to their areas of identified expertise. I see the hon. member for Skeena here, who I am informed is domestic environmental critic for his party. I thought he was a global environment critic for his party, and he may yet surprise us when it is his turn to speak.
There are many other members tonight who have contributed to this debate and who have shown unexpected profundity of thought in this area. I will not wax cynical and think that Rio may be the attraction, because it is really not an essay contest to go to Rio.
The earth summit is an important meeting for all humanity though. The agenda is heavy, the consequences crucial, and the expectations are great. If every country present defends its national interests vigorously, a large part of the debate will concern the priorities of the developing countries and the actions that must be taken by the international community to help that part of the world move irreversibly ahead on the path of sustainable development. Thus, at this United Nations Conference on Environment and Development, the debate on the development-environment equation will reach a turning point, with some 150 participating countries trying to determine more precisely how the environment is linked to poverty, to debt, to population growth, and other socioeconomic factors.
This close relationship, this interdependence between development and environment-and as the hon. member for Rosedale was saying, the welding or the melding of the two together-has come to the fore since the proceedings of the Brundtland commission where the alarm was sounded on the state of our planet, and where it was stressed that sustainable development is out of the question if we continue to upset the global balance of our biosphere.
We now realize that not only must development minimize the environmental consequences of human activity, but global growth itself is threatened by declining environmental quality. Thus, the environmental dimension surges on to the socio-economic agenda of all the world's countries and calls for preventive action that is global, firm and healing.
If we look at the obstacles standing in the way of sustainable development by the developing countries,
it is clear that generalized poverty seriously compromises the future availability of the natural resources needed for the people to survive.
The urgent need for food, energy and shelter facing many poor countries forces them more often than not to overuse their natural resources. For them it is not a matter of choice but of human survival. Other countries are undergoing, in a way that cannot be supported, gross pollution related to the use of obsolete technology. I have not even mentioned the health problems suffered because of unclean water and catastrophes such as flood and drought caused by excessive deforestation.
Non-sustainable development accompanied by environmental degradation constitutes a source of conflicts which will only multiply with the increasing shortage of essential resources and will threaten the stability of many economies.
The population explosion represents another serious threat to our global biosphere. The world's population has already risen past five billion people, three-quarters of whom live in developing countries and have a per capita income on average 50 times less than that of people living in developed countries. If the current population trends are a good indication the world population could double over the next forty years. It is also not impossible that in the coming decade Canada will receive its first environmental refugees.
To reduce poverty and meet the needs and legitimate aspirations of growing populations, our efficiency in using natural resources and industrial processes must be increased to an optimal level.
From the beginning of its first mandate, our government has set in motion several environmental initiatives and legislative measures. It has also participated in a series of accords with the provincial governments to address common or sectoral environmental problems. It has done the same with the United States and members of the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development with regard to the collective and concurrent global measures to be taken to combat the irreversible deterioration of ecosystems.

The Government of Canada is committed to working with a wide range of partners. To be able to play a well defined role in closing the gap between the north and the south we need to work together as never before to take action in ways that are radical.
I mean by that, action that goes to the root of the problem.
As representatives of the people of Canada we have a special responsibility to make sure that Canadian policies and actions in the broad field of international co-operation do not add to the global environmental problem but instead are part of the solution. Canada has a lot of environment per capita, and love of the environment runs deep in our values and culture.
Over the past 20 years that concern has been reflected increasingly in Canada's development assistance program. Over those years the environment emerged as an important new dimension of development policy and the Canadian International Development Agency funded a growing number of projects supporting, for instance, the creation of environmental monitoring in teaching institutions in the developing world.

CIDA's Industrial Co-operation Program also considers these environmental concerns. For instance, a Canadian engineering company received financial assistance under this program to prepare a restoration plan for Lake Maracaibo, in Venezuela. The company now has a contract for setting up waste water treatment facilities to clean up the lake.
During the Globe 92 conference and exhibition held in Vancouver last March, thousands of our partners in development-delegates representing industry, the business community, associations and governments- engaged in a creative dialogue. They took part in a trade fair in an area expected to become one of the prime motors of our economy in the 21st century: environmental technology and services, where economic development and environmental concerns meet.
On January 30 this year, Canada reinforced its commitment to sustainable development when the Minister for External Relations, responsible for international development released CIDA's new environmental policy on sustainable development.
The Environment
Basically, it means that CIDA will ensure, through a variety of mechanisms, that environmental considerations are fully factored into all decisions and project development. Furthermore, it will set a priority on helping developing countries deal with their environmental problems through policy reform, institutional support and community development.
We are also prepared to help our partners in Canada meet the challenge of integrating environmental concerns in their development projects.

CIDA's policy for environmental sustainability represents a renewal and a step forward in CIDA's commitment to the environment. It goes beyond the 1986 policy, which was essentially responsive to a more proactive role for CIDA in promoting environmental sustainability.
The policy does this by giving CIDA a new set of rules for factoring the environment into the development equation. The government is committed to working with a whole range of partners so that Canada can play a very definitive role in helping to bridge the north-south gap.
The goal of development co-operation today is to support sustainable development. This means equitable, balanced development that is sustainable in many senses: economically, politically, socially, culturally and environmentally.
CIDA will support social and economic development in ways that improve the quality of the environment and that maintain the productive base of natural resources. The Government of Canada considers this new policy an essential step ahead on the path we are following together toward UNCED, and the new era beyond that conference. We realize that UNCED cannot succeed and the world cannot deal with the environmental challenge unless the developing countries have access to the required resources, expertise and technologies to solve their environmental problems.
We recognize that our environmental policy has to take account of the competitive position of Canadian firms on world markets. There is a lot of Canadian expertise in this field. Our development program opens many doors. The environment development sector or interface is going to be at the leading edge of growth in the global economy of the 21st century.

The Environment
We also recognize the value of our non-governmental organizations and their first-hand experience of conditions in the developing world. We look forward to working together with them to improve the integration of environmental factors into the development projects and programs financed by Canada.
We need to create a new global alliance for the environment, an alliance between south and north, between government and non-governmental organizations and institutions, and between the public and private sectors. The efforts of all of us will be essential.
Canada has been firmly committed to the earth summit concept from the beginning. Our wealth and strength has been built on the development of our rich natural resources. One in ten Canadians depends on the forests for their livelihood. Commercial fishing supports some 1,500 coastal communities. Almost two million Canadians earn their living from farming and related activities. The rivers and reserves of oil and natural gas provide the energy that heats our homes and drives our industries.
However, many of our natural resources are threatened by pollution, overfishing, misdirected urbanization, and wasteful misuse. Canadians have recognized these problems and the different levels of government have responded to these concerns. At the same time many Canadians have already taken steps in their own lives to correct the mistakes of the past and adopt environmentally friendly lifestyles.
For all of us who are committed to helping the less developed countries improve their social and economic standards of life the earth summit has special significance. It offers a unique opportunity to ensure that all development assistance is environmentally sustainable, and that developed and developing nations alike work hand and hand to build a world that will provide a healthy atmosphere for our children and grandchildren.
The Canadian International Development Agency has invested funds to help developing countries send delegations to Rio. Some of the money is being used to help them prepare national, environmental and development reports to present to the summit.
Other funding from Canada will allow non-governmental organizations from developing countries to
participate in the conference. Canada is also providing $1.3 million to help Brazil cope with the burden of organizing the conference and to support its own sustainable development efforts.
The success of the earth summit is not a foregone conclusion. Negotiations will be difficult. We know from experience how hard it is to get agreement on policies within our own nation. Getting some 150 and more nations to agree on policies will be that much more difficult. We can only hope that the seriousness of the problem and the demands for change to ensure a viable future for our planet will help us to find unity and co-operation.
A lot of issues will be on the table. Managements of land resources, forests and oceans are three big ones. What institutional arrangements will be necessary to implement the new policies that will emerge from UNCED? The transfer of technology is an important question.
Everyone knows that technology transfer is one of the most important tools of development but it has also proven one of the most difficult to use well. Poverty alleviation, population growth and consumption patterns are important areas in which change is needed; changes in attitude and changes in use of resources.
Women have an important role to play in bringing about changes. So do non-government organizations, indigenous peoples, business and other sectors
of society.
Canada's delegation, including CIDA representatives, has played an important role in all these areas in the four meetings of the preparatory committee leading up to the earth summit. Unanimous agreement is not often achieved, but a consensus has been growing on many of the key issues. Despite the difficulties, we can remain hopeful that UNCED will produce a real declaration on environment and development which will spell out mutually agreeable principles that all nations can follow in their moves toward sustainable development.
There is even hope the summit will generate a binding international convention on climate change which will recognize the need to control greenhouse gases and another on biodiversity which will help to insure the continued existence of a rich mix of plant and animal life.

The other major result hoped for in UNCED is agenda 21, a global action plan that will itemize costs, set timetables and assign responsibilities for the difficult concrete steps that have to be taken to keep the planet firmly on the road to sustainable development. The United Nations Conference on Environment and Development is not an end itself, but rather a beginning; a beginning of a process of global dialogue among the nations of the world so we can find new ways of working together as we tackle new priorities.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to speak in this most important debate. There is no doubt that the earth summit is an important watershed meeting, and as to how successful it will be, we had best all keep our fingers crossed and hope it really is as successful as it might be.
I lament the lack of global leadership. Issues such as population and poverty are not leading the agenda.
We have also seen in recent weeks and months the bullying by some major nations such as the United States on issues that are critical to the survival of the planet such as global warming. We have basically seen the gutting of the draft international agreement by the United States, which does not want to move on this issue. I intend to spend some time on that.
The issues that were originally called for in the UN resolution were the protection of the atmosphere by combating climate change, depletion of the ozone layer and transboundary air pollution, protection of the quality and supply of freshwater resources, protection of the oceans and other seas. Protection and management of land resources, including combating deforestation, desertification and drought, conservation and biological diversity and environmentally sound management of biotechnology, environmentally sound waste management, improvement of the environment of the poor in both urban and rural areas, protection of human health and improving quality of life.
Some things have been dealt with in agenda 21. Without dealing with issues like population or what is happening in terms of the reversal of the flow of capital from the developed world to the developing world, until very recently billions were still continuing
The Environment
to flow from the major industrialized nations of the world to the Third World countries so that their economies could begin to develop to deal with issues such as poverty and population.
Every major international financial institution in the world is aware that the poorest countries in the world are now paying out those few dollars their economies earn to the wealthiest nations in the world to sustain what may well be the most unsustainable kind of society this planet has ever seen.
I want to give you a few things to think about and people who are watching should think about it and those who are still involved in preparations for Rio should think about it as well. There are three children born every second. Today, while this debate takes place 40,000 children under the age of 12 will die of starvation and preventable disease.
The population will rise from where it is right now, just over 5 billion, to 8 billion and perhaps as high as 14 billion during the next generation, which is far beyond the caring capacity of earth. Twenty thousand species will become extinct this year. The leading scientists in this field now calculate that half the species on earth will become extinct over the next 50 years.
World wide, 18 million hectares of rain forest will be cut or burned this year, 2 hectares ever second. Over the last decade, Canada's track record in this field, we lost 2 million hectares per year to forest fires and a million hectares per year to clear cuts; 5 hectares per minute, 24 hours a day. That is one acre every five seconds, much of it never regrowing at all.
Expenditures around the world have continued relentlessly; in the neighbourhood of a trillion dollars a year on military expenditures. Even Canada is spending over $12 billion this year on defence related matters.
Let me spend a moment on global warming because it is a particularly crucial issue and one that is not being effectively dealt with by this country or by the majority of the countries that have been participating in the development. Here I am speaking of the major industrial countries. Certainly most developing countries have long recognized the dangers that are presented by global warming to them and their economies.

The Environment
The all-party committee of this House a year ago produced a document called No Time to Lose-The Challenge of Global Warming. Our opening quotation was:
"By the time scientists have all the answers to these questions, global climate change may have been driven by human society to the point where the answers are largely academic".
What did we adopt? All parties in this House spent more than a year and close to a million dollars collecting scientific, internationally recognized evidence upon which all members from all parties, from all sides, could decide and report to this House. What did we recommend? We unanimously recommended a 20 per cent reduction in human source carbon dioxide emissions by the year 2005, compared to the 1988 level of emissions be adopted by the federal government as its minimum, interim objective in reducing Canadian carbon dioxide emissions.
That is what an all-party committee of the House had to say. We then issued a subsequent report because this government, leading the delegation to Rio, apparently alone, without any members of the opposition, then adopted what it described as the stabilization proposal, 1990 levels by the year 2000, something which has still not been implemented two years later.
Our report, called Out of Balance, the Risks of Irreversible Climate Change, was again unanimous, all-party. It said:
"Our report is based on three main premises. Global warming has been proved scientifically. It is an inevitable and continuing consequence of past and present patterns of human activity and it represents a severe threat to both Canada and the planet as a whole".
We went on to say, and I quote from page 4, which is referring to the United Nations environment program, a world meteorological organization group of scientists which eventually came to be known as the intergovernmental panel on climate change, the IPCC: "We are certain of the following: the greenhouse affect is real. Man-made emissions are substantially increasing the atmospheric concentrations of the greenhouse gases, carbon dioxide, methane, the chlorofluorocarbons, nitrous oxide and tropospheric
ozone. These increases will lead to a warming of the earth's surface. We calculate with confidence that atmospheric concentrations of the long lived gases adjust only slowly to changes and emissions. Present day emissions of these gases are committing us to increased concentrations for decades to centuries. The long lived gases would require reductions in man-made emissions of 60 to 80 per cent to stabilize their concentrations at today's levels. Methane would require a 15 to 20 per cent reduction". That is agreed to by the scientific community across the world. Across the world there is unanimity.
I have heard senior scientists at meetings I have attended here, in the United States, in Europe, everywhere I have gone, who state with absolute confidence that there has not before in their experience been a global issue studied as carefully by as many scientists with as high a degree of reliable confidence as global warming.
What does our government do? Our government refuses to accept what a parliamentary committee has found. It refuses to accept what the international scientific community has found. It flails around and suggests that perhaps stabilization at 1990 levels, but we have three different figures being used by this government as to what 1990 levels are. The National Energy Board says 517 megatons. Energy, Mines and Resources says 508 megatons. The Canadian Council of Environment Ministers says 467 megatons. Not a single minister of the Crown to this point, less than a month before we go to Rio, is prepared to stand in this House or to put in writing what Canada's 1990 emissions are.
This is tantamount to going to a doctor who tells you you have a broken leg and you go back and your government tells you to put on a band-aid and carry on as usual and everything will be fine. It is the business as usual phenomenon. There is a blatant refusal to accept even the premises that scientists reached a decade ago which was that there were real limits to growth, whether of urban sprawl, of agriculture, of industrial activity. Everyone was agreeing that there were limits to that kind of growth. That was a decade ago.
This particular government, I regret to say, never even got out of business as usual to get to that understanding.

This is not just the cutting edge, but the majority of the scientific community studying the ozone problem and studying the problem of global warming has realized now that it is the growth of limits. It is moving in on us very, very quickly.
Let me give you some examples of that because they are truly shocking when you realize what they are in terms of the loss of entire nations beneath the sea. Even the United States has calculated these. William Cline, an economist with the Institute for International Economics and the author of a major American study on this, says: "If nothing is done, average temperatures are likely to rise an average of 10 Celsius degrees in Canada and much of the United States over the next 250 to 300 years and this will cost the U.S. economy $355 billion a year in 1990 dollars."
People say we must not talk in tranches of 10 years, 20 years, 50 years and centuries. Look at this continent on which a mere five centuries ago there was the first white contact. For more than 10,000 years the aboriginal people on this continent operated and made no measurable impact on any of the watersheds, on any of the ecosystems, on any of the major biological systems of plant or animal on an entire continent. In fact it can be said they made no impact on either of the major continents in this hemisphere, North or South America.
Yet in this tiny fraction of time, particularly since the time we began to massively expand the use of fossil fuels, the impact we have had, and subsequently major industrial nations like Japan and Europe have had a dramatic and potentially final impact on this ecosystem.
I am no longer one who is prepared to just sit by and watch it all happen because I know there are answers. There are many people around the planet who know there are answers but it seems to be a deeply hidden secret that we can get off this treadmill.
I am going to spend only a few more moments on global warming but I think it is critical that people know at least that reports like the DPA report exist in Canada. It came to a conclusion that the former minister of finance, Michael Wilson could stand in this House on any given day and give every man, woman and child in this country a $5,000 gift by simply moving to renewable energy systems in Canada. The DPA report concluded that a net benefit of $150 billion in 1988 dollars would ensue simply by taking simple measures to get only three-quarters of the way to a 20 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions.
The Environment
By protecting the environment, we could have a $150 billion net saving. Well someone might say: "Oh, well, pooh-pooh ta-ta, that is only one report".
Here is a report that came out yesterday, America's Energy Choices by the Union of Concerned Scientists, the Natural Resources Defence Council, the American Council for an Energy Efficient Economy and the Alliance to Save Energy. What does their summary conclude? It concludes that national energy requirements in 2030 would be cut nearly in half from the reference case with renewable energy sources providing more than half our energy supply.
Our nation's petroleum consumption would steadily decrease to just one-third of current levels by 2030. Carbon dioxide emissions would be cut by more than 25 per cent from 1988 levels by 2005 and by more than 70 per cent by 2030.
Consumers would save $5 trillion-not million, not billion-in fuel and electricity costs over the next 40 years. By subtracting the $2.7 trillion additional investment needed to achieve this, we estimate a net savings of $2.3 trillion.
To reduce the effect of greenhouse gases you reduce greenhouse gases. How do you do that? You opt for a different energy future. You save money doing that and you improve the environment.
We should not be naive. The reason that George Bush is going to Rio but will not allow a global warming draft treaty to move forward with targets and timetables is because he is a captive, he is a hostage, of the fossil fuel sector, the same way the entire front bench of this government is captive and hostage to the fossil fuel sector of this country. You cannot tell me it is not so. There are 700,000 children living in poverty in Canada and there is money for a heavy oil upgrader from the taxpayers of Canada for Lloydminster, and there is money from the taxpayers of Canada for Hibernia. Where is the private sector? Where is the free market? It is a lot of hogwash.
Let me spend a moment on nuclear and a few of these other phenomenally wasteful systems that we continue to subsidize at our own peril. Let me quote from Dr. Amory Lovins who appeared before the Standing Committee on Environment and told Canadians what we should be doing. This is quite aside from the $150 billion in savings so that Canada could go to it. The committee of this House unanimously found out what we could, should, and must do if just our children are to live normal lives, to say nothing of the havoc that would be wreaked on future genera-

The Environment
tions with entire nations becoming submerged under the oceans of the world.
The Pacific Ocean has already risen. No one talks about it in this House. People talk about interest rates and the dollar, and what are we going to do. It is a lot of crap. They just do not seem to be living in the real world. The limits of growth are moving in and moving in. The growth of limits are moving in and moving in. Yet no one seems to want to wake up.
Dr. Lovins very carefully analysed the energy economy of Canada. He gave us some very clear, concise, easily understandable suggestions of what a society with intelligence, a society that opted for intelligent government, instead of greedy government might want to do. He pointed out that more than one-sixth of the electricity in Canada is used directly and indirectly for light. Almost half of that is incandescent lights.
He points out how we can go on to save energy. I quote from the next page: "When you add up all of the lighting improvements and fully install them, you will save upwards of 90 per cent of the lighting energy". You get the same amount of light as right now, but it looks better and you see better. The average cost of doing that will be somewhat less than zero because of the saved maintenance costs. Across Canada it would save on the order of 8,000 or 9,000 megawatts at a rough estimate. On motors, which use more than half the electricity in the world, including in North America, again you can have massive savings on everything in your home; fridges, freezers, electric motors in your car. All of these things add up and most of them bring about a reduction in the amount of fossil fuels we use.
Let me give you, Madam Speaker, an example on nuclear and electricity in this province of Ontario. By the time you get up to here, you are saving about three-quarters of the electricity in the country. He has already shown us how to reduce electrical production at coal thermal in Alberta, at nuclear in Ontario, at major water hydro, James Bay I and major hydro in British Columbia, the W. A. C. Bennett dam. You are saving about three-quarters of the electricity in the country at a marginal cost of somewhat over three cents a kilowatt hour; in other words, comparable to what Ontario Hydro says is its avoided cost or long-run marginal cost.
However, the average cost of quadrupling electric efficiency is only about .7 Canadian cents per kilowatt hour. That is probably cheaper than just running a coal or nuclear plant even if building it were free. Indeed you can get up to this point and save roughly half the electricity in the country at zero net cost because this area equals this area. This is very good news for global warming and acid gas emissions.
I use this as an example of what the inherent problem is. There are certain vested interests in this society and in most of the industrial economies of the world. They have become fossil entrenched. The infrastructure is fossil, the investments, the loans and the debt are fossil related. They do not want to get off of it.
Global warming will cause us to perish, perhaps not these withering bodies that are in this Chamber, but future generations which would love dearly to live in a world where they can walk outside, hear birds, sniff flowers and maybe go for a swim in a lake, where they are not either poisoned by the water or have their bodies stripped clean by the acid in the water.
I plead for a success in Rio but it is going to require a much more potent form of leadership from this country and from others on population, poverty, technology transfer, maintaining the biodiversity of this planet, doing something serious on targets and timetables to protect the ozone and to protect the atmosphere of the planet. I have left many other things out but there are serious, real solutions to every single one of them if we apply our intelligence and our scientific ability just once on behalf of this planet.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I am pleased to have this opportunity to participate in this important debate about the survival of our planet, the survival of our small, fragile, unique and lovable planet, our one and only home in this vast universe.
I do not want to appear or seem over-dramatic, but that is exactly what the nations of the world will be discussing at Rio next month. They will be discussing the very survival of our planet, the survival of our atmosphere, the survival of our oceans, the survival of our fish and animals, the survival of our forests and our arable land.

Some might say that I am being overdramatic, that I am exaggerating and that these things we see around us day and night, month after month are not really at risk. They are.
We are polluting our land, our air and our water at an alarming rate. We are pouring C02 into the atmosphere and destroying our ozone layer, building a greenhouse and developing a global warming system which will raise our waters and destroy our lands. We are destroying our forests by deforestation and getting rid of our good arable land by which we feed ourselves and grow our crops. We are overfishing in many parts of the world.
It appears to be exaggerated because it is not visible to us at all times. We do not see it happening from day to day. This makes it all the more scary. It is happening but we do not notice it happening. It is like an individual who gets cancer. In the early stages they do not know they have cancer but it is developing inside of them. Finally one day they do not feel very well and they go to the doctor. The doctor has them examined and he says: "You have three months to live" and he is right. They are dead in three months.
In the early stages, it was not noticed. Unfortunately it is the same with many people when they look at what is happening to our environment, the risks to our environment, the threats to the survival of our great planet.
It is only after it is well advanced that it becomes noticeable and people want to do something. It will be too late then. It will be too late to do something unless it is done right now. The purpose of the earth summit, the UNCED conference, the UN Conference on Environment and Development which is to take place in Brazil next month, is to stop the degradation of our planet and to reverse the initiatives which are moving the planet in that direction. Their main goal is to implement many programs for sustainable development that will help the real and necessary development of the world, but will do it in a way in which we do not destroy those things that we need for centuries and centuries to come.
Obviously this approach cannot be achieved without cost. We mislead ourselves, we delude ourselves, we totally fool ourselves if we think we can make great statements with respect to sustainable development,
The Environment
with respect to the protection of our waters, our arable land and our forests without any cost to ourselves, without some sacrifice, without some change in our consumption habits and without some change in our development.
The principle challenge at this conference will be to resolve the needs and goals of the southern hemisphere with the needs and goals of the northern hemisphere.
In the northern hemisphere we have for the most part developed nations, rich nations, rich in comparative terms which are heavy consumers. In the south we have little development, people that are extremely poor and who have very low levels of consumption. The challenge is how do you achieve a world agreement to stop destructive development and at the same time initiate sustainable development so that the southern hemisphere can catch up and get those things that are necessary and that we have in the north, so that they can get proper housing, proper food, proper health care, proper education, proper care for their children and so on. They need that development, while at the same time, those of us in the north who for the most part have exploited, colonized and have been imperialistic toward the south for many centuries, have to contribute and co-operate to control and change the destructive development that has taken place for a long time.
Problems are developing as a result of these two situations in the world. The north is asking the south for environmental commitments which seem too heavy to the south unless it gets some help. The south is saying that if it was to curtail its development in the way that we are asking it would be condemned forever to permanent underdevelopment.
Those in the south are saying: "You are hypocrites in the north. You have already destroyed your forests, you have deforested many of your lands. Now you are asking us not to develop our own forests".
The south is demanding transfers of modern technology from the north to help it develop its lands, forests and waters in a way which would be sustainable but the north is not willing to contribute or pay to the extent that is necessary.

The Environment
Sometimes the north puts conditions on its contributions to the south which appear to the north to be politically necessary. For example, the north will say: "Yes, we will help you but we want you to be democracies like we are", "We will help you but we want you to straighten out your human rights records", or: "We will help you but we want your contribution in combating world terrorism". They all seem to be reasonable requests.
They can be achieved but only if the north is also willing to make some sacrifices to help the south to do the things that are necessary.
Exactly what is UNCED? It is the UN Conference on Environment and Development scheduled for June 1 to June 12 in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, better known as the earth summit. It will be the largest international conference ever to take place in the world. It is expected that about 30,000 people will participate in the major inter-government conference and the parallel conference that will take place at the same time.
The conference delegations will not only be made up of heads of government, heads of state and national delegations but there will also be participation from non-governmental organizations, industry, science, business, youth and women. The goal, the stated purpose as set out in the United Nations General Assembly resolution is the following, and I will read it exactly as it is written in the resolution:
The purpose is to elaborate strategies and measures to halt and
reverse effects of environmental degradation in the context of
strengthened national and international efforts to promote
sustainable and sound development in all countries.
It says in all countries, not just in the rich countries, not just in the north, not just in the white countries.
This conference in Rio is a follow-up to a process that began in 1972 in Stockholm with the UN Conference on the Human Environment. It was followed up with the UN Commission on the Environment and Development in 1983 which published the Brundtland report on sustainable development.
There are some very real problems with respect to this conference, and if they are not solved and solved soon the conference will be a failure. Unfortunately the biggest, strongest, and richest nation in the world, the United States, is resisting change on almost every item before the conference.
The President of the United States is the only head of government in the world who has said that he will
not participate in the conference, at least thus far. There is still hope that he will go and support the conference. HoweveT, so far the president of the richest and most developed country in the world-the country that has expended the most energy and produced the most waste and pollution-is not attending the conference.
Unfortunately, the United States has tried to dilute the proposed earth charter, which is the proposed declaration of earth rights. It is a declaration which would set out new norms for international behaviour with respect to the planet. The United States has sought to dilute that earth charter so that it becomes just a declaration of principles with very little teeth.
As well, the United States has rejected the proposed limits for carbon dioxide emissions. It is supported to a certain extent by certain OPEC countries and the Soviet republics. However Germany has committed itself to a reduction which goes beyond that set out in the earth charter, and many countries in Europe, as well as Japan, support the binding agreement as proposed.
Some major industrial nations are supporting it but the United States is dragging its feet and is trying to dilute it. The United States has resisted commitment to Third World aid and technology transfer, and the President of the United States is the only world leader who has said he will not attend the meetings.
UNCED, or the earth summit, has three major goals. One is the earth charter, which is to be a declaration of earth rights, new norms for international behaviour with respect to the world.
The second goal is what is called agenda 21. It is an international work program to achieve the goals set out in the earth charter. How do we achieve the goals in the earth charter? That is what agenda 21 is about. It defends the principles of the charter, sets targets for each issue, and sets out the costs.
I talked about costs. It is estimated that the measures set out in agenda 21 would cost $600 billion. That seems like a lot of money, and it is a lot of money. It is a cost that would be carried by the whole world. However, when we realize that today the world is spending $1 trillion, if you can imagine that figure, on armaments $600 billion is by comparison a small figure.
May 7, 1992

The Environment
The nations of the world are spending $1 trillion-I cannot even imagine that figure but that is what we are told in the document-on tanks, bombs, guns, flame-throwers, napalm, rockets, and nuclear weapons to destroy humanity, to destroy the planet, to destroy our forests, and to destroy our fisheries and our oceans.
If we could agree, if we understood, if we moved to a higher level of civilization, a new way of thinking, we could easily transfer the money that we spend on arms to the sustainable development of our planet, to the development and protection of our waters, fisheries, forests, arable land and air; we could clean up our air and waters and provide the mechanisms necessary to do that; we could provide for the transfer of technology to the south so it can achieve the same standard of living that we have, but in a way that will not destroy the environment.
It is also the goal of the UNCED conference to come up with some binding conventions, some international treaties. One is to be on climate change. However that is at risk because of the attitude of the United States and certain countries. It is to be a treaty on climate change in which all countries of the world would commit themselves to reductions in CO emissions by the year 2005. It is hoped that a second convention would be on biodiversity. A third treaty, which is important to Canada, is to be an international convention on the management of fish stocks and marine resources.
We know what has been happening off the coast of Newfoundland and the east coast of Canada. Our cod stocks are being severely depleted by overfishing, principally by the European nations.
That is why it is necessary. Some people may ask why it is necessary that we do this internationally in Brazil. Why do we need these conventions? It should be obvious.
Let us look at Canada. If Canada did everything under the sun to protect its environment, its waters, its forests and so on and so on but its neighbour-let us say the United States or France or Portugal or Spain-did nothing the air that was polluted in the United States would drift over us, as it did with acid rain, and destroy our maple trees, our lakes, our fish and our crops. We need international agreements.
Canada could very strongly protect its fishery resources and its domestic waters up to the 200-mile limit, but if there is no international agreement about what is done on the high seas then nations that do not care about tomorrow, the next century or 50 years from now will just deplete the resource. We have no way of dealing with them. Therefore, we must get serious about this and come up with international conventions. That is what they are trying to do at the UNCED conference in Rio.
What about the Canadian position? The Canadian position is a bit ambivalent. It looks very good on paper and there is some very good rhetoric here. Canada is supporting the earth charter. It has opposed the watered down version proposed by the United States.
Canada is committed to the transfer of technology to the southern hemisphere. Canada has committed itself to the required reductions in C02 by the year 2000, but it is waiting for the treaty to be agreed to. It has not said that it will do it here at home whether the treaty is passed or not. It is saying: "We will support it at the conference in Brazil", but it is not doing it at home. Despite our great green plan we have been very slow to implement some of the measures on the domestic scene.
Worse still, and I am told this by those who attended the preparatory conferences, while Canada has supported the right things at the conferences it has not taken issue with the United States when the U.S. has tried to, and in many cases done the job, weaken the earth charter, agenda 21 and so on. Canada has said what its position is, but when its friend to the south has taken measures to weaken the regime, to weaken the proposals Canada has not really played the role expected of it in international conventions. It has not taken issue with the United States strongly enough in trying to get the United States on side.
That is what is required. We require leadership in the world. Canada is standing for some of the right things. That is why we are sort of in the middle on this. We are certainly not a destructive element in the debate but we are not doing enough to push it over the top.

The Environment
There is a lot of concern in Canada among ordinary Canadians about their environment. However, many of the things we are talking about in this debate are difficult for them to understand. Ordinary people deal with the world around them, with their farm, their neighbourhood, their parks and playgrounds, their lakes and rivers and they do not often see the pollution happening. They do not know until one day they find out that there are no more fish in that lake where they used to go when they were young and all of a sudden there is no more grass in that field where they used to play ball. They see the green disappearing and the brown getting bigger and bigger and more sand and less good earth. When they find that out they get pretty upset.
In this country there is a lot of grassroots support for doing something to protect this planet and this nation, and to protect the resources of this nation for centuries to come.
In this House we often talk about not leaving our grandchildren and our great-grandchildren with a great deficit and debt. That is important, but we do not want to leave our grandchildren and great-grandchildren with a planet that is barren and cannot grow things, that does not have the ability to produce food, beauty, clean air and so on. We would be betraying our race and our people to forget about that and not do what is required of us.
In conclusion, I want to urge the government-unfortunately I do not see too many government members here at the present time, but I know they will be taking note of this debate. They are in a much better position than we are on the opposition benches to make another great effort to push this conference over the top and make it a success.
If we, the nations of the world, fail next month at the UNCED conference in Brazil, it will be a disaster not only for the environment, not only for the planet, not only for north-south relations because it has very serious implications for north-south relations but it will also have a very serious effect on the political stability of the whole world. I would like the government to think about that.
If people are starving, if people are dying, if there is drought and they cannot grow crops, and all the resources are drying up, that is when you have war,
that is when you have a revolution, that is when you have massive movements of refugees, a world in conflict and commotion. We can turn that around if we do the right things in Brazil next month at the UNCED conference.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have had the advantage of being in the Chamber most of the evening. Indeed, I had the honour and privilege of occupying your chair for a very short time. I will say from your vantage point it does focus attention on the diversity of opinions that are heard in the House. I may say it gave me even more respect for the Chair.
There were a number of things I thought about as I listened to the debate. It is difficult to get up at 9.30 p.m. to say something that is very much different from the excellent presentations that have been made by all the speakers here this evening. They were making good points. Some I agree with, some I disagree with.
By and large, the tenor of the presentations have been that there is a conference coming up in the first couple of weeks in June. It is the biggest conference the world has ever held. In most people's minds who have spoken on this it is probably the most important subject that we have ever seen at least as far as I am concerned.
I would have to tell you in trying to approach how I was going to put forward my point this evening, I want to relate to a subject that is very near and dear to your heart, I am sure. I do not want it to appear to the House that it is purely from a narrow viewpoint. I am using it to relate to the over-all environmental problem and the problems that will be discussed at this conference.
I also want to say by way of introduction before I get into the main presentation that until 1972 when the Stockholm conference was held and the report that came from that and the Brundtland commission, I had never heard the expression "sustainable development". I did not know what it meant.
Speaking personally, my conscience and my consciousness of the environment, of those things that put a perspective on the world and a perspective on the time that my grandchildren are growing up, the 2050s, causes me a lot more concern than it ever did before.

When I look at the agenda for this conference, in order for me to put it in perspective I want to go back and look at an area that has been of essential importance to me. I am talking about the fishing situation in Newfoundland and indeed the whole attitude and the development of the fishing industry in our province.
I want to go back to times that we remember from our history books. In 1497 John Cabot came over and the message he sent back to England was that it was teeming with fish. Baskets were put over the sides of the vessels, 400 ton vessels in those days, and after waiting the baskets would be brought in. The baskets would be filled with fish. That was 500 years ago.
Let me go to the time when I was a little boy growing up in Bonavista. It was not that long ago when there were the great companies, S. W. Mifflin, C. R. Tilley, and J. T. Swyers. That last company was formed by a man who in the early 1920s took $20 and borrowed another $100 and set up a business that is 100 years old today. This year it celebrates its 100th anniversary.
To give some indication of the lack of concern about the future of the fisheries, perhaps a little bit before my time in the good years, one of those companies, the J.T. Swyers Company that celebrates its 100th anniversary, in a good year would export 7,000 tons of dried cod to the West Indies and the Mediterranean. That is about 7 per cent in one town of all the cod that were caught last year.
That will give some perspective of what has happened to the resource of fish, groundfish, in this particular case, cod. Again, when I was a young boy the season was cyclical. There were good years and bad years, but there was never ever a concern that the fish would go away and never come back. That was never thought about.
Even when I came to this House in November 1988 which is less than four years ago, the very mention that the stocks of cod were in trouble, that they were on the verge of extinction was not a very believable subject to discuss.
It was not until almost two years later that there was an in-depth study done by credible people, mostly scientists headed by Dr. Leslie Harris, an eminent,
The Environment
renowned and most credible scientist who at the time was the president of Memorial University in St. John's, Newfoundland.
One of the concerns that he and his board members raised was that the stocks may be on the verge of extinction now. People read it and pondered and they said: "We really don't know, so we will continue to catch fish. We will continue with the high technology. We will continue."
Members on this side of the house did raise many times the concern about foreign overfishing and other kinds of overfishing, but even with that report with such credibility, it was not until this year that the reality of the extinction of those stocks became very stark. It was at about the same time as the Hibernia disaster, with the reduction of 50 per cent activity and money spent and a concern for the future, that has been the subject of other debates here, and I am sure will continue to be so. Those stocks have formed the way of life and have done so from the time that John Cabot came to discover Newfoundland 500 years ago.
It hit people like a ton of bricks, including me. I had always been concerned about it, certainly since I read the report of Dr. Harris, but the concern and the reality sometimes are not as parallel as we would like them to be. There has not been very much since, I am talking about early February, that has changed the minds of the people who are concerned about it.
I am not going to indulge the House this evening with a diatribe on the problem with foreign overfishing. Suffice it to say, as a quick reminder, that last year the foreigners illegally caught on the nose and tail of the Grand Banks of Newfoundland 40 per cent of what Atlantic Canadians caught legally. They had their best year in 15 years; Atlantic Canadians had their worst year in 15 years.
This has become the subject of great debate in this House and it is related to the Rio conference for two very simple reasons. One is that we cannot seem to convince the government to have the political will to make a declaration which gives Canada functional jurisdiction over the nose and the tail of the Grand Banks, to rid us of this plague and plunder of illegal and despicable foreign overfishing by Spain, Portugal and to a certain extent, Germany and other European Community countries.

The Environment
We are told by the government that the panacea for this, in addition to all the diplomatic work that has gone on in the last four years, is we are going to take it to the Rio conference. We are going to talk about this at the Rio conference. Everything is going to be fine. People are going to listen to us at the Rio conference.
Well, we have heard tonight about the Rio conference. I am not going to repeat what was said, but what is being discussed at the Rio conference?
I have 78 schools in my riding. I do not get to them all in a short timeframe but at one time or another I have been to most of them. In the last two months I guess I have been to 10.
One of the questions that the school population, both teachers and students who are familiar and are aware of this conference, ask me is: Why is this conference such a big deal? Well it is not hard to answer that. It is the same reason that foreign overfishing is such a big deal. Why is there such discussion in this House, the highest court in Canada, about the northern cod, a very specific item? Well, there is discussion about it because we think they may disappear. Equally, this conference at Rio is so important because we are concerned about the earth.
I take you from the town of Bonavista to the riding of Bonavista-Trinity-Conception, to our province, to our country, to our alliance within NATO and all the rest of things, and now we are looking at the planet.
What is the concern? It is a very simple concern. We cannot manage what we have now on this planet. We have technology. We have the results of the industrial revolution. We have never had so many scientists living in the world and every second they are inventing something new. That is is great. It is progress but is it sustainable?
I really did not think when I was elected to this House that I would be here at this time of the night speaking about sustainable development. But I am concerned about it, if for no other reason than the example of the possible extinction of the northern cod and other groundfish species. It is a jump-start for me to be concerned about the Rio conference and what is going to happen there.
The idea is that if we cannot control the world and the planet right now with our population of 5.5 billion almost at the turn of the century, how in the name of heaven and everything holy will we be able to control it 40 years from now when it is said the population will be at least double and perhaps even 13 to 14 billion. We have to stop and take stock.
Can I believe the government when it says that when the Rio conference takes place it will have some answers? Well I am not sure. We have 12 days. It is the largest conference the world has ever seen. There are 100 heads of state, there are 6,000 direct participants and another 24,000 observers and semi-participants. That is a big system. What is Canada's agenda for this conference?
I heard an excellent presentation being given by a couple of members here this evening. The member for Rosedale spoke with great knowledge on the subject and he mentioned that our agenda would be focused on a number of things such as climate change, the loss of biological diversity in the tropics, deforestation and the health of the ocean.
All these agenda items bring in concern for the Third World. They bring in the concern of the southern agenda and we know from our knowledge of the system, and I know from what I have heard this evening and what I have read, that the biological diversity may work. It has some chance. A climate change is certainly going to be the focal point of much discussion. Deforestation does not seem to be getting very far because of the concern of some of the tropical countries led by Malaysia. They are concerned that their tropical forestry industries cannot cope with some of the suggestions that are being made.
On the very cost of implementing some of the measures, just a few moments ago my hon. colleague from Notre - Dame-de-Grace talked about $160 billion to $600 billion. While I seldom disagree with any of my colleagues, particularly my esteemed friend from Notre-Dame-de-Grace, irrespective of how much money we spend on defence, I am not sure how we are going to conjure up among the 100 nations that will be attending this anywhere in the vicinity of $600 billion; $100 billion, $50 billion, perhaps.

I am not a pessimist but we are broke in Canada. We are broke. The United States is broke. Everybody seems to be broke. Where is the money going to come from?
Perhaps in the future it may come from the moneys that are spent on armaments, on defence expenditures today, but that is not going to happen over night.
Perhaps what we can hope for in this conference is a little bit more than an awakening. Perhaps we can hope for internal chastisement. Perhaps the Canadian delegation, whoever that is going to be, will come away from this conference with some indications of where we should we headed.
The Canadian delegation is lead by Mr. John Bell, whom I met a few years ago in South America when he was the consul general in Sao Paulo. We stayed in contact through the years. Mr. Arthur Campeau with Environment Canada, I understand, is also the personal representative of the Prime Minister at this conference.
Certainly from what I have heard they have lead one of the best delegations in the preparatory process.
However, and certainly from some of the things I heard here this evening, now that the conference is entering its penultimate phase or its penultimate stages, it is becoming clear that Canada does not have that much to offer on many of the key questions.
These kinds of questions require the kind of cabinet involvement and high level political leadership that may be taking place. I do not mean this as a political statement. It has not been apparent to the House.
The Minister of the Environment made a presentation this evening and in trying to read between the lines, I was not really sure what commitments had been made. We do not know exactly, precisely, who will be attending the conference.
Again, I do not mean that as a slur, but we are less than a month away from the conference. We should have our act together now. If we were rehearsing for a play, we would not be starting the first round coaching and the first round of having our little spills. We would be into almost a dress rehearsal.
I have been to a considerable number of conferences or committee meetings and caucus meetings that impinge around this very important conference. I have not seen anything that makes me feel confident that we are going there with a full deck of cards and with a honed position.
The Environment
Canadians have been known to get their act together quickly when the pressure is on and I am hoping this will happen in this particular instance.
We have a lot of leadership to offer.
I am hoping for some commitments from this conference. The hon. Minister of Fisheries and Oceans is from my province, he is my Newfoundland minister. We never use the words great things, but he is expecting that progress will be made in the foreign overfishing so that the government does not have to use a political will to extend beyond the 200-mile limit, Canada's jurisdiction.
I believe he is hoping that we will come out of there with at least a commitment from some countries that there will be a castigation of the European Community. I am not so sure that is going to happen. In some ways I am an idealist, but you learn to be a realist in politics very quickly.
In some ways, if the conference is not going to make a commitment, I would prefer to come out and say, "this is what we achieved" in stark terms and not to see a cleverly worded communique backed up with a couple of good photo opportunities.
I see my time is up. I want to say in conclusion, please play this well and make our preparations. As a Newfoundland member, I am making a special pitch to highlight the subject of foreign overfishing and ocean management. I am hoping for some results in mid - June.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, it is an honour to be able to participate in this debate which literally deals with the survival of this planet.
The debate is taking place in the context of the up-coming earth summit in Rio in less than a month, on June 3. I want to take this opportunity to pay tribute to those many Canadians from coast to coast to coast who have been involved in the preparations for this landmark summit about the survival and the future of the planet.
Particularly, I want to pay tribute to my colleagues, the member for Saanich-Gulf Islands and the member for Skeena, who have put in tremendous energy and dedication on behalf of New Democrats across this land in speaking out eloquently on the challenges that face us on the environment both here in Canada and globally.

The Environment
I very much regret that in the preparations for this historic conference, those colleagues and other members of Parliament from all parties were not involved far more in the process of arriving at a common position on behalf of the people of Canada. They were not involved in the preparatory conferences, for example, as we had hoped they would be.
Nevertheless, I know that they will be participating actively. I know that colleagues from a number of different parliamentary groups will be participating actively and hopefully will be able to help to shape the response of the Government of Canada.
I also want to pay tribute to the many Canadian NGOs working in the environmental field, in particular to young people. It is groups such as the Environmental Youth Alliance, young people, high school students, college students, unemployed young people, young working men and women who have said that the old ways are not longer acceptable.
The economy, which is driven solely by the pursuit of profit and corporate greed, both in Canada and increasingly internationally as we are drawn into the horrible vortex of trade deals with the United States and now with Mexico, is not accepted by our young people any longer. It is time for fundamental, structural changes. It is their future, after all, that this debate is all about and whether they are going to have a future at the rate at which the destruction is occurring.
I said that this is a debate and a dialogue from coast to coast to coast. My leader, who has been particularly outspoken on issues of the environment and our environmental protection in the north, whether it be low-level flights over her constituency of Yukon, the proposal for drilling in the north, which fortunately seems to have been shelved, or other proposals, certainly has reminded all of us as parliamentarians of the importance of protecting the north, the pristine north, from the ravages of environmental destruction.
I would hope that we would look as well at the proposals for demilitarization of the Arctic, of the north. I am sure that my colleague from Nunavut, who will be following me, will speak to this.
When we talk of challenges in the area of the environment, when we speak of de-militarization, it is particularly important that we recognize that unless we as a planet stop spending the obscene amounts of money that we spend each year on weapons of destructions, over a trillion dollars a year, the planet is doomed. We must redefine our understanding of what we mean by security and recognize that security does not come out of the barrel of a gun or from nuclear weapons, God help us. True security comes from ending the scourge of poverty and from ending the threats to the global environment. That is the true measure of security.
Recently, the citizens' inquiry on peace and security, which travelled across Canada and held public hearings, issued a landmark report in which it emphasized how fundamentally important it is that we redefine security, as Gro Brundtland also advocated in her report and the report of her Brundtland commission.
In a world in which 40,000 children are dying each and every day from hunger and preventable disease, if we are to speak seriously of protection of the environment, we must recognize that resources must go to ending the scourge of this kind of poverty and to making the links directly.
We must recognize that those wealthy nations in the north which are involved in multilateral and international financial institutions, the world bank, the IMF, party to programs of structural adjustment that strangle the poorest and the most vulnerable countries and within those countries which crush the poorest of the poor, that Canada and other wealthy countries can no longer impose those kinds of structural adjustment programs on countries which are already suffering under terrible and tragic debt burdens and expect that those countries will be able to play an effective role in protection of the environment.
It is time that we ended our hypocrisy of, on the one hand, urging these countries to do what they can to end environmental destruction and then in the next breath imposing upon them structural adjustment programs through the IFIs, the international financial institutions, which too often make it impossible for them to implement those policies.

There are a number of challenges that my colleagues have spoken of very clearly before me. My colleague from Saanich and the Islands has spoken of the particular importance of confronting the second-class status of women globally. A recent report of the United Nations documented very powerfully this lack of fundamental equality of women globally. Here in Canada, the United Nations Development Program pointed out that while we may be number one over all, the status of women in Canada still leaves a great deal to be desired. As long as women globally continue to be victims of violence, to be disproportionately poor, to be denied the fundamental freedom of reproductive choice, to be denied the basic means of ensuring that they are able to feed and clothe and house their children and as long as that second-class status continues, there will be no true respect for the environment.
