As long as we fail to make the fundamental links between poverty and destruction of the environment, there will be no true respect for the environment. As long as we continue to refuse to listen to the voices of indigenous peoples, there will be no true respect for the environment.
I regret to say that Canada has been silent for too long, both here at home in terms of the national shame of the treatment of our aboriginal peoples, which we are only beginning to come to grips with, but also globally.
A declaration was made by the indigenous peoples who attend the prep-com in New York in March of this year, just a couple of months ago. In that declaration they state their profound disappointment and anger that the statement which was forwarded to the secretariat of the earth summit by Norway and Denmark, which represented a consensus of indigenous peoples present at the prep-com was watered down.
They point out that indigenous peoples cannot, in fact, contribute to sustainable development, that they do not have control over their own territories. They point out that the struggle of indigenous peoples to have control over their own territories has been consistently undermined by governments, transnational corporations and international financial institutions.
The Environment
They had hoped that the process leading to the earth summit would involve a respect and understanding of the priorities of indigenous peoples, would involve an understanding that we have much to learn from them in terms of the sharing of their knowledge and experiences in protecting the environment. As they said, they are the original environmentalists on this planet. But no, Canada remained silent when this declaration was watered down.
I want to take a moment to speak about one particular group of indigenous peoples on this planet whose very survival is being threatened with genocide, that is the indigenous peoples of Sarawak and, in particular, the Penan people.
As David Suzuki has stated: "If we cannot save even a tiny remnant of the world's most ancient rain forests as a homeland for one of the world's only remaining hunter-gatherer tribes, there is not much hope for the rain forests elsewhere or for any of us. Whatever we let happen to Sarawak's forests will be symbolic of our values and actions for the next millennium".
The Penan people, numbering some 9,500, only 32 remaining families of hunter-gatherers are living on the edge of extinction.
I had the privilege of being able to meet with them myself in the heart of the rain forest in Sarawak in January of this year, where they have erected a blockade to stop the last road from going in to destroy their ancestral home. I could do no better than to quote the words of one of the leaders of the Penan people who said: "You must help us before it is too late. You all talk about the greenhouse effect and climatic change. The rain forest offers solutions to these problems. Our forest is your life support system. If we can preserve it, this is not only a victory for the Penan, it is a victory for the whole world".
It is time we listened. It is time we listened to the voices of indigenous peoples. It is time we listened to the voices of the Penan.
I very much regret that the government of Malaysia has been one of the governments that has been most vocal in resisting an international convention on the rain forests, on tropical forests and on forests generally-

The Environment
As a member of Parliament from British Columbia I recognize that we have much work to do at home as well in terms of our forests, whether it be old growth forests or other forests. The legacy is not one of which I am proud. This is a global problem and we must recognize that the rapid disappearance of the world's forests, the deforestation which is taking place, contributes to global warming. It accelerates the loss of biodiversity, it speeds soil erosion and flooding and it depletes an economic resource that could be sustainably managed, that could be creating jobs for generations to come. It is essential we recognize that the challenge is there, as a planet we must respond to it and our government should be showing leadership.
Finally, we are reminded to think globally and act locally. I want take just a couple of minutes in closing to talk about a global environmental challenge which is being dealt with at the local level. In my constituency of Burnaby-Kingsway, some 600,000 people are now being sprayed from the air by a bacterial insecticide BT Foray 48B against the Asian gypsy moth.
I want to voice on behalf of my constituents in North Burnaby my profound concern about the way in which this has been carried out. There was no opportunity for the people affected by this spraying to state their case, to voice their concerns, to put forward their arguments, to have a hearing and to listen, for example, to the study done by a group of Japanese scientists which demonstrated that there are some very serious concerns with respect to the relationship between BT and another type of protein, a toxigenic organism, which is not safe for human beings.
They were denied an opportunity to hear from eminent scientists who have expressed deep concerns about this, including Dr. Donald Dahlsten, professor of biological control and the chair of the division of biological control at the University of California. He pointed out that based on the trapping of a very small number of adult males of the Asian gypsy moth that a large scale eradication program is not warranted. There are other methods available to try to respond to this.
We all recognize the very serious concern about this infestation. After all, in this debate on the environment, I have to speak on behalf of my constituents, particularly those in North Burnaby who have voiced
their concern not just about this short-circuiting of the process, but their sense of anger and betrayal at the way in which the decision had been communicated. Some areas have been sprayed on more than one occasion. Notification is not adequate.
I want to take the opportunity of this debate, Madam Speaker, to appeal through you to the federal Minister of Agriculture to reconsider his approval even at this late date of this project and to give these constituents and these residents of the lower mainland an opportunity to be heard. The B.C. Medical Association, the B.C. Association of Allergists, ordinary residents, for example Fred and Alice Court and others, want an opportunity to have their voices heard on this program.
In conclusion, I want to say how fundamentally important it is that the outcome of this earth summit not merely be more words, more profound declarations, but that there be action, action in a global and collective commitment with Canada leading the way, demonstrating not just in Rio, but demonstrating here at home by concrete action that we are prepared to be world leaders on the environment. We should be prepared to live by the words of the Haida elders who reminded us that we did not inherit this globe from our ancestors, we borrow it from our children. We owe it to our children to make the earth summit a success.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
[Editor's Note: Member spoke in Inuktitut]
Madam Speaker, it is a very good opportunity to speak on the issue of the environment as a member of Parliament for Nunatsiaq and also as an Inuk member of Parliament. Whenever we talk about the environment, whenever anybody talks about the environment, we always think of ourselves as one of the two environmentalists as a group of people, the Inuit.
This conference that is going to be held in Brazil is going to focus on the environment. I would like to quote from my president of the Inuit Circumpolar Conference, Mary Simon, who said in March 1991 in Geneva: "It is widely known throughout the world that indigenous people spiritually believe all living and non-living things on earth are connected. These values and beliefs are integrated to ensure sustainable development of all renewable natural resources for the protection of the environmental habitat and natural resources".

I very much agree with this statement because, as I was saying in Inuktitut earlier, as we were growing up and as has been taught to us for thousands of years, we took from the land as a hunting and gathering society the animals but we gave it back. We gave it back to the land so there was never any pollution of any kind. This has always been the case until very recently in Canada, in North America.
I would like to quote from an action plan for the 1990s that was adopted at a global NGO conference in December 1991 in Paris, No. 16 of the action plan: "We call upon all governments to acknowledge aboriginal indigenous peoples ownership of their lands prior to colonization and to include this recognition into all government constitutions. Governments must promote and legislate aboriginal indigenous people's right to self-determination. Governments must compensate aboriginal indigenous people for the dispossession of their lands.
This does not imply that governments can expropriate lands against the will of the indigenous people. They must work in partnership with aboriginal indigenous people, peoples from small development projects, especially mining, forestry, and fishing, and ensure free access to their traditional food resources. Governments must legislate to protect sacred sites and to recognize tribal traditional practices that sustain the land. Governments must ensure constitutional and legislative requirements are implemented at all levels of the governmental process".
That very clearly spells out what the aboriginal people of the world, indigenous people of the world, would like to see. I go back to my colleague the previous speaker who said you have to listen to the aboriginal indigenous people in terms of the land.
I would also remind members and Canadian people of what is happening in Canada today.
After quoting this action plan, I can tell you right now that the government is in the process. Whatever land claims negotiations are going on right now, whatever land is being claimed by the aboriginal people of Canada, the majority of that land the government is asking the aboriginal people to give up aboriginal title to so that it can have absolute title as the Government of Canada in order to free that land
The Environment
for development purposes such as mining, oil and gas, and whatever else.
I can give an example of my land, Nunavut, that we just agreed to divide in 1999. We are now in the process of being asked by this government to give up, out of a total of 770,000 square miles of land that we live in, 633,000 square miles and keep 130,000-odd square miles for surface rights and 14,000 square miles of surface and subsurface rights. There is an example of what the government would like to do after we give up title to that large piece of land.
When I talked about how we are true environmentalists, I remember my colleague from Newfoundland and I went through some rough periods back in the 1970s when people like Brigitte Bardot started saying what cute little seals they were and they should not be killed by these barbarians from Newfoundland. They are savages. It showed all these things, but we should not kill these cute little animals, the cute little things so that they grow prosperously.
I began to think of the sealskins that we use for clothing as part of commerce for the Newfoundlanders. I think about what they gained in return for destroying the Newfoundlanders' and the Inuit way of life. We were not killing as many seals any more, so we were not wearing as much sealskin. People started wearing fake fur.
I remember talking to one lady who had been pressured into buying a fake fur coat. Some supposed environmentalists who did not know any better said: "How can you wear that? How many animals had to die for that?" The lady turned around and said: "Thousands and thousands of little polyesters". Just think how much more damage making that one fake fur did to the environment than if she had just gone out and bought a sealskin coat. How much cleaner the air would be if she had bought a sealskin coat instead of buying a polyester fake fur coat that had to go through a process of manufacturing and polluting the environment.
I talk about Inuit as true environmentalists. Whenever I have been up north and I come back here, I am always asked what the temperature is up there. I always say: "I don't know. It's warm". Today in Rankin Inlet I think it was something like minus seven, which is nice and warm for us.

The Environment
To give an example, I never know what the temperature is because I never bother looking at the thermometer. I look out the window and determine what kind of a day it is going to be. I think that is a true environmentalist who does not need a mechanical gadget to tell you how cold it is out there, or what the weather is going to be like later on in the day.
Down here we listen to the weather forecast and determine whether we should bring our umbrella because the weather forecast is it is going to rain today. We do not need to do that. We can tell by looking outside.
When I say in terms of being an environmentalist I say in whatever form, however we treat the land that has sustained us for so long in the north.
We had a scare a couple of years ago because we were told that in Balkin Island there was an awful lot of PCBs in mother's milk and we thought how can that be. We then realized that it was not us who were contaminating the sea or the land or the food chain in the north. It was international pollution, whether it was from testing of the nuclear bombs or other forms of pollutants that had no regard for the boundaries of the world.
There is no such thing as "this is Canada so we should not cross over to Canada from the Soviet Union, or from the United States or the smelters". That would have been nice if it could have happened, but unfortunately it did not.
All of a sudden mothers were endangered by a pollutant to which we had made absolutely no contribution. Today, we are still telling mothers to breastfeed their babies because it is still more healthy to breastfeed than the dangers of whatever may be in that. Hopefully it will be that way or lessened in years to come.
The same thing is happening in Manitoba where there are hydroelectric dams that have destroyed hunting grounds for the Indians of Manitoba. The hydroelectric dams that are in the process of being built in Quebec will destroy thousands of square kilometres of land that the Cree people use, the Inuit people use, and probably pollute Hudson Bay which is in part of my riding. Whatever flows into Hudson Bay goes around and would therefore pollute the sea.
There are all these things that are polluting. When I talked earlier about international pollution I did not mention these other pollutants that are out there, the hydroelectric dams, the sawmills, or others that are polluting the environment and crossing over borders such as from Alberta to the Northwest Territories to the Mackenzie River or the Slave River, or any other waterways. They do not show any concern for boundaries.
We try to say that we do not need the militarization of the north, that we do not need the military in the north. The only time that we would ever think of saying yes is because of the benefits that would come with building a modern airport in various parts of the north. That is the benefit we would get. At the same time we do not necessarily think we need the military in the north to maintain sovereignty.
I guarantee the Inuit are not going to move out of the north. We have no wish to move out of the north. It is our land, Nunavut. My riding is called Nunatsiaq. Again, and I have said this before, Nunatsiaq, if I were explaining it, means the beautiful land. But if I were explaining it to another Inuk, I would say Nunatsiaq in the English language would mean the good land, because for us it is the good land which sustains our way of life as Inuit.
When I say we are not going to move out, I know the Inuit have no wish to move out by and large. Some will move to go to school, to seek jobs elsewhere, or maybe they have married into another culture and wish to move down somewhere else in Canada. But by and large the Inuit are always going to remain in the Arctic. Therefore we maintain that sovereignty through the Inuit. We are not moving.
Why the need, especially today when the cold war is gone and there is hope for peace all over the world? Why build up military sites anywhere? Hopefully it is not just a make work project for people.
If we are to have make - work projects, let us do it in peaceful terms. Let us do it in ways that people are comfortable with whatever is going on. I include the Innu in Goose Bay who have for the last number of years protested the low-level flights there. I think they have gone through a tremendous hardship because of the low-level flights in Goose Bay. Hopefully their determination will bear fruit.

I go back to Inuit being environmentalists. Inuit are the true hunters. We hunt whatever animals we have. We hunt whales, caribou, walrus, beluga whales and seals. Whatever animals we have that can be eaten, we hunt them all. Yet we have never, never decimated a species of animals to the point of extinction because we only take what we need. We only take what we want.
I just mention that because we used to have an awful lot of bowhead whales and whalers came along and totally decimated the population. Now we as Inuit cannot even hunt them when they are in our land.
I just wanted to point out these things out. Hopefully people will learn and listen to the fact that indigenous people should have a role in the Brazil summit. The traditional knowledge of indigenous people should be recognized in Brazil so that when we talk about the environment we include the people who have the most knowledge of the environment.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext:
Madam Speaker, I have just a couple of comments to make, following the address of my hon. friend. I might add to the hon. gentleman's words. He referred to the real problem we had with the environmentalists back in the days when there was a considerable seal hunt in progress up north and off the northeast coast of Newfoundland, off Labrador and up into the Arctic.
Environmental groups came along, passed judgment and said that the native peoples in those areas and Newfoundlanders were barbarians, as the hon. gentleman mentioned. After those environmentalists promoted that campaign over in Europe and throughout the world, we had the ridiculous sight day after day of the hunters leaving seal pelts on the ice pans because they could not sell them.
The only thing they could sell was what they could eat, which was what they always sold. The carcass was of far greater value than the $11 they received for a seal pelt. Even today if we look at the people make a living, people who go out every day and work who have to strive for just a few dollars to make ends meet, they go out and they always get paid more for the meat if they sell it than they would for the pelt. The pelt's best price this year, last year and the year before was $11.
The Environment
They have to cure it and then ship it. How could they make any money at that? They cannot, thanks to those groups who organized the campaigns through Europe and around the world against our native peoples and against the seal hunters from Newfoundland who always made a living at that particular profession.
The hon. member made a very interesting observation at the end of his address. He talked about whales. He talked about restrictions on certain hunts. The restrictions are there not because of what the native people did, not because of what the people did who always hunted those species, but because of the actions of foreigners, foreigners who are allowed into those waters, into those areas of Canada, to do in a very big industrialized way what we have been doing for years and never hurting the resource.
Today we have the Government of Canada talking about this summit. It has put a motion on the Order Paper today which states:
That this House take note of the Canadian position at the United
Nations Conference on Environment and Development.
That is fine, but what is the Canadian position? It is fine to take note of it, but what is it? What is the main motion on the fishery at that conference? What is the motion? I do not know what it is. I do not know what the government's position is.
We do know that the Canadian government is now continuing the same practice it continued all over the years in relation to these resources that my hon. friend spoke so eloquently about a few moments ago.
In Japan over the last three months there have been demonstrations because the blue-fin tuna is in danger of extinction. Where? In the northwest Atlantic. In Japan it was on the national news that the blue-fin tuna in the northwest Atlantic is in danger of extinction. The northwest Atlantic is off the coast of Canada.
Why are they demonstrating? They are doing so because the country with the highest quota for blue-fin tuna in the northwest Atlantic Ocean is Japan.
Which country has the second highest quota? The United States. Which country has the lowest quota, at the bottom? Canada.

The Environment
While the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans was away in Mexico and in Japan asking it to stop overfishing, does the House know what the Department of Fisheries and Oceans did in Canada? It gave a larger quota to Japan than it gave to Canadians. This is 1992, and the Japanese have seven ship licences to fish tuna in our waters to within 12 miles of the hon. gentleman's coast and my coast out to 200 miles.
We are not talking about outside the 200-mile limit we are talking about Canadian waters.
Japan today has a higher quota in our own Newfoundland waters than all the Newfoundland fishermen put together. We have 35 tonnes and it has 180 tonnes of blue-fin. It has unlimited quotas of alba-core, big eye, yellow-fin, and all of the other different types of tuna. These unlimited quotas, in 1992, were given just four weeks ago when the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans was in Japan talking about overfishing. Those quotas were given by agreement; they were signed, sealed and delivered by Canada.
How does that make a Canadian feel? He cannot get a licence to go out and do what the Japanese are doing. The government is saying: "If you have a Japanese flag on your boat you can pick up your licences free of charge, we will bill you in the mail". That is what Canada has done, that is what it has done over the last four weeks. It has said to Japan: "You can fish more tuna than Canadians can. We will give you seven ship licences". In Japan there are demonstrations claiming that the blue-fin tuna is an endangered species.
The Minister of Fisheries and Oceans for the Government of Canada went down to Cuba the other day. Just last week he went down to Cuba. This year, in 1992, Cuba has been given licences for quotas of squid. An ordinary Newfoundlander, an ordinary Canadian up in the Arctic, down the Labrador coast, in Newfoundland, Nova Scotia or Quebec cannot just go down and get a licence for squid. It is restricted. This is the first year that we have a restricted licence for squid in this country.
A poor person, somebody on welfare, is not allowed to get a licence for squid. A person who has lost their job, and we have many of them, cannot get a licence for squid. Even full-time fishermen in Canada, in Newfoundland-and we have many of them-are restricted to their own bays. There are restrictions on their licences, they must have a certain number of
people in their boat and it must be a certain size. Oh, no, not for Cuba. If you are flying the Cuban flag you can go out there 12 miles off our coast out to 200 miles-this is not outside 200 miles-and you can catch the squid.
Why? Is squid an endangered species? We have not seen one on the northeast coast of Newfoundland or the Labrador coast since 1979. What glorious days they were: men, women and children out catching squid, drying them. Everybody had shoes on their feet. They had recession money, it was great and marvellous.
Today in this country, in Newfoundland, not one of those women can get a licence to catch squid if they came in tomorrow. Not one of those children would be allowed in a boat to catch a squid. They would be thrown in jail by law in Canada today. It is a restricted fishery. Yet if you fly the Cuban flag you can come inside the 200-mile limit. You can come into 12 miles and fish squid because you have been given licences all along the coast of eastern Canada in every zone marked 3 and every zone marked 4.
It is not an endangered species. There are none of them around. They only live for a year. They are bom in Florida, they die in Florida. They know where to go. They come up the east coast of Canada, we call it the 401, the Trans-Canada Highway. They come up in this thin black line, they go up to Newfoundland and Labrador. They get bigger and bigger and they go back down to Florida. Just as they hit the Canadian coast, lo and behold, there are the factory freezer trawlers, this big mechanized fleet from Cuba, Russia and from every other country that wants a licence. There they are. They are catching the squid, preventing them from getting up to our northern areas, which are represented by members of this House who represent people who could not get a licence today even if the squid struck in. If you fly a Cuban flag you can do it.
There is no capelin. The government announced the other day that there is no capelin, none at all. There is another restricted fishery. You cannot go and fish capelin if you wished. None of your constituents can if they wished. Oh, no, that is a restricted licence again. There is only a select few people and they are under strict regulations on where they can fish capelin. Five foreign nations have been given capelin inside our 200-mile zone this year under this famous NAFO agreement, last November.

The Soviet Union has quotas of capelin in a zone called 3NO. The hon. member for Bonavista-Trinity-Conception knows that very well because a great many of his constituents have been thrown in jail for fishing in 3NO over the past year. We have seen it all on television.
Talk about an endangered species. Talk about being an environmentalist. On the quota sheet now it just says: "Russians". They have a quota for cod of 1,600 tonnes in 3NO, where the hon. member's fishermen are being arrested. They have a quote for capelin, that are not supposed to exist, in 3NO and so have five other nations under this so-called international agreement that was signed, sealed and delivered by people who claim that they are environmentalists but who place Canadians at the bottom of the list. Every other foreign nation can walk in with the compliments of Canada and stick out a net anywhere.
As for redfish, there are fish plants that have closed that processed redfish in eastern Canada. Yet there are quotas given in zone 3K, my riding and the top of the hon. member's riding over there. There are several foreign nations who are fishing redfish this year and we are closing fish plants. We are saying it is an environmental catastrophe and we have to go down to some conference and ask all these other nations to respect these quotas and we are bending over backwards just because it is a request from a foreign nation to give them quotas.
What about northern cod? We have had a disaster in Canada. They call it the biggest disaster in the fishery ever, northern cod. France just got a few extra licences for northern cod all because a document had to be translated down in New York. It did not matter to France, did it? France was given an extra 2,000 tonnes beyond the end of April until the end of June, while awaiting the translation of a document that concerns a boundary dispute off the south coast of Newfoundland.
Nine factory freezer trawlers from France are presently fishing the northern cod today. The motion before the conference that we are talking about today talks about international co-operation. You talk about it, international co-operation. You know that the best spawning grounds in the northwest Atlantic that is not within Canadian control, that is not within total Canadian control is an area called the Flemish Cap.
The Environment
It is a shallow area in the Atlantic Ocean. It comes up to 30 fathoms when the water is low, and because of that, the sun creates an environment where fish can feed. It is an internationally recognized spawning area for all different types of fish.
This year, when we are sending people to international conferences, when cabinet ministers are going all over the globe saying that we are going to conserve our fishing resource, when there is a motion at this international conference dealing with international co-operation, what happened in the last six months? Canada agreed to reopen the fishery on this internationally recognized spawning and nursery ground for fish that lies approximately in the mid-Atlantic, 320 miles southeast of the city of St. John's.
Who holds the quotas? Nine nations hold the quotas, given by Canada. What is the total quota? I will give you an example. For cod it is 13,900 tonnes. Canada has 100 tonnes. Nobody should be there. What did Canada do when the matter came up for a vote a couple of months ago in the city of Halifax at the NAFO meetings? They abstained from voting.
Every scientist in this country who passes judgment on our fishing resources recommended against the reopening of the fishery on that spawning ground. The Government of Canada advised the people who voted in that meeting to allow the reopening of the fishery in that internationally recognized spawning ground in the northwest Atlantic.
In conclusion, let me say that on behalf of the people who actually are involved in the fishery and involved in things that my hon. friend referred to in his address on the Arctic, the Government of Canada has to realize that Canadians have needs, that Canadians must come first, that in our fishery the best fish you can take out of the ocean is a fish that is caught by one man in a little boat over the side of his boat.
That fish would be a delight for a fisherman to eat, not one caught by modern technology in a ship with a control room that looks like a scene out of Star Wars, not in a control room where you have 50 television cameras and computers on each end of your nets as they do in those vessels from those foreign nations that have destroyed the resource in the north. They are in the process of destroying it on the east coast of Canada, all because Canada wants to be nice to everybody else in the world.

The Environment
The real people who run the federal department of fisheries is the Department of External Affairs.

subtopic: UNITED NATIONS CONFERENCE ON THE ENVIRONMENT AND DEVELOPMENT
speechtext: Since no more members have asked to be recognized, pursuant to order made Wednesday the motion is deemed put and adopted.
Motion agreed to.
